mangopositive^/asus-tuf-gaming-x570-plus-wi-fi-socket-am4-usb-c-gen2-amd-motherboard-with-led-lighting/6356983?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^5^0^"The other boards have more features
column2: but I found that this board
column4: had everything I needed it to have.

column1: Okay
column2: full disclosure... I had the 3900x in my cart and this was the only board Best Buy had that wasn't sold out.  But i was relieved to see online folk recommending it in reviews.  It works pretty well.

column1: I had no issues
column2: save for having to deactivate wifi in the Bios to get Windows to install.  That took longer than it should have to figure out
column3: but I'm not an expert at this stuff.

column1: This was my first non-Intel build.  Despite the early-adopter beta-testing stuff
column2: the experience has been relatively painless."^4^Jul 31

column1: ITAngel^/asus-tuf-gaming-x570-plus-wi-fi-socket-am4-usb-c-gen2-amd-motherboard-with-led-lighting/6356983?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^5^1^"This is a great motherboard with a lot of protection features. However
column2: I feel that even though they stripped some features of this motherboard like temp sensors
column4: and on board usb-c header. I feel that for what you pay is not a bad thing at all. So for

column1: Pro: Nice looking motherboard with very good VRMs and a lot of protections. Ran the AMD Ryzen 3700X pretty well and is worth it
column2: if you are not planning to overclock. It is able to run 3700X
column5: and 3950 base on VRMs power capacity.

column1: Cons: No bios flashback to recover you must remove the battery and hope it clears your issues. No USB-C header on the motherboard for a case that may have a front USB-C port. The motherboard release some pretty high heats from it so you need a very airflow case. System kept my fans pretty high and they went up and down a lot with the speed
column2: even on silent mode. Weird bios behavior Froze at 90% bios flash

column1: My thoughts: Overall is a nice starter build motherboard with the ability to run a 3700X/3800X/3900X
column2: and 3950X. For the price you can't beat it."^4^Oct 24

column1: mandiv^/asus-tuf-gaming-x570-plus-wi-fi-socket-am4-usb-c-gen2-amd-motherboard-with-led-lighting/6356983?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^0^"No problems but ran into a few things.
I do wish the manual was a little more clear. On one page of the manual when talking about hooking up the power supply
column2: it says do not hook up only a 4 pin for cpu power
column3: but do an 8 or an 8 and a 4 since only a 4 may cause it to overheat. Then later it shows a picture of you hooking up only a 4. (To just have it take up half of the 8 pin slot.) That is confusing. Also
column6: dont have an 8 connector at all
column7: but have two 4s instead. After talking to many people and doing research
column8: I found I could hook up both 4s to get to 8 total pins. I did one to the 8 slot and one to the 4 slot. Wish it would have mentioned that as a possibility.

column1: Windows 10 did not pick up the wifi drivers
column2: so be sure and save the drivers to a thumb drive in advance if needed!

column1: Also
column2: bios picked up my hard drives but wouldn't boot them. Manual doesn't mention this
column3: but I had to go into bios and select a compatibility mode of legacy only instead of the new + legacy

column1: Hope this helps!"^4^Dec 1

Cube^/asus-tuf-gaming-x570-plus-wi-fi-socket-am4-usb-c-gen2-amd-motherboard-with-led-lighting/6356983?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^0^"Used with a 3700x and rtx 2070 Super. No problems at all."^5^Oct 13

syliftech^/asus-tuf-gaming-x570-plus-wi-fi-socket-am4-usb-c-gen2-amd-motherboard-with-led-lighting/6356983?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^0^"During my build process I had followed reviewers and purchased a Gigabyte Aurous Elite with wifi. Bad luck on that
column2: the board failed to post several times and the wifi was very poor

column1: This board was very simple to setup
column2: the wifi was amazing in comparison. Some key factors
column3: Aura rgb needs community fixes to get running correctly
column4: out of box it has failed since 2018. Asus armory needs to be disabled in bios before your OS install
column5: and don't run Asus AI3 suite. Asus handy helper tools like this often cause driver conflicts or just irregularities. Besides that it is a fantastic board
column6: if you can only get one x570 board in a 200$ price range at best buy this is the best choice."^4^Oct 7

column1: JamexRZ^/asus-tuf-gaming-x570-plus-wi-fi-socket-am4-usb-c-gen2-amd-motherboard-with-led-lighting/6356983?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^5^2^"Great motherboard for the ones that don't want to break the bank with more expensive x570 ones. The VRM's are excellent (check buildzoids youtube channel
column5: and are among the lowest VRM's temps for the price).

column1: Stability is great
column2: I have it paired with a Ryzen 9 3900x and it can boost up to 4.55Ghz totally stock (very close to the 4.6ghz advertised).

column1: I also have two 16gb sticks of corsair vengeange pro rgb 3200mhz
column2: overclocked at 3600mhz (using Ryzen dram timings calculator) totally stable.

column1: It has nice features
column2: like wifi and gig lan. The onboard sound is nice and up to 7.1. Some people say the chipset fan is noisy
column3: but can't hear it at all
column4: granted my PC is in the floor and closed. It does spin all the time though
column5: I wish Asus would provide a bios update with fan profiles for it (like other mobos
column6: like a silent one when temps are low and then ramps up when temps go up).

column1: It does not support SLI
column3: SLI and Crossfire are dead now anyways.

column1: There was a bios update
Only con
column2: is it appears to have an incompatibility with my Fnatic streak keyboard
column3: but just in the bios. Its totally useless
column4: it lags and I cannot type at all in there to change values. Once it boots to windows its fine. Hope it can be fixed on a bios update.

column1: Other than that
column2: great mobo for 3rd gen ryzen for the price
column6: see the reviews above on those youtube channels!)."^5^Aug 23

column1: MCaboose^/asus-tuf-gaming-x570-plus-wi-fi-socket-am4-usb-c-gen2-amd-motherboard-with-led-lighting/6356983?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"The TUF GAMING X-570 is a great piece of motherboard hardware. It has a good aesthetic
column2: great thermals and decent overclocking capability for the price. However
column3: ASUS proudly advertises the motherboard as a RGB board. This was at first simply a bonus to the already nice set of features on the board
column4: but it turns out that AURA SYNC is horrible. After having issues with my colors resetting to default rainbow every time I played Rainbow Six Siege (ironic
column6: I decided to simply try reinstalling the software. Huge mistake on my part. Now the program won't even open
column7: and my PC is stuck with a single color and pattern. ASUS support won't even talk to me
column8: it tells me to ask Best Buy for help every time even though Best Buy likely knows little about how AURA even works. If you're an RGB enthusiast
column9: either go for a different mobo brand or pay the premium for Corsair fans and etc. ASUS is not the way to go for RGB."^3^Dec 5

column1: Mike^/asus-tuf-gaming-x570-plus-wi-fi-socket-am4-usb-c-gen2-amd-motherboard-with-led-lighting/6356983?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^1^"I'll preface by saying when it works... it works excellent. But there are lots of potential bugs and at least one certain bug. First off
column2: be sure to start with the QVL on this product
column3: quite a few of Best Buy's DRAMs are not on it. Secondly
column4: be aware that the drivers are a little buggy. I've only run in to one certain instance
column6: when using one of the two USB 2.0 headers
column7: for some reason
column8: the board kills the Wi-fi/Bluetooth. Switch to the second header on the board and the Wi-fi turns back on. I'm also having an intermittent failure to load past the 'Welcome' screen
column9: but can't place blame squarely on the board yet as I'm using PNY's memory and they are not on the QVL. Additionally
column10: some are reporting similar issue with a Win 10 update. So it may be QVL related
column11: it may be Win 10
column12: or it could be the board... unsure.

column1: The last thing
column2: I'm just not used to the BIOS options
column3: lots of tinkering was needed to simply boot up initially. My past boards have been plug and play
column4: but that's not the case with this one
column5: for me. The settings were Boot device compatibility features (CVM
column6: UEFI/Legacy). Not a big deal
column7: but again something that needs to be found during setup.

column1: All that said
column2: it is a very good board when it works. Seems weird to say its stable after all that
column3: but it is... when it boots."^2^Oct 28

column1: King^/asus-tuf-gaming-x570-plus-wi-fi-socket-am4-usb-c-gen2-amd-motherboard-with-led-lighting/6356983?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"I paired this mobo with an NVMe ssd to make use of PCIE 4.0 and its awesome!"^5^Oct 5

Nattyice^/asus-tuf-gaming-x570-plus-wi-fi-socket-am4-usb-c-gen2-amd-motherboard-with-led-lighting/6356983?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"I had trouble picking an board for my new Ryzen 3rd gen build. But this unit has been solid. Liked the vrm setup. Feel like it will be plenty to run a 3950x when I got to upgrade later. Wish it had a header for a front USB c. Only downside I can find with this so far.
Working great with my GTX 1070 and Ryzen 3600."^4^Oct 4

Inepsa^/asus-tuf-gaming-x570-plus-wi-fi-socket-am4-usb-c-gen2-amd-motherboard-with-led-lighting/6356983?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"This board has been performing quite well. I have a Ryzen 7 3700x in it and love the speed. I was able to overclock my memory from 3000 to 3200 with very nice timings. The motherboard supports lots of memory options and very good manual overlocking support for memory. Temps are low across the board.

I'm taking away a star because of a few annoying things. Spread spectrum cannot be disabled which causes several monitoring apps to show your base clock at 99.8 meaning you don't see true 4.4ghz speeds. You're technically still achieving those speeds
column2: it's just very dumb that we cant disable spread spectrum.

column1: This means you also cannot adjust the base clock. The reason it's annoying these features are not available is because this is the X570 chipset
column2: the highest-end AMD AM4 socket chipset. Access to these basic features should be there."^4^Sep 27

column1: Kyle^/asus-tuf-gaming-x570-plus-wi-fi-socket-am4-usb-c-gen2-amd-motherboard-with-led-lighting/6356983?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"Unlike a lot of 'budget' X570 boards
column2: this one stacks up to even a lot of higher end boards. It has all the features you'd really want
column3: and the power delivery and VRM cooling is more than adequate. A lot of lower end boards have issues with overclocking or boost frequencies due to poor VRM cooling
column4: but this board doesn't seem to have that issue."^5^Sep 16

column1: Steven^/asus-tuf-gaming-x570-plus-wi-fi-socket-am4-usb-c-gen2-amd-motherboard-with-led-lighting/6356983?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"Awesome X570 motherboard.  Excellent price to features ratio. Best VRM in a low cost AM4 motherboard available!"^5^Aug 21
MasterG7^/asus-tuf-gaming-x570-plus-wi-fi-socket-am4-usb-c-gen2-amd-motherboard-with-led-lighting/6356983?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^1^"It does what its sposed to
column2: the only reason I'm taking a star off is cause they wont let you control the fan curve of the chipset fan. Its louder than the whole PC combined."^4^Aug 9

column1: Panda^/asus-tuf-gaming-x570-plus-wi-fi-socket-am4-usb-c-gen2-amd-motherboard-with-led-lighting/6356983?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"An affordable X570 motherboard that does not cost $300 with Wi-Fi and bluetooth. Booted up right away after installation running Ryzen 7 3700X perfectly fine with stock cooler and manual timings on V-Color RAM. Make sure to use DRAM Calculator for Ryzen to maximize performance. Also
column2: it has some nice RGB headers to connect some RGB LED strips. No complaints so far besides multiple bluetooth devices connection interference at random times. I believe this could be cause by my case? Anyways
column3: still an awesome X570 motherboard for the price."^5^Aug 9

column1: TheCatsback04^/asus-tuf-gaming-x570-plus-wi-fi-socket-am4-usb-c-gen2-amd-motherboard-with-led-lighting/6356983?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"What can I say?!  If all you need is a solid well build reliable and stable mother board for moderate gaming
column2: I went with ASUS TUF gaming plus X570!

column1: After I returned two IBUYPOWER gaming PCs.  Tthe 1100 dollar system had a ASUS 365 board that over heated big time...not over clocked either by third day of game play
column2: and the 1500 dollar system had an ASROCK hunko-junk bottom of the barrel board that would not let me install a fresh Windows 10 and had a monster ugly bios to work with.

column1: I got the ASUS TUF Gaming X570 because it was affordable (less than 200 bucks)
column2: and I wanted an AMD system (the IBUYPOWER systems had GREAT components that included an Intel i7 9700k processor).  I wanted to build my system from scratch
column3: and I wanted it better than the pre-built systems.  I did no research on this ASUS TUF GAMING before I bought it.  It was just within my budget

column1: AFTER I put my system
column2: I was QUITE pleased with it.  I did all the research later
column3: and this board gets a LOT of positive YouTube test videos
column4: AND Ive not found any negative reviews except by reviewers that want a higher end gaming system.  I dont count these because they could really find no faults with the board except for wanting more higher end gaming functions...like more than casual enthusiast level need.

column1: It is NOT as fast as the IBUYPOWER systems.  For example
column2: my M.2 drives ran faster bench marks on the IBUYPOWER systems I bought (and returned for valid reasons:  Over heathing and not accepting my Fresh Windows installs).  But that said
column3: the benchmarks are still within what would be expected and as advertised.  Blazing fast speed anyway is what I get on this board...read/write is super fast (just faster on the IBUYPOWER systems).

column1: My Asus board has never crashed or frozen.  The board temps never go past the high 20s Celsius as far as temp.  My Graphics card
column2: AMD CPU and memory stay cool and well within normal good temps (never above low 60s on the CPU...the Graphics card stays in the low 40s).  I boot into windows from power start button to sign on in about 8 seconds (M.2 drive is amazing).  The bios is SO EASY to work with; fairly intuitive and safe to play around with if you are a beginner...just as advertised.  I highly recommend doing YouTube searches on functions you understand in the bios.  I doesnt take much time
column3: and you would quickly learn there is a lot of stuff you dont even need to play with because its all taken care of
column4: but if you gotta do something
column5: its easy enough to undo it and return to normal/default.

column1: Im a moderate gamer
column2: and the game of choice (world of Warcraft) is not the most demanding game.  The Asus TUF Gaming Plus X570 is perfect for this.  I have an AMD Ryzen 3800X
column3: and Corsair Dominator Platinum 3.2 ghz RAM (RGB is cool).  I find I do NOT need to over-clock
column4: but I did try some minor automated over clocking
column5: and the system remained super stable
column6: and no over heating with just the AMD Ryzens packed cooling fan (The Prism Wraith).  I run my CPU on factory Default just because there is no need to over-clock for my needs
column7: but if you needed to
column8: I found no issues with what little automated over-clocking I did do.  I have a Corsair 850 power source
column9: and I have both the 8 and the 4 power connecter  plugs plugged into the board.  Every thing runs perfectly.  NO PROBLEMS AT ALL!

column1: I have two M.2 drives on my system.  I decided to not have any other drive types and prefer to just use peripheral drives for other storage needs.  Both drives run equally fast (Gen. 3X4)
column2: so there was no sacrifice.  My Graphics card (Nvidia RTX 2070 Super) also Runs at full potential...no lane sacrifices at all and reads at Gen. 3.0x16).

column1: So
column2: for me?  I have my gaming needs met
column6: all work just as they should on this system running the ASUS TUF GAMING X570.

column1: I HIGHLY RECOMMEND THIS BOARD!"^5^Feb 28

column1: Bklynman671^/asus-tuf-gaming-x570-plus-wi-fi-socket-am4-usb-c-gen2-amd-motherboard-with-led-lighting/6356983?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"Amazing quality. Would deffly buy again if needed."^5^Sep 20

charliem^/asus-tuf-gaming-x570-plus-wi-fi-socket-am4-usb-c-gen2-amd-motherboard-with-led-lighting/6356983?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"Got this to use with a 3700X CPU. They work great together."^5^Sep 14
Hightechredneck^/asus-tuf-gaming-x570-plus-wi-fi-socket-am4-usb-c-gen2-amd-motherboard-with-led-lighting/6356983?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"When Zen2 came out
column2: there were a lot of boards on the market for way over the comparative Intel price point.  After doing a lot of comparing
column3: this board was NOT one of them.  Asus offered a very solid power phase handling for reliable and strong power delivery
column5: good cooling on the VRMs and southbridge
column6: reinforced PCI x16 lane
column7: good connectivity
column8: and an attractive looking board.  Many boards above this price range attempt to overdo the gamer stereotype
column9: and this TUF series is a simple
column10: less is more approach.  CPU dropped in
column11: the board posted just fine
column12: and the memory overclock worked well.  Aura lighting connected well and has worked flawlessly since day one.  I've had two times where the board will power on
column13: leave a red LED on the board and refuse to post... Hard power off and fire back up fixes that and its been so minor in the time I've had it that I don't take away anything from the board as I suspect a BIOs fix is incoming.

column1: My only complaint about this board is that the QFan control (Which is an Asus thing
column2: not just this board) is total garbage.  Run the configuration/listening tool
column3: and it will change the min/maxes of your fans every time
column4: and really just doesn't do a good job controlling them either.  It maxes the 'graph' of changes at 70c
column5: which a stock 3700x on the Wraith cooler will touch on load
column6: and it will spike at that temperature often
column7: so your fans will rev quite a bit and be pretty annoying overall.  For this reason I'd recommend a manual fan controller of some type... Corsair
column8: thermaltake
column9: anyone really.

column1: Overall I recommend the board.  Its the right combination of price
column5: and brand name/warranty.  The fan issue prevents me from giving it a 5* review
column6: but it doesn't deter me from recommending it."^4^Sep 13

column1: Sean^/asus-tuf-gaming-x570-plus-wi-fi-socket-am4-usb-c-gen2-amd-motherboard-with-led-lighting/6356983?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"Was looking to build a gen3 Ryzen system and this had everything I needed.  The built in WiFi is great and system had no issues POSTing.  However
column2: I  can not get the addressable RGB to work at all.  The header for it on the board is very loose and the connector will not stay connected.  The onboard RGB on the board only comes on when the system has been shut down and the power supply switch in the on position - Does not work when computer is running or at any other time.  While I'm not big into RGB
column3: it would still be nice to be able to set it up

column1: ST1NGRAY1979^/asus-tuf-gaming-x570-plus-wi-fi-socket-am4-usb-c-gen2-amd-motherboard-with-led-lighting/6356983?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^2^"The MB has nearly a blackout design. It appears well made and has whats needed for perhaps a 1st time builder or someone who has no desire to wrap up $10k in a build that has a threadripper and multiple GPUs. It has everything needed for an ADVANCED build: space for 4-DDR4 RAM up to 4
column2: 000Hz. Theres room for 2 GPUS running in SLI. 2-M.2 ports.  Its an X570 board and supports PCIe 4.0. Its wireless if thats what you need. Has more than enough SATA ports.

column1: I cannot think of any reason a builder would need anything more than this board unless you are a serious
column3: enthusiast that is spending upward of $10
column4: 000.00 on their build. The price point is good. It was easy to install. All hardware necessary was included. BIOS was easy to navigate and update.

column1: I was really looking at some of the $400-$700 MBs because I felt as though I had to have THE BEST. But then I had to reality check myself and ask...What do I need?  I realized this MB has literally EVERYTHING I needed. No frills. I didnt need to spend an extra $500 on a top of the line MB that has technology that requires very expensive hardware to take advantage of it.
If youre looking for an excellent MB for less than $200
column2: then this would be it!  Even several PC reviewers recommend this MB for under $200.  No regrets...absolutely none. I love this MB."^5^Feb 18

column1: T13N^/asus-tuf-gaming-x570-plus-wi-fi-socket-am4-usb-c-gen2-amd-motherboard-with-led-lighting/6356983?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^0^1^"I upgraded from an X370 motherboard (Gigabyte GA-AX370 Gaming K7) and I think I made the right decision for sure. Although this motherboard does not have all the frills/features of higher end motherboards
column2: I actually prefer the minimalist nature of this motherboard. I also like the TUF color scheme.

column1: I installed a Ryzen 9 3900X
column3: 512GB NVMe M.2 (and other Firecuda/SATA SSDs) and an RX Vega 64 (Power Color RX 5700XT Red Devil on the way though) and all went well without any issues (POST no problems
column4: BIOS setup was a breeze and even my Windows 10 transfer via sysprep/driver removal went unexpectedly smoothly). BIOS upgrade was easy via the internet and I am up and running. Gaming at 1440p with this new rig (MOBO
column5: CPU new that is) and everything is smooth so far!"^5^Nov 17

column1: Khatar^/asus-tuf-gaming-x570-plus-wi-fi-socket-am4-usb-c-gen2-amd-motherboard-with-led-lighting/6356983?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^0^1^"Motherboard BIOS wouldn't detect either one of my 2 SSD drives but could see my NVMe drive. Updated the BIOS from v0807 to 1201 to see if it would help and it made a little progress. Would see my Samsung 860 SSD but not my Intel SSD. Took way too many attempts to try and install Windows 10 from USB flash drive. Friend in town bought the same board a month before and had the same issues but finally got his working.Ended up returning motherboard after ordering Asus Prime X570 board which worked flawless on first boot up. Wish TUF board worked out but definitely needs the bugs and flaw fixed. Would've bought the Prime board from Best Buy if they sold it but unfortunately they didn't."^2^Nov 17

AlienOUTLAW90^/asus-tuf-gaming-x570-plus-wi-fi-socket-am4-usb-c-gen2-amd-motherboard-with-led-lighting/6356983?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^0^2^"One of the best MOBO on the market for mid tier gaming!!"^5^Jan 13
Bossman^/asus-tuf-gaming-x570-plus-wi-fi-socket-am4-usb-c-gen2-amd-motherboard-with-led-lighting/6356983?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^4^6^"I got two of these motherboards
column2: one for my gaming rig at home and one for my new work PC. The gaming rig was pretty stable which is why I decided to build the work PC as an identical rig. Problem is it was flaky from the start. Windows crashed out twice locking up
column3: and the second time the SSD vanished and was not found by the motherboard. I reseated the memory
column5: SSD etc but it was still flaky so I decided to upgrade the BIOS to v1405 from the v1404 that came with it. Boom. Instant brick that I had to return to Best Buy for an exchange.

column1: Then to top it all off
column2: last night I was running CrystalDiskMark on the gaming rig to see if it was better after doing a firmware update on the Corsair MP600 I am using
column4: it rebooted itself in the middle of doing the test.

column1: Now finally if you look at the layout of this board
column2: some idiot at ASUS decided it would be a great idea to put the motherboard chipset fan right behind the primary PCIe slot. Guess what goes there? Your GPU. And guess what happens if you have a half decent GPU with 2 or more fans on it that it is double wide? It covers the *entire* motherboard fan
column3: so the motherboard chips can't breathe!

column1: So at this point not only is the BIOS super flaky
column2: but I suspect part of the general flakiness of this board may well be due to the motherboard chipset fan not being able to do it's job. Guess I am gonna try the MSI boards out.

column1: Oh
column2: and if you do get this motherboard (or actually any X570 chipset motherboard)
column3: you will need at least an 850W power supply. Not because it needs all that power
column4: but because it needs an extra 4-pin 12V ATX power supply connection next to the standard 8-pin 12V ATX connection and power supplies less than 850W generally only come with one of those (as I found out). In order to get decent performance use Precision Boost Overdrive on your CPU (especially if you have a Ryzen 9 3900X or bigger)
column5: you will want that extra 12V power line attached. I suspect one reason the work rig was flaky is because I did not have that attached but it was still flaky even with PBO disabled."^1^Jan 3

column1: Giovani^/intel-core-i7-9700k-octa-core-3-6-ghz-socket-lga-1151-desktop-processor/6302021?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^9^0^"I upgraded to see what all the jazz about Intel was and I have to say that these are my insights:

Overall consider the 3700x and 9700K if you're buying a new chip for the long haul I picked this one because I never have had an Intel before and gaming has been much better. Content creation has been the same or a little worse to the 2700x so I can only imagine the 3700x"^5^Aug 30

column1: AMD has been much better about keeping their CPU's compatible with their supporting motherboards by minimizing disruptive socket changes despite frequent CPU updates.
If you are in the market for a new CPU
column2: I would wait until the Comet Lake CPUs become widely available along with the supporting motherboards. Then weigh the advantages and drawbacks of Intel and AMD.

column1: That is
After a couple of hours playing Call of Duty: Black Ops 4
column2: my computer suddenly shut down. After a few seconds
column3: I pushed the power button. For a split second
column5: but then it shut right back down. I let it sit for a minute
column6: then tried again. This time
column7: it stayed on for a few seconds
column8: then there was a crackle/pop from the GPU
column9: the computer shut down
column10: and smoke came out of the case.

column1: I have read a few reviews of other people having this exact same problem. I'm extremely skeptical on getting a replacement. But because it is such a good price for the performance
column2: I am most likely going to get a replacement. Let's hope the replacement card actually works like it should."^2^Oct 15

KnightTechDev^/xfx-amd-radeon-rx-580-gts-black-edition-8gb-gddr5-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card-black/6092641?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^6^0^"This card is the direct successor of the RX 480
column2: and it's a newer faster modified version of the RX 580 as well.

column1: I got this to upgrade a machine from an RX 480 for AAA game development and game content creation.
I have very specific feature and functional requirements and the hardware I choose must meet those requirements
column2: but it must also be at an affordable price and offer a specific level of performance and features I expect within reasonable limits.

column1: These requirements are easier to meet with today's hardware from AMD.
The RX 480 was more than enough for my needs but I had the opportunity to upgrade to a RX 580 that was available at store for a reasonable price
column2: any higher and I would've skipped it.

column1: I considered the RX 590 and even 5700 XT and NVIDIA RTX graphics cards but the prices of those cards plus the features and performance they offer at that cost is a huge drawback compared to the basic requirements needed.
The RX 590 would use alot more wattage
column3: perform 20% - 30% better but cost more when that level of performance and watt usage isn't needed to achieve those same graphical results visually and this version of the RX 580 can actually match the RX 590 for the most part with some proper tweaks while running cooler and using less wattage.

column1: The same goes for the 5700 XT though it's in a higher level class of performance balance for a higher tier of newer card
column2: that price does come at a premium and availability of 590 and 5700 models are sketchy right now.

column1: NVIDIA Graphics Cards and RTX in general are way overpriced for the performance and what's actually needed and they don't have enough shader processors and low latency compared to AMD. Though the tech demo's look nice and game engine's are now starting to feature NVIDIA's ray tracing functionality
column2: during development so far I've not had anyone once suggest to me the need to use NVIDIA's ray tracing for realism
column5: I know the Star Wars games and various titles are now using it. From my personal experience
column6: so far I've never needed to use it in development or content creation and that's a fact
column7: and is not something I ever think about. Though the soft shadows look nice when the feature is turned on
column8: it doesn't justify the price for development or usage of that 1 feature. But I'll look into it if prices ever come down in the next few years.

column1: I work with things such as Unreal Engine
column5: and much more. This video card handles everything I've thrown at it and then some
column6: both the RX 480 and RX 580 can play the latest generation games without any problem.

column1: It play's video's on Youtube and movie sites 1080p60fps smoothly on standard 1080p Full HD screens
column2: it optionally down samples the 4k content to fit lower resolution screens with increased quality with a slight performance decrease.

column1: It handles 8k and 16k or larger landscape resolution content development fine too but the standard is usually no higher than 4k for most environments with 2k being even more common or even just 1k
column2: highest recommended being 64k that would be for resolution scale and then the others would be the actual texture to screen resolutions.

column1: The physics (especially with vehicle
column6: VR
column7: audio
column8: and graphics rendering work beautifully and are very responsive.

column1: 8GB of GPU memory is perfect capacity for textures loaded into memory
column2: the cache speed is fast and with the capacity leaves plenty of room for proper optimization during content creation
column4: and for final production as well as for later optimization.

column1: Game streaming options are solid on a stable wired network much like the RX 480
column2: the RX 480 used over half it's power for Steam Link Streaming of games
column3: with direct gaming and streaming with ReLive and DVR turned off was much better
column4: RX 580 is uses much less resources than that and further improves upon streaming.

column1: The latest versions of the AMD Software offers more improved Live Broadcasting
column6: with support for more live streaming and video service accounts. So if you're a gamer
column7: developer
column8: content creator
column9: teacher
column10: or want to communicate remotely you can do so with a higher level of quality. As with the more recent years of previous generation video cards there is dedicated circuitry in these cards that handles recording live video so gameplay and regular computer usage performance is not impacted. The DVR functionality is already in the card and it's software.

column1: The only things I don't like about the RX 580 is that the XFX logo doesn't light up
column3: and the fan's look like cheap plastic and don't light up either and the heat pipe is too close to the power connector and wiring. I generally don't get something at a price like this that is this old (the box says 2016)
column4: but this is a quality product that offered the price to performance at the benefit of an upgrade.

column1: So if you've got anything less than an RX 580
column2: I'd get an RX 580 if there's one in stock at store
column3: or just wait until the next generations of cards come out and get a full sized card that is affordable because at this point in time most these cards are more than capable of doing what you'd be using it for and spending more wouldn't make much sense for most cases."^5^Jan 14

column1: Zer0Chill^/xfx-amd-radeon-rx-580-gts-black-edition-8gb-gddr5-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card-black/6092641?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^6^0^"This card fit right in with my B450M and 2600. Installation was simple. The metal backplate gives the card a solid feel and helps dissipate heat
column2: The wide copper heat pipes do a very good job of removing heat from the gpu and memory.

column1: I am not a big gamer however if I wanted to play AAA titles this card can handle them on ultra high settings at 1080 or 1440.  I mainly develop applications and perform productivity tasks
column2: because this cards architecture is based on the 480 it shares the same computational power but does so more efficiently.  The 4k capability and multi monitor support are great. Although AMD has come out with the Vega VII and RX5700 each of those cards are clocking in at $300.00+. At just about $220 this card now(which was the top card from AMD 18 Months ago) fills a mainstream segment that wants decent upgrade  without breaking the bank."^5^Nov 20

column1: JonJon^/xfx-amd-radeon-rx-580-gts-black-edition-8gb-gddr5-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card-black/6092641?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^6^1^"This is a great card

column1: The fans and cooling on this are great. By default they let it run pretty hot but if you go in and turn down the target temperature in wattman it can stay cool with the fan running super quiet. It undervolts on the CPU well for less power consumption and sees almost 50% performance boosts by adjusting the memory straps and overclocking there.
This is a highly underrated card and a great price from Best Buy. I have been an Nvidia man my whole life
column2: but this card has changed my mind."^5^Nov 30

column3: I started experiencing intermittent loss of video signal(happed every 20 seconds or so) when trying to play any type of game. I thought maybe it was a software issue

column6: and even reverted back to old drivers to see if that would help. Nothing did. So then
column7: I removed this card and put my old RX470 back in. And what do you know
column8: no signal loss whatsoever. Installed the new card again to see if it was just a fluke and it did the same thing. Immediately returned this card and ordered from another brand. Not saying all XFX cards are bad
column9: but stay far away from this particular one."^1^Mar 14

JoeH^/xfx-amd-radeon-rx-580-gts-black-edition-8gb-gddr5-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card-black/6092641?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^1^"The card seemed to work
column2: but I did not stress it for the first month. Minecraft was the only thing anyone had played on it. On day 35 I final sat down to play Fortnite. A few hours in the PC just shut down and then would not power on. Started to debug and the first thing I removed was this card. System powered right back up. Put the card back in and the system will not power on. When I say won't power on
column3: I mean no LEDs light up. Fans don't start. Nothing. Just dead.

column1: Unfortunately
column2: since it was past the 30 days
column3: Best Buy in Nashua offed to give me the phone number to XFX so I could RMA it with them. Thanks but I can google that too.

column1: Buy a brand that may be more reliable then XFX."^1^Mar 27
Floormatio^/xfx-amd-radeon-rx-580-gts-black-edition-8gb-gddr5-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card-black/6092641?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^1^"This card I thought was a good deal but I was wrong.

Bought the card and within 3 weeks it failed. I went to Best Buy for a refund and they would not give it to me and told me to contact XFX. I contacted them and they said to send mine in and they will replace. 2 weeks later I got it back and it worked fine until today.
I want a refund for this thing but I doubt I will receive it. Stuck in a forever loop of spending 30 bucks to ship back to XfX for a refurb one.
STAY AWAY"^1^Mar 23

Chris^/xfx-amd-radeon-rx-580-gts-black-edition-8gb-gddr5-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card-black/6092641?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"Does it pump out the most frames? KyleMTobin^/xfx-amd-radeon-rx-580-gts-black-edition-8gb-gddr5-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card-black/6092641?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"Was able to find this card on sale for a very reasonable price and thought it might pair well with my older generation I5 2500k processor and 8gb of RAM. I can say I'm very pleased with the results. I plan on upgrading around this card and it is nice to know that the already good performance will only get better with further upgrades. Seems well built
column2: the fans can be a little loud but I have only experienced this under absurd amount of load. You can stay in the 1080 range in most games and never hear the fans at all. For that reason I do not count that as a negative on this card. Would absolutely recommend this to any high to mid range pc build."^5^Feb 2

column1: DrRansom^/xfx-amd-radeon-rx-580-gts-black-edition-8gb-gddr5-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card-black/6092641?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"I stumbled across this product on the shelf at a brick and mortar Best Buy and purchased it for the FreeSync capability to pair with my 4K FreeSync monitor. It offers respectable graphics performance but periodic screen flicker
column2: intermittent loss of input signal to the monitor and overheating while gaming are unacceptable defects in a GPU. After sorting through some online reviews it appears that this particular RX 580 from this manufacturer is plagued with the aforementioned defects. I returned it to the store and although I no longer had the receipt the Best Buy staff converted the full purchase price into store credit. Disappointing product but I am more than satisfied with the customer care."^1^Feb 2

column1: Bennett912^/xfx-amd-radeon-rx-580-gts-black-edition-8gb-gddr5-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card-black/6092641?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"I recently purchased a 1080p 144hz FreeSync monitor and was running off an old GTX 750 TI. I decided it was time to upgrade. While I do also support NVIDIA
column2: i wanted to take full advantage of the FreeSync so I went with this GPU over the GTX 1060 6GB equivalent. So far so good
column3: every game I play consistently hits over 100 FPS and the games look amazing. My CPU is also a little dated so I'm not hitting the full 144hz but still pretty worth it. If you are in the market
column5: but also know that AMD just released the RX590 which is slightly better than this one. But price wise
column6: it might not be worth it. Just do some more research!"^5^Nov 18

column1: OuRuKai^/xfx-amd-radeon-rx-580-gts-black-edition-8gb-gddr5-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card-black/6092641?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"I upgraded my old FX quad core system with a new Ryzen 7 2700x system. I installed the XFX - AMD Radeon RX 580 GTS Black Edition 8GB as the price / performance couldn't be beat. This 8GB OC+ GPU sits between the GTX 1060 6GB and GTX 1070 6GB in most benchmarks for $259.00. For the same money you can only get a GTX 1060 3GB card that are not VR Ready. Loaded the included Assassins Creed Odyssey game at ultra graphics and frame rates were higher than my 60Hz monitor could make use of. Well looks like I will need to upgrade my monitor to 4K to see what this cards limits really are."^5^Oct 11

column1: Memo^/xfx-amd-radeon-rx-580-gts-black-edition-8gb-gddr5-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card-black/6092641?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"Don't let the reviews fool you. Will^/xfx-amd-radeon-rx-580-gts-black-edition-8gb-gddr5-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card-black/6092641?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^10^8^"In terms of performance
column2: this is about on par with a GTX 970 for older games that don't make use of DX12
column3: and maybe slightly better than a GTX 1060 for newer games. Also
column4: FreeSync is really nice to have. The main reason I bought this card is because I bought a FreeSync monitor
column5: and my current card (GTX 970) can not make use of FreeSync.

column1: It's entirely possible that I just got a lemon
column2: but I believe that quality control should be included in a product's rating. I'm going to give it two stars because I believe it is a good product if you get a working one (and most people do)
column3: but since mine was defective I cannot rate it above that.

column1: I got it installed. Everything seemed to be working great for a few hours
column2: and then there was a small pop and my computer shut down. My first thought was that I had tripped a breaker because I have a whole lotta stuff hooked up in my room
column3: but everything else was working fine. My computer would not turn back on after that.

column1: I spent about half an hour trying to figure out what was wrong with my computer. At first I thought it might be a PSU issue. I tried unplugging everything and only plugging in the basic necessities and it started up. I shut it down again
column3: and it won't start. So I took it out
column5: and it started up just fine.

column1: I returned this card. I'm debating whether I want to try another one of these or go with a different brand."^2^Jun 21

column5: I am running this video card in a Ubuntu Linux environment and the current drivers work well with it."^5^Dec 13

column3: and knowing I wouldn't be running any 4k monitors for the next couple years. Installed this card in my system
column5: installed all the AMD software and started gaming. Worked great until I was about 15 minutes into a game and my system crashed. Booted back to bios and realized my system temp was resting in the high 80's. Did some google searching the next day to find out I missed the detail about AMD cards running warm. To counter this I adjusted my fan curves more aggressively and went back to business as normal. Until my system crashed again. I contacted BB and was told to check with the manufacturer. So I contacted XFX to see what I could do. They recommended aggressive fan curves (in my case 3 Arctic F120 exhaust fans and 2 Arctic F140 intake fans installed and on the GPU)
column6: undervolt
column7: underclock or attach aftermarket cooling solution. I tried more aggressive fan curves
column8: undervolting and underclocking the card and still could not get this thing to idle below 80c. Contacted XFX again and was told adjust fan curves
column9: undervolt
column11: and I could reapply thermal paste. At this point
column12: my pc sounded like a jet taking off (with my fans maxed out I can move about 200cfm in and 210cfm out in an mATX case) and my patience with this card was wearing a bit thin. I returned the silicone lottery fail to BB
column13: and bought a GTX 1660ti. This card was just way too much work and headache for what should have been a basic plug and play. I don't want to say this card was horrible
column14: I was getting above 75fps during gameplay. Mine may have been a solid silicone lottery fail. You can make the choice on if you want to tinker with settings before you get a card that runs as it should out of the box."^2^Apr 5

column1: xBuckeyex^/xfx-amd-radeon-rx-580-gts-black-edition-8gb-gddr5-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card-black/6092641?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^7^"I bought this card to run on an i7-4770 with 24GB of DDR3 and couldnt be more disappointed. At first glance everything was fantastic from the installation
column2: the AMD software and the initial frame rate I was getting while playing games but the latter part proved an issue.

column1: As soon as this card came under load and was over 60celcius both my HDMI and DP connections would drop signal on and off like someone was unplugging and re-plugging the cables. Meanwhile the DVI connection was rock solid and had no issues. I have 2x80mm / 1x120mm inbound airflow into my case and 1x80mm / 1x120mm outbound so I knew this wasnt the issue. Upon doing some research I found this has been a semi-common issue with these cards.
To eliminate other root causes I popped my gtx970 in the same slot and all of my issues disappeared

Regarding the AMD software it has some AWESOME features but no safeguards. By this I mean it allows you to make changes (like enable HDR) but these changes are actually toggling Windows settings. My issue came when I enabled HDR not knowing that (1) my monitor wouldnt like it and (2) there is no are you sure you want to keep these settings with a revert timer. It was a huge PITA to figure out it was actually toggling the feature in Windows settings."^1^Mar 24

column1: terix^/xfx-amd-radeon-rx-580-gts-black-edition-8gb-gddr5-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card-black/6092641?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^3^"This card has all the makings of a good product. Great price
However
First and foremost
column2: many users wont be familiar with this cards lack of plug and play
column3: eg it requires pci-e in addition to the slot it plugs into pin wise. Second
column4: I had nothing but issues in terms of running hot and then black screening in every game I played. I ended up:

column1: -pushing the power limit up to +50%
-increasing the fan RPMs and Lowering the temp target
-Undervolting the VRAM from 950mv to 900mv
-lowering the Core voltage to 1137mv instead of 1150mv
This bought me about 2 days of good gaming until the card COMPLETELY died on me. Ill be returning to Best Buy as its still within the return window because it only lasted a grand total of 4 days.
To be fair to all
column2: I am not the only one that had this issue but it doesnt seem to be the norm. However
column3: as someone who has had Nvidia cards since i started gaming 20 years ago
column4: I took a gamble on AMD and will not be buying their GPUs again."^1^Jan 21

Kelvin^/nzxt-h510-compact-atx-mid-tower-case-with-tempered-glass-matte-black/6364328?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^10^1^"I did a fair amount of research on this case. You get what you pay for. It came without scratches (although paint job could be a little better)
Note that:
-negative pressure case. all fans are set to exhaust. I swapped them out to corsair fans 120mm rear
-don't bother adding any intake fans on the front
column2: it'll be a waste of money. Watch GamersNexus
column3: and other youtube videos on the H500 and you'll see why.

column1: -My mobo didn't have a USB-C/ USB 3.1 Gen 2 plug
column2: so the usb-c was kinda useless for now. I have a ASUS TUF GAMING WIFI x570
column4: but did come with a usb-c port on the back of the mobo.

column1: Overall for $70

Levire^/nzxt-h510-compact-atx-mid-tower-case-with-tempered-glass-matte-black/6364328?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^5^0^"I just bought this case for my new Ryzen 5 2600X build. Right away I could tell that NZXT designers really thought this case design through. I found the case to be intuitive to work with. The finished build is great looking and very functional.
The cable management solution is very nice with the velcro straps for the main PSU cables and tons of anchor points for zip ties for other component wires like fans
column2: etc. All of the cable mess is behind the motherboard panel and totally out of view even if you do a poor job with cable management.

column1: The stock case fans were quiet
column2: but I replaced them with my Corsair LL120 fans for top and rear exhaust
column3: and two Corsair ML120 fans for intake.

column1: The tempered glass panel is beautiful and mounts with only one thumb screw. This makes access to the inside very quick and easy.  Just be careful as removing the panel can be tricky
column2: and it is glass.  The wire management side attaches with two thumb screws and is also easy to work with.  I did
column4: replace all the thumbscrews with better anodized versions.  The stock screws are plastic gripped ones and looked cheap.

column1: This case is very much worth the money over the low budget cases. I would definitely recommend it to a friend for any workstation or gaming machine within 'normal' spec and moderate overclocks. If you plan to go nuts with overclocking components you may want to spend a little more for a case with more airflow or use water-cooling."^4^Dec 13

Trendy^/nzxt-h510-compact-atx-mid-tower-case-with-tempered-glass-matte-black/6364328?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^5^0^"This case is something else. I appreciate the fact that it costs what it did because I was able to fit approximately $3000 worth of parts in it and not have an issue. You can indeed fit a 280mm rad in the front of the case and set the fans as an intake on the radiator and have good idle temps.
9700k OC at 5.0ghz in here. Idles mid to upper 30s."^5^Nov 21

frodaddy^/nzxt-h510-compact-atx-mid-tower-case-with-tempered-glass-matte-black/6364328?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"My Dell inspiron 3847 parts fit in this case and don't have a problem with proprietary parts- i3-4170 CPU with a corsair H60 on it
column5: 1TB Seagate 7200 rpm HDD for back up and 3-120mm thermaltake fans
column6: 1 corsair fan on the H60. My CPU Temp at idle is 31C-Gaming Temp is 50c-60c. GPU Temp idle is 28c-Gaming Temp is 55c-60c. SSD Temp is usualky sitting at 21c at idle or gaming unless I use crystal disk mark to test then I will see it go up to 32 or 33c with 555mbs reads-535mbs rites so I'm really happy with temps and cable management with this case and overall quality of the product and looks of it too."^5^Dec 28

column1: Seven19o^/nzxt-h510-compact-atx-mid-tower-case-with-tempered-glass-matte-black/6364328?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"this case is very forgiving
column2: the psu basement hides most of your cables and if you have a module or semi module psu your in a even better spot. when i went for a case i was looking for just something local to throw my build in to because my old case was just shot. the case is a good deal if you are getting it on sale or even a open box deal but i wouldn't pay full price. For starters this case has no true breathing room. i could more than likely use my system as a heater due to constricted fresh air intake. you cant add anymore than 4 total fans and personally im one of those that wants to get fresh air to my system even if i have to run them at full tilt and replace them every few years to make sure i don't put extra wear and tear on more expensive parts. it maybe just my way of thinking but i haven't had a system fail yet. thumb screws on it are TORKED DOWN.  i had to replace a few other screws due to stripping on them from factory.

column1: in short if you want good airflow and/or are a overclocker i wouldn't get this case."^2^Dec 19

column1: Roger^/nzxt-h510-compact-atx-mid-tower-case-with-tempered-glass-matte-black/6364328?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^1^"The H510 is pretty great in general
column2: but throw in the frequently discounted 60-70$ price tag
column3: and it's a tough ask for something better.  The stock fan configuration of dual vent works well with a dual front intake
column6: and actually allots enough space to do a full push/pull 4 fans 280mm rad
column7: which should be more than overkill for anything you'd build in a case this size.  It looks excellent
column8: with a very minimalist approach with definitive boundries for each section that manages to make a spartan approach look refined vice cheap.  The tempered glass 3/4 panel is just enough to show off your hardware without being a full glass panel
column9: or god forbid 4 full glass panels
column10: as is found in many of the 'high end' and 'premium' try-hard cases.  The front IO is located at the front of the case on the top panel
column11: which is the only acceptable place for front IO for anyone who isn't a masochist.  It features a single 3.5mm combo audio jack
column12: but included in your case bundle is a splitter adapter for mic/headset so no worries there
column14: and 1 type C USB 3.1 gen 2 and 1 type A USB 3.1 gen 1 (thanks USB moderators forum...).  Basically you have 1 'normal' usb port and one 'ever-phone-but-apple' port
column15: with the former capable of 5Gb/s transfer and the latter capable of 10Gb/s.  It's nice to see a type C
column16: as it is one of the amenities oft reserved for those glassonglassonglass cases that cost twice the price of  this one
column17: however 2 things to note are that:  for your type C 3.1gen2
column18: you will need an accompanying connector on your motherboard
column19: which is a toss up with anything older than x570 mobos
column21: and the type a port uses a full motherboard 3.1 header
column22: which usually supports two ports of it's variety.  My sollution was to dremel out the type c slot and throw in a double front type a
column24: as cool as having that high speed type C port is
column25: do you know anyone who routinely has a type C male to male cable routinely on hand?  In all likelihood
column26: that will the primary cable of use in the future with thunderbolt standards
column30: it's just a pretty awkward port.

column1: ...Also
column3: which is important to me because I carry around a computer all day in my pocket
column4: and I feel like there's no exuse for the giant heavy rigs of yesteryear.

column1: If you're looking for a good deal on a case

column1: Mine came with Samsung memory (you can use GPUz to check your mem brand) so its rated to 2000 mhz (stock is 1938 mhz). So I did a mild overclock to 2000 mhz (which is the official rating)
column2: however other people have been able to add much more
column3: even 1000 mhz more on some reviews
column4: but I didn't need to push it that hight. I was able to push the core clock to +70 mhz
column5: netting an around 2055 mhz on the core. All totally stable.

column1: Power target can be pushed to +116% (to low for my taste
column2: I hope Evga can produce an updated vbios with more power target
column3: they did for the regular 2080's non-super) and 88 C on the temp target.

column1: pefarrell^/evga-super-xc-ultra-gaming-nvidia-geforce-rtx-2080-super-8gb-gddr6-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card-black-transparent/6373486?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"EVGA - SUPER XC ULTRA GAMING NVIDIA GeForce RTX 2080 Super 8GB GDDR6 PCI Express 3.0 Graphics Card - Black/Transparent

Bought this card for $800.  This card drives a 2560 x 1440 monitor at 144hz just fine.  Most of the games run at 144hz.  New AAA titles at ultra settings wont reach the 144hz.  The settings have to be adjusted and lowered.  The LED can be adjusted to match the current color scheme of the PC case.  It reads 'EVGA | GEFORCE RTX 2080.'  It can be run in SLI.  The card takes up 2.75 slots on the motherboard
column2: because of the large cooler.  I had to use 3 slots and 3 screws to secure it.  When using the desktop the fans stop spinning.  They spin up during gaming but I have not noticed any noise so far.  It requires both a 6pin and 8pin connector
column3: and needs at least a 650 Watt power supply.  You can register the card on EVGA and upload the invoice for the warranty.  The card booted up fine out of the box.  Overall it was expensive
column4: but you pay a premium for the high end and current tech."^5^Dec 21

column1: LordPappi^/nvidia-geforce-rtx-2070-super-8gb-gddr6-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card-black-silver/6361328?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^2^"Seriously only had it for a couple of months and the thing crashed last night. Kart^/nvidia-geforce-rtx-2070-super-8gb-gddr6-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card-black-silver/6361328?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^0^1^"There is a lot of discussion of price vs performance between RTX 2070 Super and RX 5700 XT. As an owner of both of these GPU's here is what you need to know. RX 5700XT is the value king
column2: however the software is very little more buggy then Nvidia. 2070 Super runs 10-15% faster on most of my tests
column3: but I have noticed that Nvidia drivers are better designed and lead to lower crashes. At the time of my purchase
column4: I was able to use 10% off coupon from my birthday and also get a free copy of Modern Warfare.

column1: Design of the Founders Edition card is the best in the market. It has this high end apple like design and matched perfectly with my white and silver build. Coil whine is very minimal and this is one of the few 2 slot design cards on the market for 2070 Super.
If you own GTX 1080
column3: performance should be 5-20% higher. Ray tracing is still a gimmick and it really kills a game's FPS performance when it turned on. Modern Warfare looks good
column4: but I really can't tell big difference when RTX mode if ON or OFF. Nvidia also allows Gsync on free-sync enabled monitors

column1: If you are on the budget I would recommend getting RX 5700 and flashing the bios of RX 5700 XT. I was able to get a blower version of RX 5700 for $280 from bestbuy. If you do the math you are saving almost 45% for 10% performance drop. However
column2: flashing the bios of your RX 5700 is a little bit risky
column3: since you can brick the card if you DO NOT follow the procedures correctly. In my experience I have flashed 2 cars and they have been working perfectly."^4^Dec 15

column1: trandy1001^/amd-ryzen-5-3600-six-core-3-6-ghz-socket-am4-desktop-processor/6356278?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^0^"For most people this should be the default choice for a processor in this generation for mixed workloads. It has wide compatibility among most AM4 socket motherboards assuming the bios is up to date also not super picky about DDR4 ram.

The performance is very impressive without caveat in both single and multi-threaded workloads and requires basically no tweaking since it is already highly optimized under its different boost algorithms.
The included cooler provides adequate cooling and quiet enough for most.

column1: If you are upgrading and using a b350/x370 or b450/x470 motherboard
column2: please be sure to check the manufacturer site for a bios update before you try to add your cpu in. It needs to update in order to recognize the new ryzen 3000 series.  After I did that
column3: I had no issues. Just plopped it in and had a smooth experience on my msi b350m gaming pro mobo
column4: but please google your mobo model to check for compatibility issues beforehand. Always best to check first because some mobos do have compatibility issues."^5^Aug 9

column1: The beautiful part about this cpu for me is it performs fantastic out of the box with little to no tweaking aside from prioritizing you're core utilization in the OS. No Integrated Graphics is a bummer but definitely not a deal breaker.
Monitor you're motherboards QVL
column3: powerful and beautiful but ugly as hell if treated wrong lol.

column1: I am currently running this cpu on a Rog Crosshair VI Hero with Best Buy purchased LPX Vengeance dual channel 2400Mhz. I first attempted this setup using LPX Vengeance dual channel 3000Mhz and I nearly lost my sanity dealing with the compatibility hiccups on this motherboard. If you have this board and are not considerably above average in OC experience I highly advise against the ladder ram speed. I literally heard an Asus engineer even advise against the use of 3000Mhz on the Ryzen 5/3600 Rog Crosshair VI Hero combo. The last bios update improved its compatibility slightly but the future initialization errors still persist. Go 2400Mhz or 3200Mhz."^5^Nov 22

Tullio^/evga-super-xc-ultra-gaming-nvidia-geforce-rtx-2070-super-8gb-gddr6-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card-black-transparent/6373489?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^10^0^"Had Best Buy install this card.
I have the yearly Geek Squad membership so my install was no additional charge. The membership is not cheap but it's all inclusive for help
Bought this card since the previous card this replaces was sold out. I always buy through my local store because I don't want to see another empty store like Sears or K-Mart closed.
Anyway
column2: please note that this card takes up three
column3: yes three spaces on your motherboard. I have a full size case and board. Any compact tower may not have the room. THE CARD REQUIRES TWO POWER CONNECTIONS TOO. The power supply I have is a 75 watt Cooler Master Gold supply that has probably 6 different power harnesses to choose from. The tech had to use one of my other harnesses so I had to go grab my power supply box with all the other configurations from home.

column1: Now no problem with installing according to the tech. He also downloaded the latest drivers too.

The card is terrific and I can set everything to Ultra without a problem. The card purchase includes Call Of Duty Modern Warefare download when available in late October. This game has Ray Tracing which there are few games for now but should be more in 2020.
I have been playing Battlefield 4 and saw much more detail and noticed distant movements of players while being a sniper.

My only limitation is now my monitor because on the refresh rate of only 60hz. Much more expense monitors go up to 244hz but those are in the $1000.00 range. No thank you but when my monitor breaks then I will probably go to a 144hz in a couple of years from now depending on costs.
I know this isn't a cheap card but the 2070 card is just a dumbed down 2080 chipset. Unless you have a very high refresh rate monitor you really don't get all that the 2070 card can do.
Go buy the card but don't tell the wife because she will NOT understand unless she is a gamer too.
Now it's time to post my EVGA GTX 1070 Superclocked card on Ebay.
Important to register the card with EVGA and they also offer extended warranty options too.
Best Buy can offer them too so compare your options.
GO OUT AND BUY THAT CARD ALREADY!
Thanks for reading my review."^5^Sep 30

Lawt^/evga-super-xc-ultra-gaming-nvidia-geforce-rtx-2070-super-8gb-gddr6-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card-black-transparent/6373489?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^6^1^"Card is pretty big so make sure you have enough room. Takes 3 slots on mobo. Almost did not get this beast in for it was pressing on sata cable connections.Had to install at an angle.  Temps don't ever go over 70c with firestrike or timespy benchmarks. Came from a gtx 1080FE and still there is about a 30% difference in benchmarks. Highly recommend"^5^Oct 21

YarsRevenge^/evga-super-xc-ultra-gaming-nvidia-geforce-rtx-2070-super-8gb-gddr6-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card-black-transparent/6373489?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^0^"EVGA has upped their quality substantially but then again the price tag reflects this. So I wouldn't worry about the price tag given the performance and quality you are getting with this card. The EVGA 970 SSC I had previously was nice but this card is leaps and bounds better in fit and finish with all the bells and whistles included. You can tell this card means business and endure anything you throw at it. The metal bracket on the back is a really nice touch. Fan design is top notch. It also includes an LED logo. This card is a very solid and well constructed card and you won't feel like something bent or snapped off installing it. The giant heat sync keeps temps around 55C gaming and boosts are great at 1980mhz core and 1750mhz memory out of the box. The fans don't really need to engage that I can hear
column2: so it's really quiet too. If you have a smaller case be sure it will fit because it's a very large card. It also needs more power than a 970 so be sure the power supply is up to it and have the correct power cabling. If your gaming at 1080P be sure to get a nice g-sync or free-sync monitor to take advantage of the increased frame rates as well. My only gripes are there are no converter cables included or case badges. So if you're coming from DVI-DL like me

column1: opivboy2^/evga-super-xc-ultra-gaming-nvidia-geforce-rtx-2070-super-8gb-gddr6-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card-black-transparent/6373489?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"Great card
column3: coming from a gtx970. Will upgrade board and processor later but for now

column7: this thing is awesome."^5^Jan 12

column1: UberRN^/evga-super-xc-ultra-gaming-nvidia-geforce-rtx-2070-super-8gb-gddr6-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card-black-transparent/6373489?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"First off
column3: it is better to buy something like this locally at BestBuy
column4: instead of online. I initially bought this exact same card directly from EVGA
column5: but had to end up RMAing the video cad twice
column6: because of way too much coil whine. Because coil whine isnt considered a defect by EVGA so I got hit with a restocking fee. Even though the tech at EVGA noted the coil whine
column7: they just felt (very subjective here) that it fell within normal limits.

column1: I purchased the card at my local BestBuy on sale
column2: and the coil whine was remarkably less
column3: almost inaudible. Thats that was only under high GPU strain. The card also appears to have been manufactured in 2020 (based of the serial number) verses the 2019 manufactured dates of the ones EVGA sent me.  But... the most important thing to note
column4: if it would have had coil whine
column5: I would have been easily able to exchange or return it that day
column6: instead of the long back and forth of online purchases.

column1: That said the card itself performs very well at 1440 resolutions with all the settings maxed. In my case the card never passes the high 60s for temp
column2: and that is with an additional 100MHz OC above the default clock. Its also nice that this card is one of the shorter 2070 Supers out there. A lot of the 2070 Supers run over 300mm long.

column1: Also
column2: Ray Tracing is kind of a disappointment. Maybe at 1080 resolutions its not big of a performance hit
column4: unless you start turning down the graphics settings
column5: which is defeats the point of having it in the first place.

column1: Only thing to complain about other than whole hassle I had with EVGA
column2: is that Nvidia has the RTX cards priced a little too high. While the RTX 2070 Super performs better than AMD RT 5700 XT by 5-7% its runs about 20% more in price."^5^Mar 25

column1: kbwatson^/evga-super-xc-ultra-gaming-nvidia-geforce-rtx-2070-super-8gb-gddr6-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card-black-transparent/6373489?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"Nvidia finally has their price/performance in line. Beast of a card that handles anything 1440p I throw at it!"^5^Jan 12

column2: and I went from a Vapor X R290 to this and wow. Games are smooth and consistent. I can play at ultra settings with RTX. Cannot wait to play Cyberpunk with this beautiful GPU."^5^Jan 10

column1: CrockPot^/evga-super-xc-ultra-gaming-nvidia-geforce-rtx-2070-super-8gb-gddr6-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card-black-transparent/6373489?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"This has worked flawlessly and is quite an improvement from 1070 that it replaced.  I would highly recommend this GPU for the pricepoint.  Easily instaled as well."^5^Jan 10

RedNinja^/evga-super-xc-ultra-gaming-nvidia-geforce-rtx-2070-super-8gb-gddr6-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card-black-transparent/6373489?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"Pertinent tech details of my system -
Processor: Skylake i7 6700k @ 4.5gHz
Memory: 16gb ddr4 3200 no oc

I'm more of what's called a 'casual gamer' though I am technical and proficient in custom PC builds and components. Upgraded from an eVGA 960 4gb to this 2070 super which is my first 70 series card ever. I'm truly blown away by its performance and quiet fans. Running at the stock clock speed so I haven't bothered to check temps but the fans seem pretty quiet under considerable load. By that I mean Metro Exodus running fully maxed ultra Settings including PhysX and Ray Tracing. The result is a smooth 60+ framerate (yes even with ray tracing) at 1440p. Though there is a bit of coil whine it doesn't bother me in the least. It's not thunderous or anything but it may slightly irritate extreme enthusiasts. I haven't tested 4k since I don't have access to a 4k monitor.

The price dropped by 50 bucks immediately after I bought it so if you can get it at 519 (current as of 12/31/2019) it's an absolute steal. If you don't care about ray tracing or running absolutely maxed out Settings on higher resolutions
column2: you can probably get away with a 2060s for 100 cheaper but even for my casual gaming
column3: I prefer this beast which chews up graphically intense games and spits out smooth high fps even with gorgeous ray tracing."^5^Dec 31

column1: Deez^/evga-super-xc-ultra-gaming-nvidia-geforce-rtx-2070-super-8gb-gddr6-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card-black-transparent/6373489?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"This thing runs everything Ive thrown at it.  I went into evgas x1 software to set a fan curve and make sure it runs a cooler then stock settings.  Either way I can hardly hear it.  Not sure about all the complaints about noises and coil whine.  It pumps out a lot and takes a beating so its gonna make some noises.  I believe some people are just too picky.    By far the best gpu Ive ever owned.   All metal backplate is a nice touch.  Something that Ive always had to install myself after the fact.  RGB is controlled by my Gigabyte motherboard with no problems. It is a big card.  Thickness is almost 3 slots so make sure you have enough space before purchasing.  Otherwise enjoy!"^5^Dec 29

column2: I have to say that I returned the card yesterday.  I held out as long as I could
column3: hoping I could get it working properly
column4: but that wasn't to be.  It is a fast card--very fast
column5: especially compared to the GTX 780 SC that it was supposed to replace.  I started with older games first that I am familiar with
column6: running Tomb Raider 2013
column7: and Rise of the Tomb Raider at 4K ultra
column8: all settings maxed and turned on except for motion blur and film grain (which I do not like).  The benchmarks averaged around 58fps on each title
column9: and in game
column10: the frame rates were equally smooth and stable.  The issues I suffered were graphical and aural.

column1: Graphics issues - With Rise of the Tomb Raider
column2: the card would occasionally freeze the onscreen graphics for a second or two
column4: there would simply be a brief stutter.  It wasn't a once in a while thing--it would happen at least every 4-5 minutes.   My PC has sufficient cooling--3 120mm case fans
column5: and no obstructions on any sides
column6: and it's fairly dust-free.  I also use MSI Afterburner
column7: to ensure the GPU's fans will speed up sufficiently as the temp increases
column8: so there should not have been any issues there.  I have an eVGA 700 watt 80+ power supply
column9: so power was not an issue.  I briefly tried out Metro Exodus
column11: and with all settings maxed out
column12: the frame rate was reasonably smooth
column13: with demanding portions dropping to roughly 45 fps
column15: the average was 50 fps.  For whatever reason
column16: the card must have been overly taxed with Rise of the Tomb Raider
column18: I didn't bother testing Shadow of the Tomb Raider
column19: which is even more graphic intensive.

column1: Sound Issues - for my 4K gaming
column2: I use the GPU's built in audio processor
column3: routed through a Pioneer Elite VSX-LX503 receiver.  When starting any audio track such as a YouTube video
column5: there is always a 2-second delay at the start.  The audio isn't misaligned with any onscreen video
column6: it just takes 2 seconds for the audio to be heard.  This is a huge issue when playing a music playlist
column7: as the 1st two seconds of every single song would be silent.  If the only issue were with Rise of the Tomb Raider
column8: I could live with it--I've already played the game 3 times anyways
column9: but the audio issue was unforgivable.  I tried using both HDMI ports and the DisplayPort
column10: but it didn't matter; the issue never improved or disappeared.

column1: So sadly
column2: as much as I enjoyed the immense speed increase
column3: I just couldn't keep the card and deal with the audio/visual problems.  I imagine I just got a faulty one
column4: but I'll keep researching and consider possibly a different card just to be on the safe side.  More than likely
column5: most people will be over the moon with the performance that the 2070 Super XC ULtra provides."^4^Jan 19

column2: I got that sorted out and it works fine. Cable lengths are enough since I have a MicroATX case. The power supply is semi modular
column3: not fully modular like Best Buy indicates. The motherboard ATX and CPU power are hard wired into the power supply (no big deal for me!!); the rest of the connectors are modular. Use only what you need.

column1: Corsair seems to be a nice brand with mostly good reviews so I went with this 650 watt model that happened to be on sale."^5^Aug 28

column2: so nothing to it. If you are decidinf if you need an upgrade
column3: windows 10 with a few chrome tabs sits at about 5-6GB easy
column4: so 8GB these days looks minimum. Also consider a integrated card that would take some of that RAM as well. 16GB is the safer bet and provides some longevity. Ram specs wise: just make sure you are getting the max supported (speeds) on your device
column5: this is quite useful to get the best performance; especially in the case on integrated GPU's. Also dual channel is a good ideal when possible
column6: could eke out a few extra % of performance
column7: I understand a lot of AMD setups really thrive on this. Also if you can get a pair from the same batch
column8: usually via those pair deals it's apparently the best choice
column9: however if all specs of the new ram match the others
column10: you should be all good. Of course brand
column11: frequency
column12: timings or voltage etc matching would be your best best
column13: but even when they don't match; thing should be fine but you would run at the slowest ram specs. Installing them on most laptops is pretty straight forward but you might needs a few tools (special screwdriver kit) to not end up damaging screw threads and other bits on your laptop. Google your device and most videos out there show what's needed. Just make sure your ram is not soldered
column14: than there is nothing you could do
column15: some laptops do leave one spare slot with one soldered combo though."^5^Jun 24

column1: Mezzerto^/amd-ryzen-7-3700x-octa-core-3-6-ghz-socket-am4-desktop-processor/6356277?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^7^0^"I was an AMD guy 10 years ago and eventually migrated to Intel for gaming. Well... after rave reviews
column2: I tried AMD again and have not been disappointed. While Intel's 9700k and 9900k out performed this CPU in over all FPS
column3: it was typically only by single digits in most games. In Cinebench r20
column4: my 3700x out scored my friends 9900k in multi-core processing power. That result isn't typical
column5: but it shows how close these chips really are
column6: and the 3700x is available at a much lower price point.

column1: But... what does that mean to you? Overall this means that Intel chips are slightly better for just gaming today but if you do just about anything else in addition to gaming or other than gaming... You should really consider AMD and it's new line of processors unless you're willing to pay the premium for Intel's 9900k for extremely small gains."^5^Oct 18
