column1: MOTHMAN^/amd-ryzen-7-3700x-octa-core-3-6-ghz-socket-am4-desktop-processor/6356277?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^8^3^"Put this in a Dan A4 case
column2: runs no more than 80c after 20min of Prime95 even in that extremely cooling restricted environment. The performance vs price reminds me of the old 2600+ days when AMD was laughing at Intel. Huzzah!"^5^Sep 27

column1: ITJIm^/amd-ryzen-7-3700x-octa-core-3-6-ghz-socket-am4-desktop-processor/6356277?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^5^0^"Earlier this year I replaced a 7 year old
column3: custom built computer with something more modern.  I replaced it with an Asus ROG Strix B450-F AM4 motherboard.  Outfitted her with 32GB or memory
column5: and a Ryzen 5 2400G processor.  At the time
column6: the Ryzen 5 was cheap and suited my current needs.  I also had a plan to replace this processor as soon as the third generation Ryzen processors hit the market.  Glad I did.

column1: Installation was fairly simple.  First
column2: I updated the system BIOS with the latest from Asus.  The update took about 20 minutes.  Execution was flawless.  I then reset all Bios settings to factory defaults.  Saved
column3: allowed the system to power cycle one more time.  Then shut everything down.

column1: Second
column3: attached my anti-static wrist band and clipped it to a metal bit on the computer case
column4: and removed my Corsair Hydro H-55 cooler.  I chose not to use the included Wraith Prism air cooler.  The heat sink
column6: and LED lights do look cool.  However
column7: my system has a very clean look now and I felt that adding a giant heatsink and fan would disrupt my case's Feng Shui.

column1: The 2400G popped out of the AM4 socket and the 3700X popped in.  I added a pea sized bead of thermal compound and re-installed the cooler.  I powered up the system
column4: and within seconds I was in Windows.

column1: I was able to clock my memory to their factory specified clocks without any issue.  Games are super fast.  Must faster than on my 2400G.  The 2400G is a bottleneck for any game that requires high single core performance.  Older games mostly.  The 3700X really ups its game here.  Gaming has been fantastic.  Mechwarrior Online
column2: a CryEngine 3 game that is CPU bound
column3: plays on par with an Intel 7 9700 CPU.  More on that in a minute.

column1: I did find a few instances where the 3700X struggled in gaming.  Again
column2: both very old games.  Supreme Commander 2 is a CPU
column4: RTS.  I noticed that when the unit limits are reached and armies are in full scale engagements then the game will stutter a bit.  Nothing that really slowed the game down.  Just annoying.

column1: I also ran into some issues with Star Wars Empire at War.  In all fairness
column2: I was playing this game with a graphics
column4: and special effects mod that really ground the game to a halt when a mighty capital ship exploded.  The special effects simply took over the system with hyper-real primary explosions
column6: debris falling away from the doomed ship
column7: and the animation of the ship itself breaking apart
column8: spinning out of control
column9: and sinking away
column11: into the background of the map.  There were a lot of physics here for a game engine never designed for this type of work.  Ryzen did handle it with a single thread pegged at 100%
column12: got through it

column1: Other than these two instances
column2: gaming has been a dream with this new CPU.

column1: So
column2: let's talk about the Intel i7-9700.  My daughter has an Intel based computer with this processor.  I chose to run some benchmarks too compare the two.

column1: 3D Mark Time Spy:
AMD 2400G - 5
AMD 3700X - 6
Intel 9700 - 6
PCMark10:
AMD 2400G - 3
AMD 3700X - 6
Intel 9700 - 5
SuperPosition:
AMD 3700X - 8
Intel 9700 - 8
Overall
column2: I am getting as good with the Ryzen 3700X as my daughter is getting with her Intel i7 97000.  I am very happy I went with AMD for my future proof mainline computer system.  Gaming is great and productivity is fantastic."^5^Aug 4

Make sure your memory is compatible with this processor and your board so you don't have any issues. Coming from intel my entire life I think saying I was nervous about this purchase was an understatement. I really liked what AMD was doing with this chip
column2: really pushing things in a new direction.

column1: The faster your memory the better
column2: these new chips like fast memory a lot. They also are very dependent on cooling. The better your cooling solution is the faster this processor will go
column3: without you having to do anything other than install a better cooler. The processor automatically adapts to how well its being cooled and overlocks itself.

column1: If you're seeing a higher than normal voltage at stock/auto settings that is absolutely normal. When a program like hwinfo/cpuz reads the voltage it sometimes gets the last peak voltage it was at because the core that its polling is possibly asleep so amd won't let it poll the live voltage because that would wake it up."^5^Sep 9

TopBun^/amd-ryzen-7-3700x-octa-core-3-6-ghz-socket-am4-desktop-processor/6356277?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^0^"slotting this thing into a x470 board may be a little much for those less experienced PC enthusiasts
column2: but otherwise installation is a breeze and works beautifully out of the box. AMDs precisionboost overdrive does a mighty good job of getting the most performance out of this chip with no fiddling in the bios
column3: though if youre so inclined you can tinker a bit with the maximum boost allowed to PBO. the extra performance over the 2700x is definitely real and nothing to sneeze at by any means
column4: but even if it wasnt a marked improvement
column5: the energy savings alone is amazing. i would consistently pull over 110w with the 2700x bit with the 3700x i never pull much over 80w if i hit 80w at all.

column1: another fantastic improvement with this architecture is the DRAM compatibility as well as the improved ability to overclock your DRAM. same 3200 14c kit i had with the 2700x (amd was never able to get to post past 3200mhz) i was easily able to push to 3600mhz no sweat.
very satisfied wit this purchase."^4^Aug 2

column1: Benjy117^/amd-ryzen-7-3700x-octa-core-3-6-ghz-socket-am4-desktop-processor/6356277?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"Faster than my 2700X and 1700 by a lot. column3: the older boards for those should work fine. I don't do overclocking however as I like my parts to last longer this way
column4: so do keep tha in mind. Final note is the cooler that it comes with is impressive. I heard it was solid

column1: Darkangel^/amd-ryzen-7-3700x-octa-core-3-6-ghz-socket-am4-desktop-processor/6356277?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"The Ryzen 7 3700X is an excellent all around value and performer for the money as compared to a similar intel cpu; the build I used this cpu in is performing above my expectations in Cinebench R20 tests at over 4750.  My purchase from Best Buy was competitive and delivery was quick."^5^Sep 6

SiXX5150^/amd-ryzen-7-3700x-octa-core-3-6-ghz-socket-am4-desktop-processor/6356277?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"Upgraded from a 2700x to this.  Some may ask 'why would you do that?? The 2700x is a great processor!'  This is a true statement... however simply put - this 3700x is a substantial upgrade over even the 2700x!   For starters... it uses FAR less power and yet generates substantially better performance!  I re-used my x470 motherboard from the 2700x... and with this processor at stock - it will NOT draw over 90-watts through the socket.  The 2700x stock was around 130-watts... but I had Precision Boost Overdrive enabled - so it drew closer to 170-watts!  That's nearly half the power savings with the 3700x
column2: yet with 20% or more performance in every category.

column1: Oh - and in terms of thermal performance - this processor is EXTREMELY intelligent as well.  I run it under a Noctua NH-D15... and since that cooler is upgraded over what it comes with - it allows the processor to self-overclock and give me all-core averages of around 4.25GHz while intense gaming... and temps around 60-degrees celcius or so.  Stress testing never gets over around 63-65 degrees.
Worth EVERY penny... even for someone who may have last year's 2600x or 2700x.  Upgrade to this - sell your last one on eBay.  You may be out $150 or so
column2: but if you're even still reading this review then you know $150 isn't much for this kind of upgrade.   AMD has hit a home run - and I'm loving every minute of it!"^5^Sep 1

column1: Silas^/amd-ryzen-7-3700x-octa-core-3-6-ghz-socket-am4-desktop-processor/6356277?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"Not only does this CPU absolutely blow Intel's current line-up out of the water

column1: Definitely eager to test out this chip with a water cooler slapped onto it and a slight OC to kick it into high-gear. All in all I really can't complain for what I've received. column1: photofrankFM^/amd-ryzen-7-3700x-octa-core-3-6-ghz-socket-am4-desktop-processor/6356277?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"This is for the AMD Ryzen 7 3700 X 65 watt 8 core 3.6 Ghz CPU. First of all I am not sure why they rate it at 3.6 Ghz as it will boost to 4.4 Ghz for a short duration and then settle in at a constant 4.1 to 4.27 depending on your board and how agressively you set the boost level in the BIOS. I got it to run at almost 4.4 under constant boost
column2: but it crashed after a restart and when I tried to go higher than 4.4 it won't boot. I am not the greatest overclocker
column3: but my experience has been the normal for many review sites who are expert overclockers.

column1: The concensus is that AMD built this to come out of the box with all guns blazing and the fact that it is a 65 watt CPU doesn't give it as much overhead as a 105 watt Ryzen. Note: it is rated at 65 watt TDP
column2: but that is at 3.6 Ghz. When running a brutal stress test such as Furmarks CPU Burner it will pull 11 plus watts per core and a total of as much as 111 watts for the whole package. Thus the reason that it has such a high sustained boost
column3: is that AMD has given it the fuel it needs to do that
column4: and therefore trying to overclock this fast out the gate horse is really not going to be worth the effort. Having said that it is an economically efficient CPU. Under normal production usage it constantly pegs needed cores at 4.4 Ghz while pulling about 50-55 watts and will run at about 30 watts under light usage.

column1: With that said it is a strong performer. I bought it because I need all the speed I can get out of Photoshop and it delivers. I paired it with an X570 board with a 1 TB PCIe 4.0 M.2
column4: three 4TB HDDS and 3 external drive HDDs. I have 32 GBs of DDR4 3200 RAM
column5: an RTX 2060 Super and a 750 Watt Bronze 80 Power Supply. For those who only have one 8 Pin CPU power cable on your PS
column6: don't worry about X570 boards having an 8 pin and 4 pin CPU plug. It runs just fine with just the 8 pin plug.

column1: I didn't try the Wraith heatsink. I installed a 240mm AIO liquid cooler. I have it in a well ventilated case that is in a compartment in my work desk and it runs at 40 degrees C at idle
column2: about 55 in Photoshop. It holds 63 degrees C in Prime 95 and 70 degrees C in Furmarks CPU Burner.

column1: How does it perform? I have a unit with an i7 9700 with 32 GBs of RAM and an RTX 2080 Super. Running Puget Systems Photoshop benchmark test it posts an average score of 860 points. I pulled the 2080 out of it and put it in the new build with the Ryzen 3700 X as GPU performance influences the test. I need to note that the PCie 4.0 capability of the 3700 X with my PCIe 4.0 M.2 and the X570 board registers a 5500 MB/s SSD read speed vs the 3300 MB/s read of the PCIe 3.0 of the i7 system and that probably had some benefit. Running the same Puget Systems benchmark the Ryzen 3700 X system scored 967 points.
This is the most responsive system that I have had to date. My previous systems have been an i7 6700K and an i7 9700.
So I think that this is a great bang for buck CPU
column2: especially if you are willing to use the included Wraith Cooler
column3: but I think in order to really get the full advantage of the 3700 X you need to leverage all of it's potential by putting it on an X570 board with a PCIe 4.0 M.2."^5^Feb 1

column1: Earlier this year

column1: In another comparison

column1: I used to have an Intel i7-8700K and replaced it with the AMD 3700X.  The AMD 3700X has eight cores and 16 threads.  The Intel has six cores and 12 threads.  While the Intel has a faster CPU

column3: by a couple of per cent.

column1: Andrew^/amd-ryzen-7-3700x-octa-core-3-6-ghz-socket-am4-desktop-processor/6356277?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"My journey with Ryzen started with a first gen Ryzen 5 1600.   I believe that it was considered the best cost to performance CPU later that year by a lot of the 'experts'.  I upgraded to the Ryzen 7 2700X as soon as it was released because I was still having some issues playing in VR and I had upgraded to a 2080ti and was CPU bottlenecked (much to no one's surprise).  It was a good chip as well....basically updated the firmware and chipset drivers and I was off and running.  It was obviously a massive improvement in performance.  Still CPU bottlenecked in a few racing sims.  Not bad
column2: but not perfect.  So about 15 minutes after the 2700X was released they came out with the 3rd Generation Ryzen 2 CPU's which was obviously an effort to confuse the consumers out there.  Now most of the 'experts' have proclaimed the 3600 as the best performance for cost and they are probably correct.  I wasn't looking for an improvement in performance; I was looking to attain a specific level of performance and the 3600 may or may not have gotten me there.  The 3700X got me there.

column1: It may not be the best bang for your buck because the 3600 is such an amazing deal
column2: but if you need a specific level of performance AND you have an AM4 motherboard (I'm still rocking an X370 chipset) and have decent ram.....well
column3: it's money well spent and a great value in my opinion.  The fact that I've been able to upgrade twice now without having to completely rip everything out of the case to install a new MB can't be overlooked.  A decent MB is going to run you at least $120 and that's if you get lucky.  The amount of performance that I've been able to get through a simple BIOS flash and a new CPU from just two years ago is staggering.

column1: Now if I was building from scratch I don't know if I'd go with a Ryzen right now.  The AM4 socket was supposed to be usable for 4 years I believe and we're getting kind of close to the end of that road.  Alternatively Intel is kind of known for changing sockets with every major release and forcing owners to a more expensive upgrade path.  So basically the next gen of everything may involve a MB upgrade anyway so I wouldn't use that as my deciding factor.  I will say that AMD stuck to their promise about the AM4 being compatible though.  It's still not completely mature as they are allegedly still tweaking the BIOS to get the clocks to boost to the advertised speeds more often (irritating
column2: but in real life performance I haven't had an issue).  Other than the tweaks it's been a rock solid platform ever since they sorted out the ram timing issues with gen 1 CPU's.

column1: Oh
column2: it's also only rated as a 65W TDP chip so you heat hasn't been an issue for me.  I was able to run it on a 140mm AIO without ever getting close to max temps.  I did upgrade to a 280mm AIO recently because I found one on sale
column3: but it was more about replacing it before the old one failed than needing it.

column1: Bottom line is that it's a great platform
column3: but figure out what it is that you are trying to do and determine whether you need higher frequency clock speeds or more cores to get to the level of performance in your use case and then pick the appropriate CPU.  There really isn't a 'bad' CPU out there today
column4: it just depends on what you are trying to do.  For the number of cores and performance the 3700X fit my needs very well.  I can't complain about the price at all."^5^Sep 6

column1: acheron^/amd-ryzen-7-3700x-octa-core-3-6-ghz-socket-am4-desktop-processor/6356277?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^1^"I previously used the Ryzen 2700X in a Gigabyte AORUS X470 Gaming 7 WIFI motherboard with my main drive being a 500GB Western Digital Black NVME M.2 drive. column2: but I had purchased two 8GB sticks of DDR4-3600 memory from G. Skill that were very problematic in the system for some time.  At best
column3: I could reliably run it at DDR4-3200

column1: After extensive BIOS updates
column2: I went and swapped my 2700X for the 3700X I purchased from Best Buy.  Aside from certain situations being *visibly* faster than before
column3: my memory now works like a charm at DDR4-3600.  Not only that
column4: but all the strange quirks I couldn't figure out in the past all went away.  I may decide to get a new motherboard in the future if I perhaps want to replace my NVMe drive with a new PCIe 4-based one
column5: but I don't want to do that now.

column1: If anyone is wondering whether they should replace their board or not
column2: I can confidently say that you can wait if you wish.  Those boards are very expensive at the moment
column3: and it works beautifully as a drop-in replacement!  As usual
column4: best buy shipped it to me in a very timely fashion."^5^Aug 5

Chris^/asus-rog-strix-b450-f-gaming-socket-am4-usb-3-1-gen-2-amd-motherboard-with-led-lighting/6311234?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^4^0^"Asus made this board budget friendly and it has everything you would need and then some for this price range. column2: if you are trying to do some more serious overclocking you may want to look elsewhere. The RGB on the board is tasteful with a simple ROG logo and there are 2 - 12v pins you can sync your fans to with Aura sync (If they have the right connectors). Shipping was fast with Best Buy and showed up in good shape
column3: except for the giant shipping sticker that they slapped on the front and center of the box. I like to keep my boxes so that kinda irritated me. Overall a decent Mobo with a few extra features for the price."^4^Jun 1

column1: cesartech^/asus-rog-strix-b450-f-gaming-socket-am4-usb-3-1-gen-2-amd-motherboard-with-led-lighting/6311234?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^0^"Mother board was nicely paired with 3700x and vega 56 gpu. At first things were a bit unstable
column2: but I went in bios after installing windows 10 and installed the latest bios for the board in the bios menu. After that I had to get the Dram voltage adjusted because it kept resetting randomly with no beeping noises so I knew it was the ram. Everything is all good now
column4: fits everything just fine and capable of handling probably up to a 3900x. It has good amount of 3.1 usb connectors
column6: nice I/O shield..

column1: I didnt need all the x570 features

column3: you might need to turn those on as well as the back USB c connection that was labeled as intel (not sure exactly what it's called at this time but hopefully that will take you in the right direction). column1: Elvis^/asus-rog-strix-b450-f-gaming-socket-am4-usb-3-1-gen-2-amd-motherboard-with-led-lighting/6311234?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^0^"I'll start by saying that this mobo looks great aesthetically. column1: ttvJeremy31061^/asus-rog-strix-b450-f-gaming-socket-am4-usb-3-1-gen-2-amd-motherboard-with-led-lighting/6311234?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"Firstly
column2: these are now being shipped with a logo indicating they are Ryzen 3000 ready
column3: so most likely your local store will have a unit that has had the bios updated. Just to clarify from a concern I had when shopping in the B450 Range.

column1: Wow
column2: what a monster for the price;

column1: I had moderate expectations for the price of this board
column2: but I have been absolutely blown away at every turn.

column1: I currently have:
A Ryzen 7 2700X stable at 4.25 running 1.43V
2 16gb Trident Z Royal 3000mhz ocd to 3400mhz
An EVGA RTX 2080Ti XC Ultra at 2100 core and 8000 mem.
and this board seemingly does not care one bit in terms of VRM temps. Its taken me roughly a month of tinkering in the bios to really get all of those numbers toned in exactly right
column2: and potentially a more capable VRM solution may have aided in that
column3: but you cannot expect anymore than this for the price.

column1: -It is a true full ATX mobo with 2 full speed Gen 3 NVME slots
-multiple (dont know exactly) Sata ports
- RIGID PCIE slots
column2: absolutely zero sag on the Ti without any additional mounting support.

column1: -Bios provides every entry and mid level OC option for Ryzen
column2: even if the capabilities of the chips are now more automatic than manual. It is simply a stunning value compared to the premium most (including Asus) charge for a 570 chipset.

column1: All in all
column2: if you absolutely must have onboard WIFI/Bluetooth
column4: otherwise; pick it up and run with it my friend; you wont regret it"^5^Mar 28

column1: I did have ONE issue with this motherboard. Upon installing RAM
column4: I installed it into the case (Corsair 100r)
column5: I booted to BIOS with no issues. I stepped away for 5 minutes and the computer shut down. When I pressed the power button
column6: it practically blinked
column7: all the fans turned on
column8: and then immediately turned off. After 1.5-2 hours of diagnostics
column9: I've come to the conclusion that the Mobo was shot. EVEN though the ROG IO RGB was illuminating and working. I checked every component starting with the CPU
column11: still got the issue. The funny thing is I have 3 LED indicator lights for diagnostics
column12: none of them showed errors.

column1: Spoke with ASUS customer support at 8 p.m. on a Monday night
column2: and got a person on the phone at 8:05 p.m. I told him all that I have done and he said that unfortunately those were the procedures he recommends doing before filing a warranty. He then gave me a case number and told me to take it back to BestBuy and get it exchanged.

column1: So
column2: I ended up boxing both the PSU and the Mobo up and I took them back to my local BestBuy (after they got a new one in stock (5 business days)). I even made sure to pack all the SATA and power cables
column3: and made thepackages all nice and neat and BestBuy employees didn't LOOK INSIDE. Oh well
column5: and as soon as I got home
column6: I bench built the Mobo back again on its box
column7: starting with CPU and RAM
column8: and EVERYTHING WORKS! So far
column9: 2 weeks in

column1: KyRoo^/asus-rog-strix-b450-f-gaming-socket-am4-usb-3-1-gen-2-amd-motherboard-with-led-lighting/6311234?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^0^2^"The product came in. After setting it up I realized there are limited fan ports. I have 4 system fans and they only have 3 ports. 1 splitter and your fine. Well thats till you find out the cpu fan port doesnt work. Youll have to plug it into a backup one. Then configure your bios to ignore it. So you successfully got your computer to boot right. Now to put in the rest of the stuff. Start it up and ram catches fire. Only for you to realize they they have loose pins and a random mettle piece stuck in there? Attempting to file a claim right now. It works if you are doing a caseless build. And plan to cool hour cpu to the minimum requirements. Would not suggest unless you know how to check things without using them. Idk how thats possible but I know some one can put there. Hope this helps yall. Im sure not all of them come in beat up like that just this many problems and I got another one threw bestbuy exchange. And still had problems with it."^2^Dec 5

column1: CP1975^/msi-mpg-z390-gaming-plus-socket-lga1151-usb-3-1-gen-1-intel-motherboard-with-led-lighting/6305798?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^0^"I was nervous about buying a motherboard with the latest chipset as from my experience they can be buggy. My last build was about 3 years ago and I made multiple trips to and from store from where I bought the MB. This was an easy build with respect to the MB and processor. I chose to buy the MB & Processor from Bestbuy instead Craigslist knowing that I could easily return the board within 15 days. The whole process went very smoothly with the only hitch being that I had a very old power supply that didn't have the 8 pin connector. This was an easy fix. I purchased an adapter after which the computer booted up. I paired the MB with a i5 9600k processor. Super fast system. The only issue I had with this build was that the Radeon Vega 56 Graphic Card I chose required more power than what my 500 watt PSU could provide. The system would shut down and restart when doing anything that taxed the the card. I was hoping the problem was my power supply
column2: though was worried that the card may be defective as I bought it off of CL for $180
column3: which is really cheap for this card. I headed to Bestbuy and spoke to an employee that worked in the DIY pc section. He asked all of the right questions and provided a sensible explanation for the issue that I was having and helped me choose a new PSU. He was right and the new PSU solved my problem. What I like about purchasing from Bestbuy is their return policy. They make the whole process easy. This is huge as I've been building computers for over 20 years and have bought many pc components that were either defective or didn't pair well with other hardware. Amazon is cheap and they have a huge selection
column4: though returns are a pain and Bestbuy will price match them as long as the product is sold by Amazon. I've found that Bestbuy is selective in what MBs they carry and it appears that they stay away from MBs that are of poor quality.

column1: I highly recommend this MB!"^5^Feb 9

column1: Taylor^/msi-mpg-z390-gaming-plus-socket-lga1151-usb-3-1-gen-1-intel-motherboard-with-led-lighting/6305798?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"Their are better Z390 motherboards with more features and better VRM setups
column2: but at $140 this particular mobo is great. If you don't need onboard Bluetooth or WiFi and you don't have a OC'd 9900K
column3: this board is just fine. It doesn't have a fancy aesthetic and it's VRM likely cannot keep an OC'd 9900K at an acceptable temp due to its lacking VRM configuration. I'd recommend this chipset for i5 9600K or 9700K with an aggressive cooling setup. I was able to OC my 9700K to 5.1 across all cores and it never exceeds 60C under the heaviest loads with a Corsair H100 240mm AiO. Overall
column4: this motherboard is a great sub $150 option. Look elsewhere if planning to run 9900K over clocked."^4^Mar 10

column1: Meiru^/corsair-ll-series-120mm-case-cooling-fan-kit-with-rgb-lighting/6181283?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^9^1^"The three fans connected perfectly within my computer case. I paired these fans with some Corsair lighting strips for an RBG build. When I booted up the computer
column2: I was pleasantly surprised about how nice the lighting on the fan was compared to the HD120's. Definitely a lot smoother and fluid. Then I installed Corsair Lin-- I mean 'iCUE'

column1: Oh boy. The lighting options were alright. Nothing too fancy
column2: pretty much the same stuff compared to the HD120's. Again
column3: I really like the colors and the style of the fans. Shortly
column5: however. Starting up my PC sometimes causes the fans to not activate into the lighting mode that I set it to. Instead
column6: it glitches and blinks its default rainbow setting. What's odd is that the lightstrips are fine
column7: it's just the fans that are flickering. Additionally
column8: sometimes iCUE can't even detect that anything's connected to my lighting node pro (which comes included with the fans
column9: nice touch).

column1: Overall
column2: very beautiful fans. The RBG looks terrific; Corsair really stepped up their game. Unfortunately
column3: the software that handles the lighting needs some work. Hopefully we got some updates in the future to alleviate some of these problems. For now
column4: the fans are a solid buy
column5: but it's mildly tough to justify the hefty price tag considering the software in its current state."^4^Jun 21

column1: OGstyle^/corsair-ll-series-120mm-case-cooling-fan-kit-with-rgb-lighting/6181283?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^4^0^"The fans themselves are high quality with low noise at high speeds. The RGB lighting effects are highly customizable. My only complaint is that this kit requires you to connect the fans to both the RGB lighting hub and the lighting node pro controller in order to operate properly. Each fan has two wires coming from it. The hub and node are both SATA powered. Cable management can be an issue."^4^Jun 16
AudioVideoGuy^/corsair-ll-series-120mm-case-cooling-fan-kit-with-rgb-lighting/6181283?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^0^"When I purchased may 'All-In_One Water cooler for my CPU
column2: it came with standard non-RGB fans. They worked but I wanted some bling to my build. At first
column3: I thought $120 for three fans was a bit much but then I shopped around and that was the going price for Static Pressure Fans. So I bit the bullet and purchased these fans just so I can get some RGB lighting on my build. Wow! These changed the total appearance of my system. The LED's are bright and vibrant. The amount of control you can get with the software make the fans a light show by themselves. Corsair has always produced quality products and this is no exception. They are quiet
column4: respond to speed changes dictated by the motherboard's temperature curves. Here are few suggestions
column5: however. It would have been nice for cable management purposes if the LEDs and fan control wires could be daisy-chained. I would have liked to see a subtle arrow showing which way the fan moved the air so I can install them for push or pull correctly the first time. The orientation of the fans can also use a little help as some of the lighting patterns require them to be turned in a certain way. This caused some trial and error before I got it turned the right way."^5^Dec 5

Mike^/corsair-ll-series-120mm-case-cooling-fan-kit-with-rgb-lighting/6181283?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^0^2^"Some of the best RGB fans on the market when accompanied by Corsair's CUE software. Kind of requires you to be invested in their product economy however. Each fan still needs to be connected into a fan header/fan hub. The Lighting Node Pro in the box is purely for lighting.

Pictures and videos really don't do it justice. The fans are very bright and colorful. They also provide great *case* airflow. They're average at best when it comes to cooling a radiator. As far as noise
column2: you're going to have to configure your own fan curve. CUE's default settings have these running at unnecessarily high RPM. Mine hover from 600-1000 RPM(which still keep my CPU/GPU nice and cool) and I can't hear them through my earbuds.

column1: The rear/exhaust side is not as illuminated as the front of the fan where the LED ring sits. If you're going to be using these as a front intake
column2: you won't be seeing much of your lighting.

column1: If you already have a few Corsair RGB products
column2: these will accompany them well. If you're not
column3: I recommend looking at other (much cheaper) options."^5^Dec 21

column1: Viper^/msi-mpg-x570-gaming-edge-wifi-socket-am4-usb-c-gen2-amd-motherboard/6357223?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^16^0^"I did a lot of research before I decided on purchasing the MSI MPG X570 Gaming Edge motherboard. I was on a budget but I didn't want to be too cheap and then I came across this fairly priced motherboard. If you want a short answer this is a really good motherboard with some great features and benefits and can not be beat for the price.

One of the things that I really appreciated about this motherboard is the preinstalled IO Shield it made installation a breeze and is a great for first time pc builders. The motherboard features wifi and bluetooth which is great for the price. I wish it was Wifi 6 but regardless its nice to even have wifi.It does have some RGB feature on which is minimal but honestly I didn't mind at all. RAM was interesting situation the initial speed was around 2200 MHz but when I messed around with it and enabled XMP my corsair 3200 MHz was working perfectly fine. One thing I did not enjoy was the location of the fan headers
column2: they are near the bottom and may be awkward for some or difficult to reach. Lets break down some of the pros and cons

column1: PRO
-Pre installed IO Shield
-WIFI Bluetooth
-USB C
-BIOS updating
-Quiet motherboard
-PCIe 4.0 almost all slots with Ryzen 3rd Gen 3600 and above
CON
-IO Shield is lackluster
-Fan headers placement
-Slight RAM issues (just takes a little of messing around to fix it)
- No WIFI 6
-Chipset Fan (sigh)

Conclusion- The MSI X570 Gaming Edge is a great Mid Range motherboard with some great features and a competitive price. Most of the issues that I have encountered have resolutions that just take some time. The motherboard just like most MSI products is a great combination of quality and value. I recommend this motherboard especially with the 3rd Gen Ryzen in particular anything above the 3600."^4^Jul 13
KevinK^/msi-mpg-x570-gaming-edge-wifi-socket-am4-usb-c-gen2-amd-motherboard/6357223?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^7^0^"I built my first pc
column2: waiting for the new AMD Ryzen Zen 2 processors. I picked up the Ryzen 5 3600 for my first build along with the MSI X570 Gaming Edge. The motherboard has great features for this low of a price-point especially among the other X570 boards. If you want to save some few-extra bucks for a better gpu/cpu or other parts
column3: I highly recommend the MSI X570 Gaming Edge!

column1: Many benefits for the MSI X570 Gaming Edge include the preinstalled IO Shield making installation a breeze and saving a little time and is a great for first time pc builders. The motherboard has Wifi and Bluetooth which is great for the price. It has minimal RGB features which is fine since I have other RGB. You have to go to BIOS to set your RAM to the frequency which you bought it at since the motherboard sets it lower. One thing that may be difficult for other users are the location of the fan headers which are on the bottom of the motherboard and may be hard for others to reach. Other pros/cons listed below.
PRO
- Pre installed IO Shield (Don't have to struggle like previous generations of boards)
- Wifi & Bluetooth (Saves you time
column2: money and worriment rather than getting a third party USB for either Wifi or Bluetooth that you may not know a lot about)

column1: - Has BIOS flashback for future updates
- RGB is minimal
column2: but is what you get for at this pricepoint

column1: - Overclocking is easy
column2: especially for a first time pc- builder like me.

column1: - 2 M.2 slots.
- Many SATA ports
CON
- Heat sink is a tight fit for my case (NZXT H500) since its right next to the fans.
- Fan headers placement could be a little better since they are all on bottom
column2: but for me it wasn't too bad since my fans (Corsair LL120) had long cables.

column1: - Need to go into BIOS to set RAM to desired speed which you bought since the BIOS sets it to a lower frequency.

I recommend pairing this board with a AMD Ryzen Zen 2 (third gen) processor due to the ease of installing the board with easy overclocking for first-time builders since this is probably the best motherboard you can get around this price point for the features and ease of use."^5^Jul 30
kenny^/msi-mpg-x570-gaming-edge-wifi-socket-am4-usb-c-gen2-amd-motherboard/6357223?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^4^0^"I paired the MSI x570 Gaming Edge Wifi Motherboard with a AMD Ryzen 3700X
column5: and 2 sticks of corsair vengence pro rgb. My final build is nothing short of amazing in performance and looks! However
column6: I found the setup to be quite tedious. While I would recommend this board to anyone
column7: it was not a five star experience..

column1: Overall
column2: the build was very easy. It should be noted
column3: that although I have done months of in depth study
column4: this was in fact my first build. I was able to quickly find headers for nearly everything
column5: and the manual helped me find anything that wasn't immediately apparent. The fan header placement could be better. All four are along the bottom of the case which means that if you don't want fan cables running across the face of your build
column6: you will have to get extensions.. Some people have even complained that it has been too far for some fans to run.. It did however look ascetically pleasing once I managed my cables though.. The motherboard fit in my mid tower
column7: ATX case and was very sturdy even with a massive RTX 2080 hanging off of it. I think its important to note that I bought mine within just a few weeks after launch and yet my board had no major defects other than what appeared to be a few paint or glue splotches..(Most of them are out of sight but you can kinda see one in the 3rd photo)

column1: Initially after boot
column2: everything seemed to be working well. The bios was easy to navigate and most settings were straightforward. However
column3: I had many struggles with trying to install windows on my raid drive. The windows installer just couldn't see the raid array
column4: even after using the drivers on the disk. Just after midnight on the second day of trying to get RAID to work
column5: I figured out that if I unplugged all other drives before booting
column6: then recreated the raid array
column7: booted to windows installer
column8: installed drivers from the MSI website; it then suddenly just worked..

column1: After that whole ordeal
column2: everything has gone rather smoothly. My only other gripe with this board is the Dragon Center. I originally installed the version that came on the disc and it was horrible.. Old and clunky and only worked half the time. My RAM RGB often does whatever it feels like or uses a setting I set days before.. Finally getting tired of it all
column3: I tried to install iCUE to see if it would work with my board. During the process I uninstalled the dragon center. When I re-downloaded the Dragon Center from the website this time(because iCUE didn't do what I wanted..) it was completely different.. And Faster.. And just all around works better.. So don't trust the included on disc software! Get it from the website!

column1: So that is everything that I have disliked about the MSI experience; they could do much better with software.. The board itself is amazing. As a video editor and gamer
column2: I frequently copy files to external drives. I love the amount of fast IO on this motherboard especially when compared to any other x570 motherboard at this price point. It is so fast that when transfering a 1GB file to my WD Passport SSD
column3: the transfer window just flashes and its done.. Like no waiting at all!

column1: The WIFI is a great feature. I have yet to test its effective speed because my internet is pretty slow
column2: but I haven't had any drops and it has been consistent. I didn't even add the antennas for a few days after building and it worked fine!

column1: I have yet to hear the chipset fan over the rest of my fans which are all very quite as well.
This motherboard also has great RGB control with 2 ARGB and 2 12vRGB headers. The Mystic lighting software has a little way to go but other than that its great!
I came to this motherboard grudgingly after accepting that a comparable ASUS motherboard would be too expensive.. However
column2: I would now give a 99% recommendation to a friend who was looking for an X570 board just because past setup
column3: there is no other current X570 motherboard at this price point with the IO and performance of this one. The performance per dollar of this board is just as good as can be. So good job MSI."^4^Jul 28

column1: Mikey^/msi-mpg-x570-gaming-edge-wifi-socket-am4-usb-c-gen2-amd-motherboard/6357223?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^4^0^"Perfect combination of features. Wifi
column2: RGB Support yet at a minimalist approach. Full support of 2XXX and 3XXX Ryzen chips.

column1: CPU: Ryzen 3700x
RAM: Corsair 2x16 3200. Model: CMW32GX4M2C3200C16
GPU: MSI RX580 8GB Model: R580AR28C
Out of the box
column3: immediately went to BIOS and turned on A-XMP to get the RAM at 3200
column4: Rebooted and the RAM was at 3200!

column1: RGB thoughts: I am not big on RGB
column2: so I like how the board has a simple 'Ground effect' RGB that comes from under the board (See the white light in Picture 2).

column1: Everything worked together perfectly
column2: and the only hitch I had
column3: was I accidentally set my Windows account to standard and not administrator. This caused most of the MSI programs to not work

column1: PRO's: Easy to set-up at best XMP settings. Overclock utilities work well. This board does have a second CPU power plug for extreme overclocking if that is one's desire. Heat spreader for the M2 SSD.
CON: If you aren't logged into an administrator account in windows
column2: sound will have static and other issues.

column1: Note: I used a PCI-e riser cable to mount the GPU away from the MB and keep it's heat separate!"^5^Jul 24
photofrankFM^/msi-mpg-x570-gaming-edge-wifi-socket-am4-usb-c-gen2-amd-motherboard/6357223?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^0^"This  review is for the MSI MPG X570 Gaming Edge WiFi AMD AM4 motherboard.

My review of this board is with the following attached components installed in a Mid Tower 17 X 17.5 X 7.5 inch case with the PS on the bottom. I mention this because with the large VRM heat sinks I had to move the AIO radiator installed in the top of the case
column2: all the way to the edge to get it as far away from the board as possible just so the fans will clear the VRM heat sink and the top of the RAM heat spreaders. The top of the heat spreaders on my RAM sit 1 and 3/8 inches above the top of the RAM slot. So if your case is similar to my sized case and you use liquid cooling
column3: it will be nip and tuck if you want to keep the fans inside the case.

column1: See  pictures of the install. You will see that the upper VRM heatsink is under the AIO fans and the fan just clears the RAM .
Power Supply-750 Watt
CPU----------AMD Ryzen 3700x
Cooling------240 mm AIO liquid
GPU----------RTX 2080 Super
Windows 10 --1 TB PCIe 4.0 NVMe M.2 SSD
Storage------512 GB PCIe 3.0 NVMe M.2
column4: one 4 TB HDD and 3 USB 3.0 HDDs

column1: I had no luck with any kind of beneficial overclocking of the Ryzen 3700X or the RAM
column2: which seems to be the normal experience with most who try. I choose not to loosen RAM timings to be able to overclock the RAM
column3: I'm sure the RAM could have been pushed
column4: but it did not make sense for me. By setting the strongest of the three prefigured overclock profiles in the BIOS I was able to increase consistent all core Boost performance to a constant 4.2 Ghz vs the + or - 4.0 it ran at default BIOS settings. I did get it to run at 4.3 under sustained boost for awhile
column5: but it crashed immediately when I tried to go higher. I think that AMD has cranked about all you can get out of it so far as amateur overclockers like myself are concerned. I didn't really put a lot of effort into it as a couple of tenths was not going to make any difference that justified the occasional crash. I have tested it under stress for long periods using Furmarks CPU stress test
column6: which taxes the system more than Prime 95 does. It does reach the advertised 4.4 ghz boost under varying load
column7: but at full 100 percent on all cores it will settle in at about 4.24 ghz.

column1: Lets go to the chipset and M.2 cooling fan. No worries. I have mine set to run at 1300 RPM all the time. That way the chipset will not get hot and it is quiet at that speed. Under the most stringent use transferring files
column2: HWMonitor shows the System temp at 36degrees C
column5: PCIe at 33 degrees and the 4.0 M.2 at 32 degrees. I have three fans pushing air into the case and three exhausting air. So I think with the good airflow I have
column6: it is staying at a safe temperature.

column1: The board was easy to setup. After enabling A XMP in the BIOS it set my DDR4 3200 RAM at the proper speed and timings. I loved the fan control in the BIOS. You can set fan speed curves
column3: do anything you want to either fan individually or all the fans together. You can choose the component board sensor for each fan that it is tied to. I found it much better than the iCue fan software that came with my AIO liquid cooler. It has a CPU
column4: Pump and four system fan PWM connectors. What it does lack is enough USB 2.0 on board headers. I need two for my case and one for the AIO liquid heat sink
column5: so I had to get a USB 2.0 splitter
column6: which I have shown in one of the pictures. The board has both a USB 3.0 and 3.2 connector for external case connections.

column1: I am using 2 16 GB sticks of RAM. so I can't comment on if it plays well with all the slots filled.  It has the RGB headers for those of you who have lit cases and components. I didn't mess with them as my PC sits in a ventilated enclosure in my desk so no body sees it. The board is a good looking board. The built in I/O cover fit properly.
So far for my use
column2: which is media editing heavy I am really happy. It may not be the best overclocking board
column3: or maybe my 65 watt 3700X just doesn't have a lot of overhead to overclock. I bought it mainly because I need the fast file transfer speed that PCIe 4.0 provides. Need to note that only the one M.2 slot is 4.0 the other is 3.0. I bought a 1 TB 4.0 M.2 for the system and partitioned 250 GB for the system and use the rest as a working drive to load from and save to with Photoshop. I am getting 5500 MB/sec read speeds vs 3300 MB/sec read speeds with my Samsung PCIe 3.0 970 M.2. The system is unbelievably faster than I expected. PCIe 4.0 is going to be a major player in the next jump in PC performance. I suggest that you take advantage of this fast PCIe Bus and put a PCIe 4.0 SSD on it. Also when GPus start oversaturating the 3.0 PCIe bus capability
column4: you will be able to benefit from those fast GPUs.

column1: There have been some complaints about the WiFi
column2: but I updated the BIOS before I installed Windows and it has worked just fine. Even from my garage where my workbench is. Also it isn't the quickest to post
column3: but that could be because of it having to enumerate all the drives that I have attached.

column1: So I think this is a good 200 dollar board for those who need WiFi and Bluetooth and buy the CPU and DDR4 speed RAM that they need and just let the board make it all work together with no fuss or worry about overclocking."^5^Jan 25

YouTookMyShoes^/msi-mpg-x570-gaming-edge-wifi-socket-am4-usb-c-gen2-amd-motherboard/6357223?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"As a first time builder this motherboard was great. column1: BRayza^/msi-mpg-x570-gaming-edge-wifi-socket-am4-usb-c-gen2-amd-motherboard/6357223?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"At just over $200 at the time of buying this board feels like a steal compared to my previous B450 board. Overall this feels like a Premium $300 board for much less of a price and it doesn't cut any corners 10/10"^5^Dec 10

MeMadMax^/msi-mpg-x570-gaming-edge-wifi-socket-am4-usb-c-gen2-amd-motherboard/6357223?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^25^"Got this board with the ryzen 7 3700x
column5: and after about 3 power cycles it finally gets to the bios screen.

column1: First thing i did in the bios was turn off the RGB... great
column2: now i go to restart for changes to take effect.

column1: And thats when this board fell flat on its face.
The board tries to restart. But sits there with only the cpu diagnostic LED on.
ok... whats goin on here?
Discovered the board wont reset the bios with the bios jumper
column2: or pulling the battery and leaving it sit all night. All traditional methods to reset the bios fail.

column1: Ok... try a bios update with a usb jump drive.
Again
column3: got the board to appear to update its bios with a usb jump drive.

column1: No effect
Notice that i had the 8 pin cpu power connected but not also with the 4 pin(for a 8+4 power setup

So went and fabricated a temporary 4 pin molex to 4 pin power cable because one didnt come with the motherboard when it should because up till recently these cables havent been used much since the pentium 4 days.
Anyways
column2: plugged in the 4 pin and now instead of cpu
column3: now my gpu is not making it on boot...

column1: ok... switched the gpu to the second pcie slot(x8) and boom
column2: we are posting to bios and i go about installing windows... so you have to have that 4 pin power connected because msi runs that power to the pci chipset and cpu somewhere and the board is completely unstable without it.

column1: next thing i find
column2: the documentation says nothing about sata raid other than the name and in the bios its nothing more than a on/off switch.... and when it is on
column3: it detects only 2 of 6 sata drives and windows setup agrees that the other 4 drives are missing...

column1: It was at this point that i threw in the towel after 2 days of trial and error with this motherboard and promptly exchanged for the Asus TUF motherboard which ran immediately with no hiccups other than a driver load issue with windows setup to recognize the Raid... and for ten dollars less mind you.
Avoid this board like the plague. It really does appear to be a beta test board that was thrown into production and has a power design that had a few bad design decisions
column4: its like broken chinese english translation..."^1^Oct 20

column1: surfahdude^/msi-mpg-x570-gaming-edge-wifi-socket-am4-usb-c-gen2-amd-motherboard/6357223?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^42^"If you are planning to buy this mobo for a 65-watt CPU

Avoid this if you are planning to buy this motherboard for any 105-watt AMD CPU (3800x/3900x/3950x).  The power supply design cannot supply the current required for these CPUs.  The voltage regulators will overheat
column2: hitting 100-120 degrees C.  When this happens
column3: the board will throttle the CPU speed down until the VRs cool down.  When the VR temps rise again

column1: MSi really screwed up the board design on ALL of the MPG lineup of X570 motherboards.  All of them have terrible VR designs causing the  to overheat.  I have one and it really sucks.  Better boards will only hit temps of 60-70 degrees.
Contacting MSi will get you nowhere.  They insist the board is fine but professional online reviews tell you otherwise.  I ended up replacing my MSi board at my own expense."^2^Nov 12

column1: PowerofT^/corsair-vengeance-rgb-pro-16gb-2pk-8gb-3ghz-pc4-24000-ddr4-dimm-unbuffered-non-ecc-desktop-memory-kit-with-rgb-lighting-black/6256222?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"*results are subjective and limited to a single hardware config.*
System specs: Ryzen 1700 @ 4GHz
Asrock X370 Taichi
EVGA SuperNova 750 G3
With Ryzen depending on the speed of DRAM to increase performance
column2: I wanted to get the fastest RAM as possible (and compatible). Several kits from G.Skill
column5: and Geil have all failed to pass the bare DDR4 spec of 2133MHz. Even my previous kit of PNY Anarchy X 3200MHz could just manage 2400MHz at very loose timings ( 20-22-22-40). I have had enough time to tinker with this new kit
column6: and I am very impressed. So impressed that I plan on buying another 16GB kit to round out the RGB lighting. The rated speed is decent at 3000MHz which worked out of the box with no issue. However
column7: these sticks were pushed to 3466MHz at tight timings of 17-18-18-35 and still survive a full 24 hours of AIDA64 at full burn. Just from 2933 to 3466
column8: my cpu gained 14% improvement across the board.

column1: TLDR: As of time of writing
column2: the price of DRAM is only decreasing and finding a similar price/performance kit still costs $50+ over this kit. Temps are fantastic
column3: and they're a beast in performance. Oh yeah
column4: the RGB is the only downside; the LEDs shine through the opaque cover."^5^Jan 16

column1: edgar69^/corsair-vengeance-rgb-pro-16gb-2pk-8gb-3ghz-pc4-24000-ddr4-dimm-unbuffered-non-ecc-desktop-memory-kit-with-rgb-lighting-black/6256222?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"This is my 2nd purchase of this ram
column2: running 32gb total in the system. Very fast
column4: no problems to report. The only trouble I had was with the corsair ique software that is supposed to control the lighting. It was consistantly using 10-12% of my processor(corei78700k). Obviously ther is nothing in this small utility that could use that much processor so it must be causing a conflict somewhere. I set the lighting the way i wanted it and uninstalled the utility. Lights work and cpu usage dropped from 12% at idle to 2%. Not a big deal
column5: not worth spending a lot of time on to find out what causes the high cpu usage. Still a good product"^5^Oct 12

column1: Roar^/corsair-vengeance-rgb-pro-16gb-2pk-8gb-3ghz-pc4-24000-ddr4-dimm-unbuffered-non-ecc-desktop-memory-kit-with-rgb-lighting-black/6256222?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^0^1^"Hands down worth the money for the Corsair aesthetics and overclocking.

I came from a 2133mhz hyperx single stick and going to dual channel 3000mhz has had a far more significant impact then I thought it would. Paired with a Ryzen 5 I gained upwards of 20 fps in my games from the old single channel 16gb. I don't know alot about timings but as far as I can research corsair vengeance has pretty solid settings.

Overclocked to 3300mhz and havn't tried more or less. I don't think I can benefit anymore from it. Even the 3ghz seemed like I wouldn't be able to utilize it but cpu intensive games love these sticks.
Also had an issue with HyperX where I kept having to reseat the ram every so often which seemed solved with these corsair sticks."^5^Sep 16

column1: photofrankFM^/corsair-hydro-series-h100i-rgb-platinum-120mm-processor-liquid-cooling-system-with-rgb-lighting-black-silver/6306564?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"This is for the Corsair H100i AIO liquid cooler. I comes with all the hardware to use on either Intel or AMD boards. Great for all who are looking for the lighting and who have normal cooling needs.
Only three pump speeds in the iCue control panel
column3: Balanced and Extreme. I saw no difference between Balanced-2300 RPM and Extreme-2800 RPM. I think the heatsink and radiator dictate the cooling capacity and running the pump faster doesn't make any difference. You will need an open USB 2.0 headed on your board if you want to use the Corsair iCue fan and Pump control software. I didn't so
column4: I had to use a USB splitter. I will include a picture.

column1: I tried it with the already applied thermal paste and with a premium thermal paste. I saw no difference in CPU temperature
and many review sites have had the same experience
column2: so I would just use the applied thermal paste.

column1: The reason I gave it a 4 star rating is because the holes where the fans attach and you screw it to the top of the case aren't threaded. It is a real effort to screw in the included threaded screws and the heads of the screws will strip out if you don't have a good screwdriver head. Seems if you provided threaded screws
column2: the holes that they go into should be threaded also.

column1: I dropped my CPU temps by 10 degrees below the temps that I was getting with the AMD Wraith Prism cooler that came with my Ryzen 3700X which I run at stock settings and my chipset
column2: MOS and M.2 temps run cooler seeing as all the heat is being exhausted from the case rather than into the case as it is with the Wraith Cooler.

column1: So I think that this is a sufficient cooler for 65 watt CPUs or maybe even 105 watt CPUs that aren't overclocked
column2: but if you are running CPUs that can be radically overclocked
column3: you may want to look to an AIO with better cooling properties."^4^Jan 25

MBBB^/corsair-hydro-series-h100i-rgb-platinum-120mm-processor-liquid-cooling-system-with-rgb-lighting-black-silver/6306564?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^1^"Decided to replace my 6 year old H100i with this unit.
Exceptionally quiet and effective in keeping a 9900KS chilled. I'm pretty pleased with it.
Assembly was a pain
The pre-tapped mounting holes (fan side and case mount side) were unacceptable. They were either tapped incorrectly at factory or screws provided were not the right diameter.

I basically had to retap holes by forcing provided screws through holes. It was during this process that my screwdriver slipped and almost went through my other hand. Luckily it missed my hand and went straight through the aluminum fins instead. I did not have such a problem when I installed the previous
Luckily
column2: it was only a small section of fin surface area that was damaged and not one of the flow channels. I contemplated returning unit due to this damage but the unit works fine.

column1: Be sure to thread screws in and out of mounting holes before unit is in your case. Screw insertion will create small aluminum shavings. You don't want those around your components."^3^Nov 29

column1: Cjnella^/cooler-master-hyper-212-rgb-black-edition-120mm-cpu-cooling-fan-with-rgb-lighting-black/6316592?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^7^0^"I ordered this same cooler from Newegg
column2: However I found the same cooler at a location close to me for even cheaper
column3: so I decided to buy it at Bestbuy. The installation process was easy
column4: however the included guide was basically useless it's all pictures no description on how or what you're doing
column6: instead I just found a tutorial on YouTube that helped a lot more and was able to install it way easier that way. I installed it on an i5 8600k (LGA 1151) it came with thermal compound as most coolers do
column7: I already had some good thermal compound but I'm sure the included thermal paste would have worked just fine. It performs a lot better than my stock cooler
column8: My stock cooler was far too loud and I think the bearings were going out as it made a mild but audible whining and ticking sound when it reached it's max speeds
column9: with the stock cooler at idle my temps were 55-65 under load they'd reach as high as 85 with this cooler master cooler the temps were cut in half at idle
column10: now my temps at idle are 25-30 under load temps are at 55-65
column11: all in all I'm really happy with this air cooler the included rgb controller is simple to use although it's kinda basic
column12: but it's nice to have as my motherboard unfortunately does not have an RGB header. The cable that connects the fan to the rgb controller was long enough that I had no issue running it up and behind my back panel and out of sight. The cooler fan itself is super quite. It's a relief compared to my old stock cooler. All in all this is a great cooler

We opted for the 6 series since our living room has skylights and very large windows. The 96 point contrast sensitivity is worth the higher price since colors remain vibrant no matter what the ambient light condition. The Roku interface is
column3: easy as pie to navigate. If you are also cable connected (Xfinity
column5: you are able to power on to cable channel without switching remotes (hallelujah). The option is nested a bit but easily done in network settings.

column1: Very minor quibbles:
only one USB port. Not a game changer and its possible
column3: to use a hub if needed.

column1: Roku doesnt have available browser (at least not for free). If you are desperate to surf the web
column2: you can do it on your phone and mirror the screen to the TV easily. Typing on-screen is lame anyway

column1: If you are more than 8 feet from the TV and dont have 20/20 vision
column2: 55 (or more) is the way to go. Easily readable.

column1: Settings for personal preferences are easily accessible and if you have OCD
column2: you can tweak even more settings.

column1: Picture quality and color are well described in other reviews. Sound is more than adequate for basic use.

Id also recommend Roku phone app since the BestBuy models dont sell with microphone enabled (advanced) version of remote. Just use the phone app and you can voice command. I plan to enable Alexa control at some point as well.
This is a solid product at a very decent price. You will not regret the purchase."^5^Mar 8

column1: PowerofT^/pny-anarchy-x-16gb-2pk-8gb-3-2ghz-ddr4-desktop-memory-red/5878702?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^9^1^"I had tried nearly a dozen kits of DDR4 ram after building my Ryzen machine

column1: I am a 3D artist. I primarily use Blender. This card works perfectly for Cycles
column2: Eevee and LuxRender rendering engines. I primarily use it for Eevee and Cycles and I have been doing some benchmarks. One RTX 2060 Super is quicker in some renders than two GTX 1060s. On average one RTX 2060 Super is about 90% as fast as two GTX 1060s. So yeah
column3: almost twice as fast at cycles cuda rendering. However
column5: there is an OptiX cycles rendering option that allows you to take advantage of the RTX cores. With this option turned on
column6: ONE RTX 2060 Super is nearly twice as fast as TWO GTX 1060s.

column1: If you are familiar with cycles rendering
column2: you will understand the significance of that.

column1: Let me put it to you this way with the following Benchmark results using the Blender BMW benchmark.
Two GTX 1060s overclocked takes 1:09 to complete.
ONE RTX 2060 Super takes 0:33 to complete.
Of course your results will vary based on other system specs."^5^Dec 28

optimummind^/corsair-hydro-series-120mm-liquid-cooling-system-black/5845215?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^16^0^"Buying the Corsair Hydro H60 AIO watercooler kit for my HP Omen gaming desktop was a fantastic choice~! The stock Intel fan just wasn't powerful enough to keep the CPU temperature low during long gaming sessions playing Resident Evil 2 Remake
With the OEM CPU heatsink and fan
column2: my Core i7 8700 reached temperatures as high as 97 C~! And at that temperature level
column3: the stock fan was spinning so fast
column4: it was very loud and distracting that I had to wear headphones.

column1: After installing the Hydro H60 and playing the same games at the same room temperature
column2: my CPU temperature dropped down to 74 C max (when playing Far Cry 5 New Dawn). On certain games
column4: the CPU never became hotter than 66 C. Depending on the game
column5: my max CPU temperature varied. When playing Shadow of the Tomb Raider
column6: for instance
column7: my max CPU temperature was 70 C.

column1: My idle temperatures experienced great benefits as well. It went from 48 C on the stock HSF down to 29 C on the Hydro H60.
Besides HUGE temperature improvements
column2: I also experienced great acoustic improvements. Although the Hydro H60 radiator fan isn't super quiet at max speed
column3: it was still much quieter than the stock HSF. I made the Hydro H60 even quieter by replacing the stock 120mm Corsair fan with the 120mm Noctua NF-P12 fan. As a result
column4: my system became even quieter and the cooling performance improved by about 2 C. Not a huge difference but still appreciated.

column1: All in all
column2: this is a great product with excellent cooling performance and easy installation.

column1: *Pros:
-Way better than stock Intel heatsink and fan (HSF). 97 C --> 74 C (when playing Far Cry 5 New Dawn).
-Way better idle temperatures - 48 C to 29 C.
-Easy to install.
-Stock 120mm radiator fan is almost as good as a more expensive Noctua NF-P12 fan.
-Very quiet operation (when not at full load).
-Good size for small & compact PC cases where a HUGE aircooler just won't fit.
-Good value.
-Easy to replace stock 120mm fan with a different one.
-Great warranty period (5- years).
*Neutral:
-The stock Corsair fan is a bit loud at full speed.

Cody^/corsair-hydro-series-120mm-liquid-cooling-system-black/5845215?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^10^0^"The Corsair H60
column3: is a good product so long as you realize what it is.

column1: A 120mm cooler will not tend to run your CPU any cooler than a mid-range aftermarket aircooler. It is only a couple degrees cooler than the included cooler
column4: for being a good included cooling solution).

column1: What a 120mm cooler will do is allow you to get the same cooling performance of a large aftermarket cooling tower in a much smaller package. While many cases
column2: including small form factor mATX and mITX cases
column4: most people do not desire (or need) a $120+ cooling solution in those form factors. The H60 provides a middle ground between more expensive solutions
column5: and cheaper but MUCH larger solutions
column6: and it fulfills this role admirably.

column1: The pump is small
column2: and the hoses do not interfere with RAM. The included brackets cover the gamut of modern (and two-ish generations back) mainstream processor sockets
column3: so you are highly likely to be able to use it out of the box no matter if you are team blue or team red. The included AM3/+ bracket even works on AM4 sockets
column4: thanks to AMD's choice to use the same hook-mount specifications as AM3. How much of a pain that particular mounting system is

column1: The pre-applied thermal paste is quality
column3: even if you purchase more expensive pastes to replace it with
column4: you MIGHT shave a single degree off your temperatures.

column1: The hoses on this particular model are a matte rubber. Nothing fancy
The radiator itself is a thin radiator
column2: which provides a large amount of clearance even when coupled with a standard fan
column3: without needing to purchase a more expensive (and yet lower-performing) thin-line fan. The thinner radiator does not significantly impact its performance
column4: as the actual overall size is much
column5: much more important than thickness (120 vs 240 vs 280 etc)

column1: Overall
column2: I would recommend this cooler to someone who really only needs a $40ish aftermarket air solution
column3: but either wants a clean look
column4: or has no way to fit that absolutely HUGE heatsink."^4^Aug 3

column1: HossBud^/corsair-hydro-series-120mm-liquid-cooling-system-black/5845215?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^5^0^"I installed one of these in my Alienware Aurora R6 to replace the stock air cooling on the i7-7700 (non-K) after being told by Dell that I could not order their water cooling kit. My CPU temp does not go above 56C under any conditions I've seen
column2: even with ambient in the room has gotten up to 25-26C. The biggest advantage has been the lack of noise from the (junk) Intel stock cooler. I did have to bend the mounting bracket arms up a little to apply more pressure to the CPU heat spreader even though the specs claimed compatibility

rgrios^/corsair-hydro-series-120mm-liquid-cooling-system-black/5845215?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"I was using a CoolerMaster EVO 212 for an AMD FX-8350 and it keeps it running cool while gaming and I built a new system for video rendering and gaming and thought the EVO 212 would do just as good. Instead overclocked my new Ryzen 1600 to 3.85 with the EVO and got temps around 82 C (hot and the cpu's were throttling). So I put the Corsair H60 to try it out and now at full load rendering or gaming for hours I'm staying at 53 C (almost a 30 C difference). I could probably go for 4 Ghz on the Ryzen but not sure if my memory could handle it. I'm getting rid of the EVO for the FX-8350 and purchasing the Corsair H60 for it. It's small and gets the job done. No need for the 240 or 360 coolers as I'm not overclocking the cpus that far out.
Here's my load out
AMD Ryzen 1600 (3.2 ghz stock
16 GB ADATA 3000 (boosted to 3033)

EVGA 600 PSU
2 - XFX 470 GPU's
2 - 3TB Toshiba P300 HDD (Mirror)

column1: MikeE^/corsair-hydro-series-120mm-liquid-cooling-system-black/5845215?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"I installed this in a new computer that I built.
The computer has an AMD Ryzen 7 1700X processor mounted to an ASRock X370 Taichi motherboard.
I pre-planned the installation
column2: but that changed once I put the motherboard into the case (Fractal Design Arc Midi 2). The case is fairly deep
column3: and my plan to mount the radiator and fan to the front of the case had to be scuttled because the coolant tubes wouldn't reach the CPU.

column1: I ended up mounting the radiator and fan to the top of the case
The installation was very simple
column2: and attaching it to the AM4 bracket required no modifications or extra parts. Everything needed is in the box. There is a video on Corsair's that helps explain the installation process.

column1: The instruction booklet is very well written with good illustrations. Make sure that you read it.
I think the total installation time was about 15 minutes
column2: and probably 10 minutes was deciding how to mount the radiator and fan and then forgetting that the fan needed to be ABOVE the radiator and not below it. My error.

column1: Operationally
column2: this runs very quietly. My CPU temps seem to hover in the 30-35C range.

column1: The coolant tubes are very stiff. They aren't that much different from automotive coolant tubes.
The H60 appears to be well made and nicely finished.
I'm very pleased with this unit. I have no problem recommending it."^5^Sep 8

Eagle0971^/corsair-hydro-series-120mm-liquid-cooling-system-black/5845215?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"I have an alienware R9 with the stock air cooler on my intel 9700 cpu.  My temps with the stock air cooler would reach 80C to 90C playing games. My fans would be running fast and loud as many would understand if you are a gamer of long sessions with the alienware R 7
column3: 9 series with stock air cpu coolers. Replacing the top fan with the radiator/fan combo fits perfectly but the hoses must face the front because you will need to bolt it from the top of the case and the bolt pattern of the radiator and the case makes it only go in one way to secure it. The CPU cooler I had to figure out the best way to route the hoses to make the tight PSU to close. I will add pictures to show the best way I found to route the hoses and not to be in the way of your memory. I added zip ties to help keep the hoses from rubbing that heat sink left of the cpu. I did run some CPU stress test and my temps are now around 65C instead of 80C+."^5^Mar 26

column1: DannyJax^/corsair-vengeance-lpx-32gb-2pk-16gb-2-4ghz-pc4-19200-ddr4-dimm-unbuffered-non-ecc-desktop-memory-kit-black/6319885?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"We built a new PC for game development in Unity 3D. The system was locking up in BIOS
column2: so we removed 3 of the memory. The BIOS did not lock up. We then tested each of the chips in the correct #2 slot (the motherboard manual said to use for 1 memory chip). Sometimes it would lock up on boot and give us a black screen and sometimes it would make it into BIOS and then lock up. In BIOS
column3: as long as we were suing the mouse or keyboard
column4: it would not lock up. Only if we did nothing for 20 to 30 seconds it would lock up. We flashed the BIOS
column5: reinstalled all 4 chips (64Gig total) and the operating system install went off flawlessly. The BIOS issue could have been from the CPU
column6: Memory or Video Card. We let the computer run for three days
column7: getting updates and installing other software. Never once has it locked up.

column1: CORSAIR - Vengeance LPX 32GB (2PK 16GB) 2.4GHz PC4-19200 DDR4 DIMM is the product I am writing the review for. The computer hardware fully came from Best Buy during the 2019 Black Friday and Pre-Black Frida events. AMD Ryzen 3800X Processor
column6: Corsair 220T RGB ATX  Mid-Tower.

column1: We believe the BIOS flash was needed mainly due to the CPU being a 3rd Gen Ryzen 7 CPU and the motherboard being a 1st & 2nd Gen Motherboard. We are doing game development
column2: not competition gaming. It was more important to have 64Gig Ram for handling the 12 kilometers and 16 kilometers 3D maps. If we went with the faster memory
column3: it would have put us over our budget. The difference between the 2400 and 3200 memory is only about 5 to 25 FPS in certain situations. 235 FPS vs 255 FPS is of no concern for us in game development. Some test showed 260 FPS to 265 FPS. The money was better put to the faster CPU and overclocked 4K video card for our purposes. Also
column4: most of the FPS is due to the type video card in the system
column5: but memory does have an impact."^5^Dec 6

column1: ttvJeremy31061^/evga-geforce-rtx-2080-ti-xc-ultra-gaming-11gb-gddr6-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card/6290657?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"At this price point
column2: you are just looking for the best of the best.

column1: The only remaining question is
column2: which over priced Ti do i buy?

column1: With the way timelines keep slipping further away
column2: I decided to go ahead and jump for the 2080 Ti XC Ultra as a point to upgrade to the forever back-ordered FTW3 Ultra model. So this is coming from the perspective that I get to use this GPU in the meantime.

column1: Pros:
Overclocks like MAD - This is installed inside of a Corsair 220T/RGB and it fits perfectly. The case handles both the GPU and a full ATX board
column2: with the GPU correctly measured on Best buy Specs page.

column1: Using Precision X1 I have a rock solid core clock on boost of 2070mhz (stable)
column2: idling at around 39-40*C. The extremely thick heatsink/cooler combo put in tremendous work to achieve this w/ a 1000mhz clock to the ram.

column1: posts a 194% on Userbench
just over 15
paired with a Ryzen 2700X on air
column2: ambient case temp under load is around 65C
column3: with the core at approx 58-60C. This model is not ICX2
column4: so you only get the node on the core itself.

column1: Temps translate into a effective use rate of 1980-2010mhz when gaming at 97-100% GPU usage.
Cons:
1. Cost- It is a no brainer
column2: I stepped up from a 2070 super
column3: and wanted to cry when the total came out to over $1300 after tax. To put in perspective
column4: my entire rig prior to that (monitor included) was only about that much.

column1: It is an absurd premium on this card
column2: and honestly; if there were anything close to the performance level offered

column1: 2. It spoils you- I was never a frame rate snob
column2: happily gamed on console for two decades before finally being convinced
column3: but ultimately was left wanting with a 2070S at 1440p.

column1: This card crushed 144fps in its sleep at 1440
column2: and does a true 4k 60fps on nearly every game I have tried.

column1: 3.Supply is incredibly limited- Even two plus years following launch of RTX- the ability to effectively bin these gpus
column3: shows just how far they are stretching the current node process.

column1: Bottom Line-
Dont buy this card if you dont anticipate stepping up to a higher series this year
column2: with the upcoming 3000 seires likely delayed until Q4 (i.e. early next year) This card will be the ultimate for a while
column3: and the price definitely dictates it.

column1: Do buy this card if you are aware of that
column2: and understand just how far ahead of other Cards this really is
column3: the best Nvidia can hope to do is to match the output of this card for under $1000 come this time next year.

column2: it's not as long as some of my prior cards but it certainly is thick. It is a triple slot so if your pci slots are all taken you might have to figure what stays and what goes. This card uses a dual fan set up and with a aggressive fan curve it keeps the temps down to a manageable level. I recommend good case cooling as well. You will definitely hear the fans wind up to full speed during a heavy load but I wouldn't call it horrible. BUT some are more sensitive to noise then others. There were some bad cards on the market with Micron memory and happily these cards have the Samsung memory. So far not problems or hiccups. If the best is in your budget then I say go for it."^5^Jun 11

column2: Installed it and fired it up. I noticed right away there was some kind of issue with the newest drivers. I was getting framerate stutters all over the place. I tried downgrading the drivers (after uninstalling with DDU) to a 'Known stable version'. This didn't help at all. I was still getting the stutters. I was starting to wonder if I had a defective card. So
column3: I did some more snooping online and found hundreds of other people saying that this card had some issues due to drivers. I even found Reddit posts as of last month saying that even the newest drivers STILL had some issues. So
column6: Put it back in the box
column7: And took it back to Best Buy. I ended up getting the RTX2070 Super and now all of my games are buttery smooth on ultra settings.

column1: This could be such a great card at a great bargain
