Zynergy85^/xfx-amd-radeon-rx-5700-xt-raw-ii-8gb-gddr6-pci-express-4-0-graphics-card-with-zero-db-black/6375963?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^4^0^"Latest driver released from AMD does what it says  it does. It fixed Freesync 2 glitches. WhatI mean by this is
column2: it fixes some games not recognizing Freesync 2 with Windows 10 HDR enabled in settings. This card is much better off now than at launch. It works. Keep in mind this is no RTX 2080 or even GTX 1080 Ti. What it is
column3: is an excellent 1080p or 1440p HDR video card. You do get what you pay for. If you want 4K
column4: honestly going to say buy 2070 Super+. Will this card do 4K? Yes but you'll miss half of your graphics settings right now. 4K video? Not a problem there. This card barely reaches 60c 1440p in Borderlands 3 Maxed out in game settings. HDR enabled and get around 75-83 fps topped off and 54fps at the lowest working hard with 2-4 friends on screen. I'm giving this 4 stars for what the card is. Id give it 5 if it was a 5800 XT with 12 gigs of GDDR6 pumping out 50-60fps 4K. Still this is an excellent buy
column5: you can purchase this with confidence running the latest driver from AMD's website."^4^Oct 25

column1: Meiru^/xfx-amd-radeon-rx-5700-xt-raw-ii-8gb-gddr6-pci-express-4-0-graphics-card-with-zero-db-black/6375963?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^7^3^"Disclaimer: My 5700 XT is paired with a Ryzen 5 2600X and 16 GBs of RAM.
Pros:
- Very good performance. Runs modern titles very well. I tested titles such as Monster Hunter: World
column5: and Apex Legends. All of them ran at a reliable 60+ FPS at 1080p. All titles were on max settings
column6: of course.

column1: - Good value. For 400 dollars
column2: you are getting a very solid card. This card competes with the 2060 Super
column3: and has better performance. The 2070 Super is $100+ more for only a 10-15 FPS boost in most games plus the RTX feature. Not worth it imo
column4: but if you want RTX and have some spare cash

column1: - Clean aesthetic. Not much else to say
column2: except that it looks clean without any excessive RGB lights.

column1: Cons:
- Sub-par drivers. The main thing Nvidia has over AMD is the driver support. Hopefully
column3: AMD drivers will deliver better optimization.

column1: - Size. This card is huge. Its easily the biggest card I've ever owned. It has only two fans
column2: but the card itself is thick
column3: ironically thicker than the 'THICC' branded XFX 5700 XT cards.

column1: - Thermals. This may be due to not-so-great driver support from AMD
column2: but for how big this card is
column3: it runs a bit hot. Adjusting the fan settings in the AMD software is a must. After that
column5: and the fans are not that loud at all.

column1: - No RTX. Obviously
column2: the biggest difference between this card and its Nvidia competitors is the lack of RTX. If Ray Tracing isn't that big of a deal for you
column4: then buy a 2060 Super. It's the same price as a 5700 XT
column5: but with a 10-15% performance cut and RTX.

column1: The main thing holding this card back is AMD's subpar driver support causing problems (at time of reviewing) and its questionable thermals. This card blackscreened on me once
column4: a great card whose problems can hopefully be ironed out in time."^4^Oct 23

column1: Corey^/xfx-amd-radeon-rx-5700-xt-raw-ii-8gb-gddr6-pci-express-4-0-graphics-card-with-zero-db-black/6375963?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^0^"This card powered games with no problem
column2: allowing me to run them in Ultra at 1440p - when it worked. This card constantly crashed my computer
column3: a black screen followed by a reboot or artifacting followed by the computer freezing and a hard reboot being required. Research this card before buying - it is a common issue! I am an IT professional and did any and all troubleshooting possible to try and resolve the issue
column4: but in the end it just wouldn't work. I had a feeling I should have returned it before my return period ended
column5: but I thought I had it working
column6: a couple days of solid performance. Two days after the return period ended
column7: constant issues again. I went back to NVidia and purchased a 2070S today - I should have never abandoned NVidia to save a little cash
column8: there cards are always solid and reliable."^1^Jan 20

column1: GiftCardGuy^/xfx-amd-radeon-rx-5700-xt-raw-ii-8gb-gddr6-pci-express-4-0-graphics-card-with-zero-db-black/6375963?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^0^"I don't write reviews
column2: but I feel that this will help Best Buy

column1: This board would not output any video.  My motherboard is a MSI x570 A PRO
column2: with Ryzen 7 3700x.  A much older (30 bucks
column3: from six years ago) worked.  I exchanged this card for another one.  Also same problem.  XFX tech support asked if both powers were plugged in
column4: and if both blue LEDS were showing.  They were
column5: but video output on monitor was 'Input not supported'.

column1: Best Buy has a nice return policy.  I decided to get an MSI 2060 GPU
XFX graphics card is also pretty long
column2: and covered up the SATA ports on my ATX sized motherboard.

column1: Too bad.  The specs and price were nice."^1^Dec 19

Shane^/xfx-amd-radeon-rx-5700-xt-raw-ii-8gb-gddr6-pci-express-4-0-graphics-card-with-zero-db-black/6375963?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^0^"So stock out of the box this thing was having a bit of trouble staying cool
column2: but if you go to the EVGA website and flash it to the latest BIOS
column3: I found that the cooling performance was greatly improved in the latest BIOS. The fans now come on at a reasonable temperature
column4: and aren't too loud to boot (they sound around the same loudness as a stock Ryzen cooler IMO)

column1: Under load
column2: it hovers around 72C in my case
column3: and boosts up around 1970MHz. Really impressed with this 5700XT
column4: especially considering it's price range. This thing happily runs Modern Warfare maxed 1440p at around 144FPS with no throttling or dips. Awesome."^5^Dec 19

column1: h3r0sH0t^/xfx-amd-radeon-rx-5700-xt-raw-ii-8gb-gddr6-pci-express-4-0-graphics-card-with-zero-db-black/6375963?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^0^"I have a decent gaming rig
column2: set up with a R9 390 that's lasted me since it has come out. I purchased the new Call of Duty on Thanksgiving as it was a good deal
column3: well even though my computer met and exceeded the min specs
column5: so I bought this as my GPU was the only thing maxed. Of course I got this card on black friday
column6: but the next day it goes on sale for $369.99
column7: super disappointing. Anyways
column8: the card itself is great and I would recommend it as it is the equivalent of the 2070 super for much cheaper."^5^Dec 5

column1: Fr0sti3R0gu3^/xfx-amd-radeon-rx-5700-xt-raw-ii-8gb-gddr6-pci-express-4-0-graphics-card-with-zero-db-black/6375963?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^6^3^"I have been using twin GTX 970 cards by EVGA since I first pieced my tower together back five years ago which got me by just fine until Nvidia stopped supporting SLI for my cards & 1080p on my 144hz ASUS monitor suddenly didn't pan out for the latest generation of games.

I was recently gifted COD Modern Warfare 2019 & I was finally unable to play a game at my minimum standard of 60fps with all the bells and whistles.  So here I am floating between a 2070 Super and the RX 5700 XT as my next card and 1440p HDR as my next tier of graphical enjoyment.  After several reviews & some YT videos covering just about everything I needed to know about the current industry & what it came down to for me was a $100+ difference for less than ten percent margin on frame-rates plus Ray Tracing which to me seems to be a nice perk though limited in support right now = not cost effective IMO.

It's been a long time since I used a non-Nvidia based card actually since ATI had the All-in-Wonder card series and before AMD took over.  I've been eyeing putting together an AMD rig since the new Ryzen processors had been introduced & I figured now might be a decent time to do just that.

How I came about buying the XFX brand of RX 5700 XT card is by viewing their portfolio of hardware and reading the reviews offered.  I wanted to pick up their newest card which is the XFX RX 5700 XT Thicc III Ultra but my local Best Buy didn't carry it and I needed a card tonight so I can play my gifted game with friends and family so I picked up the XFX RX 5700 XT RAW II.  I am sure I will be happy with it even though deep down inside I know what I really wanted was the Thicc III Ultra...  oh well.  Hahaha!!  Included are a couple of pictures of my EVGA Sli cards before & their XFX replacement as evidence to my situation."^5^Nov 2

Zaduwer^/xfx-amd-radeon-rx-5700-xt-raw-ii-8gb-gddr6-pci-express-4-0-graphics-card-with-zero-db-black/6375963?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"Since the first week of purchase this card has been having issues.  Games freeze for 2-3 seconds. Began with green screens
column2: which required a restart. Then crashing more than 3x a day.

column1: Now as of this reviews date
column2: card now black screens 3x a day and automatically restarts my desktop
column3: randomly has flashes of green when gaming as well. Sometimes crashes and maxes out fan speeds until manually restarted.

column1: I originally held out thinking drivers were at fault
column2: but the problems kept getting consistently worse and more aggravating.

column1: Drivers are up to date
column2: in fact I tried various driver versions
column3: some problems would disappear and a whole new batch of issues would re-arise in their place. I have spent more time fixing. troubleshooting and applying workarounds than having fun with this card.

column1: Coming from AMD cards only
column3: this card is a beast when it works
column4: but absolutely horrendous to deal with. Save yourself a headache and spend abit extra on the NVIDIA Super because those cards can run consistently."^1^Jan 28

column1: Beaud8^/xfx-amd-radeon-rx-5700-xt-raw-ii-8gb-gddr6-pci-express-4-0-graphics-card-with-zero-db-black/6375963?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"I have had the gpu for about two weeks with no issues at all.  This card will max out everything you play at 1080p with over 100fps consistently. BFV runs around 130 FPS on ultra for myself at 1080p
column2: and drops to around 110 FPS at 1440p. Division 2 around 120 FPS max settings 1080p. Doom on Vulkan maxes out at 200 FPS on max settings 1080p. If your case is properly ventilated
column3: with room for the card to breathe it will not over heat and crash (like many others have stated). Not one over heat or crash yet. It can be mildly OCd and gains about 5-7% performance. The aesthetics of the card are solid.  Metal back plate
column4: plastic shroud all black. The fans are a glossy black (but you never see the fans unless you have a vertical mount gpu).  White XFX led logo is subtle and not over powering.  This card is large taking up 2 1/2 to 3 slots on your board.  But so far no issues and Im really enjoying this card. Would highly recommend especially at the price point."^5^Jan 16

column1: kuli^/xfx-amd-radeon-rx-5700-xt-raw-ii-8gb-gddr6-pci-express-4-0-graphics-card-with-zero-db-black/6375963?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"So
Where to start.  I wanted to love AMD GPUs again after 5 years with a 1070 in an Alienware.  Unfortunately
column2: the software and drivers for these cards is still horrible.  Its still as bad as it was back in the R9 390 days.  The card hard crashed my system about every 2 hours.  Also
column4: I dont care what you set the fans too
column5: it runs 70-90C on most games.  Oh yeah
column6: every time it crashed my computer it reset the fan curve to never go above 50% so it would just hit 100C if you didnt remember to change it every single time.  Sorry AMD and Best Buy
column7: its coming back."^1^Jan 4

column1: MJB429^/xfx-amd-radeon-rx-5700-xt-raw-ii-8gb-gddr6-pci-express-4-0-graphics-card-with-zero-db-black/6375963?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"I recently purchased this card to replace an Nvidia RTX 1660. The card performed decent

column3: but I saw the positive reviews for this card and ended up purchasing it.

column1: So far my experience has been great. I uninstalled all of the Nvidia software/drivers before installing this card. The install went smooth. I made sure I downloaded the most recent drivers. I actually downloaded them from the XFX web site because they had the latest update. The AMD website didn't.
I am very happy with the performance of this card. I'm playing The Division 2 and I can tell a difference in visuals and performance. I'm not in the 4k realm
column2: but the 1080P visuals are still stunning. On Ultra settings I'm averaging 100fps. Borderlands 3 also looks amazing.

column1: For those on the fence I highly recommend this card."^5^Nov 2

column1: Realist^/xfx-amd-radeon-rx-5700-xt-raw-ii-8gb-gddr6-pci-express-4-0-graphics-card-with-zero-db-black/6375963?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"I purchased this GPU trying to build out a hackintosh and thought it might be decent...  Before installing Mac OS
column2: I decided to try it out in Windows first.

column1: I ran DDU to remove older Nvidia and AMD drivers (while in safe mode) and after getting the card running
column2: I was getting a display driver failed to start error...  I had to modify the registry to alter the delay timing for the driver and that error went away.

column1: Then I ran into another error where the shutting off the monitor made it so the card wouldn't reconnect when powering the monitor on (that's still very much an issue).
Of course
column2: my final issue was that the card would get over a 103 C at the GPU Junction while playing Overwatch...  I can only imagine how hot it would get playing something really taxing.  It actually idles at 62 C and that's double what my old GTX 1080 would idle at
column3: but that card only had one fan!

column1: Seriously avoid these XFX cards if you're wanting to go AMD
column2: as this has to be one of the worst cards running this GPU and I can't fathom why Best Buy partners with these guys!"^1^Feb 18

column2: as it seems like such a value. When the card was running
column3: games did look nice with good FPS even on ultra settings. Temps for me werent bad (70-75 on default fan settings). Card had some mild coil whine but really wasnt too bad even with speakers on low volume. Did have some stuttering issues on first person shooter games even though FPS appeared high
column4: and in one game would have occasional flashes where the colors would darken for a couple frames. However my biggest problem was reoccurring  issues with it freezing my computer or turning my screen black with audio playing in the background. Tried uninstalling drivers reinstalling
column5: making sure card was seated correctly
column6: etc but still had the same problems.

column1: To be fair the  problem didnt happen all the time
column2: and after a hard reset of the computer Id be able to boot up a game and play for a couple hours without problems. The freezes were random. However I feel for several hundred dollars a card shouldnt be crashing my computer. In the end I returned it and bought a 2070s
column3: and couldnt be happier. Theres a noticeable performance increase and everything is much more stable. Temps and noise are better too."^2^Jan 11

column1: D12005^/xfx-amd-radeon-rx-5700-xt-raw-ii-8gb-gddr6-pci-express-4-0-graphics-card-with-zero-db-black/6375963?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"Out of the box this ran great on most things. It lowered the temps and every game I tested ran flawlessly after that. Great performance and value on this."^4^Dec 19
Copa1^/xfx-amd-radeon-rx-5700-xt-raw-ii-8gb-gddr6-pci-express-4-0-graphics-card-with-zero-db-black/6375963?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^2^"I initially had issues with the fan curves
column2: Fans would not turn on until fully hot.  As a result of this
column3: I was uncertain if I would hang on to the card.  I did some research and found that you need to update the bios.  I downloaded the bios from the XFX website. This alone did the trick and completely fixed all of my heating issues.  Under full load
column4: my card doesn't get over 77 C
column6: 55 C. It's  been going on two weeks strong since the bios update and not a single issue. I'm now enjoying the heck out of this card! Update your bios
column7: it worked for me."^5^Dec 18

column1: Dakz^/xfx-amd-radeon-rx-5700-xt-raw-ii-8gb-gddr6-pci-express-4-0-graphics-card-with-zero-db-black/6375963?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^7^6^"I purchased this due to the seemingly great reviews on multiple sites from others - but this was a massive mistake (that I was ironically warned about). Upon installation (a clean install) the card immediately caused my PC to BSOD. I installed all the new drivers and went through the process - again
column2: another BSOD. So I cleared the drivers and did a fresh reinstall once more - another BSOD
column3: but now I could not even log in to my computer. The drivers literally corrupted my OS Win10 and I was unable to do anything.

column1: As I am trying to get things up and running again
column2: the card randomly started generating an insane amount of heat and the fans went into full 100% blow; mind you I was just booting the PC at this time
column3: there was NOTHING under load because I could not even fully boot my PC.  So I remove the GPU and put my old GPU in instead and ran into the fact that it appears this XFX had burned out one of my PIC slots. That's right! It had done permanent damage to my motherboard
column4: but thankfully I have another slot. I used the other PCI slot
column5: used my old GPU (which is Nvidia by the way)
column6: and reinstalled Win10. This took me roughly 4 hours of time to just get my PC running again!

column1: As mentioned
column2: I was warned about AMD cards and told that the drivers are a mess. I even read various articles that the AMD cards have issues with M.2 and using a PCI 4.0 - which I have. I should have never made this purchase and XFX has not only robbed me of time
column3: but their faulty product has caused damage to my motherboard
column4: which is only a couple months old. I love my AMD 3700X processor
column5: but they are simply not ready for the GPU market with such poor hardware AND software.

column1: Avoid this card at all costs
column2: I do not care what the other reviews are stating
column3: there is something seriously wrong with this card (do your research and you will find many articles and forums calling out exactly what happened to me) and I know that I will not be considered AMD for a GPU anytime soon."^1^Dec 8

Don't listen to the reviews and save $500+ with this powerhouse."^5^Dec 4

column2: it's impressive but loud.  The comments regarding driver issues

column1: Any time I overclock this even if it's 1%
column2: it WILL crash my system at some point.  Seems to have a lot of issues changing from one game to another or from gaming back to windows.  So leave the card alone!  Don't OC.

column1: ***The best experience for me?  Leave the Radeon settings at standard for the least bugs and absolutely bump up the fan curve.  It's made a world of difference.  As has adding a small fan to focus on the junction point (ugly but effective).   Keeping it cooler will prove vital to your sanity.***

column1: BrettDay^/xfx-amd-radeon-rx-5700-xt-raw-ii-8gb-gddr6-pci-express-4-0-graphics-card-with-zero-db-black/6375963?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^4^"I purchased this card and paired it up with a stock Ryzen 3600 and 24GB of DDR 3200. Let's just say the raw power of this card is just insane. I was gaming at 4k medium setting and was hitting FPS. That's the good part.
The bad part. This card runs hotter than the sun
column2: and then some. Out of the box
column3: the fan curse was non-exisitent. I used my own fan curve and quickly found out that I needed it to be far more aggressive.

column1: With more tweaks
column2: the lowest fan speed was at 30% and that kept the card idling at around 50c. When you start loading this card up though it will hit 85/90/95c easily
column3: and that's with the fan going full pelt at 100%. Loud is an understatement. It's the loudest card I have ever heard in my life. The junction was always sitting at around 100/105c too. Just insanely hot. It's not the noise
column4: and the worry about it spontaneously combusting just isn't worth it.

column1: Also
column3: but there were so many errors. Game after game crashed on me. I am sure that with a little more time the navi chips will be great
column4: but seriously poor optimization means you should just walk right past this card. I picked up the EVGA 2070 Super and games that were hitting 90c on the XFX were barely hitting 62c on the NVIDIA Card. Just save a little while longer and get an NVIDIA card."^2^Dec 22

column1: Bailey^/xfx-amd-radeon-rx-5700-xt-raw-ii-8gb-gddr6-pci-express-4-0-graphics-card-with-zero-db-black/6375963?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^5^"I updated my system with this video card and a new 3700X and corsair 3200 RGB Pro I could not be happier great combination also MSI EDGE"^5^Dec 7

column1: I only have the card for three days. No cons at this point.

PJACKSON^/xfx-amd-radeon-rx-5700-xt-raw-ii-8gb-gddr6-pci-express-4-0-graphics-card-with-zero-db-black/6375963?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^1^"This card is performing great in my new gaming machine. It pushes 60+ fps on high graphics settings on all the most recent games.

Getting the card setup was a little tricky as the fans did not spin on their own right out of the box. Good thing I was watching gpu temps as the first game I played she got up to 95c before I started trouble shooting.
I was able to create a custom fan profile in both wattman and MSI afterburner software that control the fans just how I like them and keep the temps under 75c.
All in all its a good card that looks cool in the system and performs just how I was hoping."^4^Jan 3

Jdogg^/xfx-amd-radeon-rx-5700-xt-raw-ii-8gb-gddr6-pci-express-4-0-graphics-card-with-zero-db-black/6375963?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^1^"At the beginning this card started out great. The drivers were easy to install and the stress tests gave expected results. However once I started up more demanding games such as borderlands 3 and monster hunter world the card would provide good frame rates at around 60 fps for the first 30 minutes. After that my screen turned black
column2: but I could still hear the in game sound. I tried everything during my troubleshooting. After 2 days the problem still persisted and I decided to exchange the card for a 2070 super which has no problems at all. Stay away from this card!!!"^2^Jan 2

column1: PhoenixTech^/xfx-amd-radeon-rx-5700-xt-raw-ii-8gb-gddr6-pci-express-4-0-graphics-card-with-zero-db-black/6375963?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^1^"I was back and forth between this
column3: and the 2070. I ultimately got this one when it went on sale for $369.99 during the BF/Cyber Monday week. I don't regret my decision one bit. I was playing Forza 4 Horizon at a steady 60FPS on my LG SK9000 at 4k and the card barely hit 90% duty cycle. If you want to push max settings at 1440P for most titles out there
column4: this is definitely the card you want. Make sure you get the AMD Adrenaline software which allows you to under/over volt the GPU/VRAM and adjust the fan curves it comes with (The unit likes to run toasty). Also the two free games and Xbox live game pass was a nice touch. Thank you

column1: DrGuru^/xfx-amd-radeon-rx-5700-xt-raw-ii-8gb-gddr6-pci-express-4-0-graphics-card-with-zero-db-black/6375963?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^7^7^"I bought this for my bday and got a nice little discount on top of the already sale price.
Always hearing about how loud these are. Quite frankly
At full load
column2: this thing runs pretty cool at 65c.

column1: Upgraded from a Zotac 1070 mini and I'm seeing a night and day difference.
Can finally run Ark @1440p on high to ultra settings around 60 frames.
Runs Modern Warfare @1440p on max settings (minus the irritating ambient occlusion crap) at 75 frames( my 32 inch 75hz HP Omen limits this thing).
Borderlands 3 doesn't drop below 75 frames on ultra @1440p
Red Dead Redemption 2 is running at medium to high at a steady 60 to 70 frames @1440p.
I've gained at least 30% in frame rate all the while beefing up the graphical details by at least a tier or two.
And for what? Under $400?
A steal of deal.

The only issue I've had is the Radeon software. Boy out boy is it far less fluent than nvidias. I already ran into an issue with running dual monitors at separate resolutions.  It does not like having a DP adapter to an HDMI at all.
Other than that
My first Radeon card ever and I'll definitely be eye balling them from now on.
Dear Nvidia
Get your crap together.
Running on a
32 GB DDR 4 3200 hz
600 Watt Thermaltake"^5^Dec 17

syliftech^/xfx-amd-radeon-rx-5700-xt-raw-ii-8gb-gddr6-pci-express-4-0-graphics-card-with-zero-db-black/6375963?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^1^"This is a very good card for the price. The fans are very quiet under most operations
column2: when the card does reach higher temps the fans do get rather loud (vacuum cleaner loud). It had no trouble playing games
column3: drivers 19.11.3 were stable and had no crashing/stuttering/black screens.

column1: I can recommend this card to anyone on a budget. If you are limited  to purchasing through best buy
column2: this card or the XFX Thicc 3 Ultra are the best options available. If you can buy elsewhere go with a Sapphire Nitro Pulse
column3: Power color Red Devil or Gigabyte 5700xt. All of these options provide better cooling than the Raw II."^4^Dec 4

column1: Hank^/xfx-amd-radeon-rx-5700-xt-raw-ii-8gb-gddr6-pci-express-4-0-graphics-card-with-zero-db-black/6375963?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^4^4^"Bought mine online had it ready for pickup at the bestbuy and was excited to put it in my rig. Bestbuy was awesome refunded me and went with a MSI 2070 Super and I'm never looking back. Third AMD card I've bought and they have manufacturer issues despite solid benchmark advertising they have.  Sorry AMD you let me down.  Thanks again NVIDIA never once had nvidia issues. My two R9s I bought last time liquid cooled all were dead. So AMD sorry. Bestbuy has best prices. They are a few dollars cheaper than newegg.  Amazon just creates thier own high prices. BESTBUY had this in stock even after black friday and will stick with best buy.  Cant beat them."^1^Dec 2

column1: Joemama^/corsair-icue-220t-rgb-airflow-atx-mid-tower-smart-case-black/6370550?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^5^0^"I got this because I didnt want a large full size tower and the small form factor cases are not only expensive but tend to run a bit hot
column2: so this was a great middle ground for size and thermals. Construction is sturdy and very professional
column3: like every other Corsair case Ive ever used or seen. Filters are fine enough to catch the majority of particles and very easy to remove and clean. Building in it was for the most part extremely easy as even though it is compact
column4: it was well thought out as to placement of most access holes for Routing cables etc. the only complaints I have are that the mounting standoffs are about 1/2 too high to comfortably mount some larger fans or a radiator easily
column5: and that the included fans are not PWM so they run faster than they really need to
column6: creating noise that certainly isnt necessary. I swapped the fans out for some Corsair LL series fans I already had which made it virtually silent. I do feel the price is a bit high however it is significantly cheaper than other cases that I would classify to be the same size and quality
column7: so thats ok. I just think all these smaller cases are overpriced
column8: its not a knock on this particular case. Less material should mean less cost
column9: but that has not been the case for smaller cases I have noticed.

column1: I would highly recommend this case to anyone looking for a small footprint that can still house a great gaming system!"^5^Nov 9
Justanotherpcnerd^/corsair-icue-220t-rgb-airflow-atx-mid-tower-smart-case-black/6370550?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^4^0^"My old case was huge compared to this
column2: couldn't fit on my desk and had broken cosmetic parts here and there. I hardly ever use the read/write internal disc drive anymore so not having a place for that in the case was not a problem. I really like this case. I think it's perfect for a simple build. It fits my full ATX motherboard with a Master Cooler CPU cooler just fine. My power supply sits under the cover at the bottom and makes it look clean concealing the cords with it as well. It only comes with 3 fans so I mounted one at the front for intake and my HDD
column3: one on the CPU radiator and one on the back. Doesn't come with software but finding it online was easy. The RGB fans are easy enough to install and move around. The software allows you to make them bright or dim and any color you want. I've had it for about a month now and the only minor draw back I would say is the filter. The filter stops most dust but not all but hey my last case didn't have one so this is a huge upgrade. I also like how easy it is to remove and clean them. The only other possible downfall I could see with this case is the front panel. The panel is metal with four nubs that each snap into a plastic part. I could see them wearing out from cleaning the front filter often but only after a long time of doing so."^4^Dec 20

column1: M88K^/corsair-icue-220t-rgb-airflow-atx-mid-tower-smart-case-black/6370550?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^0^"Great case

MudKingMts^/corsair-icue-220t-rgb-airflow-atx-mid-tower-smart-case-black/6370550?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"Pros:
Looks great
Easy to install hardware
Cons:
Had to remove hard drive cage to fit power supply cables because there was not enough room
My 240mm AIO has to be mounted at front of case because there was no clearance between top of case and motherboard
I would recommend this case tho it was a fun build and looks great when finished"^4^Jan 4

Bossman^/corsair-icue-220t-rgb-airflow-atx-mid-tower-smart-case-black/6370550?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"The first thing to say about this case is the fans are LOUD. Super disappointed in the SP120 RGB fans. While they look great
column2: they are DC only fans and have a minimum speed for 1200 rpm
column3: so they are LOUD. They only go from LOUD to SUPER LOUD and with motherboard fan controls these days wanting to always crank the fans when the CPU temp is high
column4: which happens as soon as you put load on them
column5: this case will be very loud.

column1: I replaced all my fans with LL120 PWM fans which you can spin down to 300 rpm or so
column2: but that kinda defeats the purpose of this case and the cost is now way higher than the iCUE 465X case. So in reality you are probably better off getting that case over this one as it comes with the LL120 fans already installed
column3: unless you are fine with a super noisy case. And while you are at it get a Commander Pro to control the fans so you can avoid the nasty noise spikes when you open up Chrome!

column1: The second thing to say about this case is that while the marketing material for this case say it can take up a 280mm cooler up front
column2: that's not entirely correct. The cut outs for the fans in the front are for 120mm fans
column3: so while the mounting holes would allow for 140mm fans
column4: as you can see from the included photo they don't really fit. It would also make the RGB aesthetics of the case really bad. Unlike the iCUE 465X case
column5: at least they are hidden by the front panel somewhat so it would not too bad
column6: but it would not be ideal. Also the fan blades would be hidden behind the cut outs.

column1: I am not sure why Corsair just made the rails without the cut outs to make it better for fitting both 120mm and 140mm fans.
Also for those interested
column2: it does fit a 240mm cooler up front just fine even though it does not say that. That's how I set it up in my case with a 240mm cooler covering the top two fans and the last fan just blowing on the hard drive case.

column1: Finally I was worried about room for a GPU with a cooler up front
column2: but it actually fits fine as you can see with my 2080Ti from my gaming rig mocked up in one of the photos."^3^Jan 3

column1: Nick^/corsair-icue-220t-rgb-airflow-atx-mid-tower-smart-case-black/6370550?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"Pretty solid case. All steel framework. Decent amount of room to build in."^5^Nov 29

Seth^/corsair-icue-220t-rgb-airflow-atx-mid-tower-smart-case-black/6370550?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^0^1^"I really wanted to love this case because it's absolutely beautiful but if you're going with an ATX build I do not recommend it. My motherboard was extremely cramped in this
column2: it had maybe a couple millimeters of space at the bottom portion of the case.

column1: Cable management and wiring in general is an absolute nightmare
column2: again there's just not enough space. Don't plan on using any sort of HDD in your build because you'll most likely have to remove the hard drive cage to get all of your wires coming from your PSU to fit.

column1: Neither of my SSD's fit into the included mounts either so that was another flaw
This was the single worst experience with a case in all of the PC builds I have done over the years. I spent nearly 3 hours trying to get this thing to work but couldn't make it happen.
The only reason im giving this two stars is because of how great it looks."^2^Mar 25

ThunderDPM^/corsair-icue-220t-rgb-airflow-atx-mid-tower-smart-case-black/6370550?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^0^1^"Good quality mid-tower however too tight and difficult to install components.  Not recommended for serious gamers."^3^Jan 15
ernstp5^/corsair-icue-220t-rgb-airflow-atx-mid-tower-smart-case-black/6370550?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^4^10^"I purchase this case from best buy
column3: LED fans and icue software that I have to run to shut lights off sucks
column4: as if software isn't running fans light up no case control or remote
column5: case is on the small side yes I did stick a 360mm rad in front but in push pull setup I had to remove hard drive cage to get it to fit along with my 850 watt psu. The middle fan of push/ pull set up had to be removed so my Evga black 2080 can fit in
column6: the case could be a little longer. but no back exhaust fan? for the price there should be
column7: another thing the combo audio port on top of case the headset / microphone combo where is the adapter to use a regular headset and mic? So I have to now buy a 3.5mm splitter to use top mounted audio port
column8: the nzxt h510 comes with said adapter for their combo port
column9: at a much cheaper price tag. Not happy with corsair.. I may return the case or sell it on CL
column10: for me it was a let down for the price."^3^Dec 5

column1: Nick^/insignia-450w-atx12v-2-4-eps12v-2-92-80-plus-power-supply-gray/5976300?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^0^"It's a basic power supply

column1: I also wanted to mention this line from the product description: 'It produces 450W for better game and program performance' I personally do not believe having more wattage is going to increase performance at all.

column2: but it proved me wrong. The installation was ridiculously easy. All I had to do was plug it into a USB port and it was ready to go about ten seconds later. I didnt even have to open my computer or fuss with software.

column1: The Juke delivers sound superior to the so-so onboard sound I had before. Games sound so much better. In Quake
column2: explosions are BOOM! Instead of boom and death screams are AGHHHH! Instead of ahhh. Subtle sounds like footsteps
column4: and a breeze blowing in Skyrim are more refined

column1: When listening to music all the instruments come across clearly like the band is in the room with you playing.
Installing the optional software from the companys website is supposed to somehow make your headphones sound like a 7.1 experience
column2: but I havent figured that out yet. Anyway
column3: the amazing 2.0 sound is enough for me.

column1: The juke obviously wont sound as good as some 100+ dollar product
column2: but it should be enough for most people who want to play games
column4: and whatnot at home on their computers. And for only $15 its hard to argue with the price."^5^Jul 22

column1: Jethro62^/roccat-juke-virtual-7-1-usb-stereo-external-sound-card/6335139?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^7^0^"Was trying to make a sound recording with my Lenovo Ideapad laptop using the Audacity program. Wanted to record from a professional audio board

column5: I decided I had nothing to lose
column6: so took it home to try it. Plugged the audio board into the yellow jack on the unit
column7: then the USB end into the laptop. Didnt work. Was about to pack it up and take it back until I looked closer and saw it had a purple microphone jack. Plugged into that

Vansch76^/roccat-juke-virtual-7-1-usb-stereo-external-sound-card/6335139?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"i dont have a sound card in my desktop only the on board sound on the mother board
column2: and was getting a very annoying buzz and sometimes whining noises when moving the mouse. playing some games were impossible because of the screeching coming from the speakers.

column1: The Juke usb sound card eliminated most of the issue. there was still some noise but it was much more tolerable. I later ordered an isolation filter for $11 of of amazon which got rid of the problem. $16 after shipping.
the filter on amazon is called 'Mpow Ground Loop Noise Isolator'
I have not tried it with just the filter yet and have not tried the mic input on the Juke usb sound card.
over all I am satisfied with the sound card. it is much cheaper than buying a sound card that is not available with out ordering it from best buy.
the only con is that when the computer boots
column2: the speakers would pop loudly which I feel could damage your speakers if they are expensive ones. There were several pops as the computer was booting. I would unplug the usb Juke until the computer had fully booted.

column1: using the filter from amazon there is only one small pop when the computer boots and no other pops.
using both the usb Juke and the filter got rid of the noise issue for under $30.
I may buy an internal sound card later."^4^Jan 19

Rick^/roccat-juke-virtual-7-1-usb-stereo-external-sound-card/6335139?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"I purchased this for $11.00 at Best Buy and I thought I would check it out. Went home and plugged it in a free USB port. Downloaded the Roccat software and be fan to set things up. You can use the Roccat Jukes and use 2 channel to 8 channel based upon your speaker setup. Next step is the DSP mode which enables the surround sound and then select 7.1 virtual speaker shift and Xear Surround Max. Select Headphone and begin playing games. I tested the surround in Black Ops 4
column3: Apex Legeands and Battlefield V. The Roccat provides a very solid surround that reveals people coming from behind or above. The Roccats surround can be clicked off so you can use the Dolby Atmos or Windows Sonic in Windows. I use Dolby Atmos and it elevated the effectiveness of the sound and positions of sounds very well. The Roccat adds a little bump in power and it is very noticeable.

column1: This little gadget is amazing and it provides so many adjustments to fit your needs."^5^Mar 31

column3: the slower 3200G system was running Chromium on Linux Mint 19.2.  Both systems were running 16GB RAM.  I know this is apples to oranges
column4: but I had expected more from the Linux build with the newer CPU.  You will have to do a BIOS upgrade on some motherboards (such as the B450) to use 3000-series Ryzens.  I will add a GPU to the 3200G build.. I suspect that will bring performance up.  Neither system was overclocked

column1: Kaos08^/msi-geforce-gtx-1660-ti-gaming-x-6gb-gddr6-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card/6330461?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^29^"MSI yet again did a great job with the 1660Ti. This card is mainly for an entry level gamer wanting to get great 1080P content.

The way Im using it is they mining. Currently this card gets 30MH/S on Ethash *Undervolted* under 75 watts. which is a mining ago utilize in cyrptocurreny. Yes I know gamers dont like us but we contribute a great amount in nvidia sales as well and thats one reason Im writing this review.
Out of the box it shows the workmans craft they put into the gaming edition great design and a touch of RGB.

I chose this card because of the looks mainly and the efficiency of the card. Also for resale value in the future. If your a miner you should already know this is one of the best efficient mining card and if your a casual gamer wanting decent FPS than this is a great choice of well. This card also requires an 8pin pci connector so make sure you have one available on your PSU
Happy Mining!"^5^May 21

column1: scTech^/corsair-vengeance-lpx-16gb-2pk-x-8gb-3-2-ghz-ddr4-dram-desktop-memory-kit-black/4895506?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"Bought for Gigabyte B450M ds3h WiFi motherboard. After installing and turning on XMP I got a blue screen of death. Disabling XMP running memory at 2133Mhz system was stable.  After some research I found an article to adjust memory timings manually.
On the M.I.T. tab in Bios select Advanced Memory Settings. Then select Memory Timing Mode and select Manual.
First enable XMP
-Set DRAM voltage manually to 1.35v
-Set RAM multiplier to 32x
-Set the first five subtimings manually to 16-18-18-18-36 (important)
-Set the sixth timing (tRC) to 56 instead of 54 (important)
When setting timings manually in Bios highlight the timing you wish to change and type in the number and press enter. Do this for all timings you change. Save and exit.
After applying these timing changes my memory is rock solid."^4^Dec 7
Hail4Gaming^/corsair-vengeance-lpx-16gb-2pk-x-8gb-3-2-ghz-ddr4-dram-desktop-memory-kit-black/4895506?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"The RAM

column4: and headed home. It wasn't until I got home that I found out that the 10% of birthday coupon is lessened if the item is already on some sort of sale. So I'm the event of this item at the time already being on sale by 9% of the original price
column5: my birthday coupon have me a whole whooping 1% off which required to am extra $.20 off the total! Wow
column6: what a great deal
column7: sure glad I used the coupon. The item ended up being more expensive this way than purchasing it elsewhere. Other than the disappointing coupon circumstances
column8: the item itself is just what I needed."^3^Mar 3

SuperT^/corsair-lighting-node-pro-black/5845213?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^0^"I was doing a new computer build and purchased the Corsair Lighting Node Pro and combined it with the Corsair HD120 3 Fan Lighting Kit.

It is very simple to install. It requires a SATA power connector for power and an open USB 2.0 header from the motherboard to be able to control all lighting effects with the Corsair Link Software. The small contoller hub is easily mounted out of sight using the supplied two-way tape. It includes 4 lighting node strips and extension cables if needed. The lighting strips easily attach to you PC with 2 options. Each lighting node has a magnetic strip attach to the back. That was the method I used. But for someone that doesn't have a magnetic case you can also remove the tape backing and stick them down where needed.

Can combine this kit with more lighting node pro strips or with the HD120 lighting kit like I did. They work perfectly together. All you need to do is hook the supplied controller cable from the Lighting Node Pro hub to the HD120 lighting hub

After installation you will need to install the latest Corsair Link software from their website. You then a can use the Link software to control all lighting effects on each node and fan individually. There seems to be an endless array of colors and lighting effects to please anyone.
I would highly recommend this kit for its ease of use
column2: quality and endless lighting effect options."^5^Jul 21

column1: overseer^/corsair-lighting-node-pro-black/5845213?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^0^1^"This is an awesome lighting kit for your PC. Colors are bright and vivid. To me the hardest thing was were to put the lights. I have a gaming PC with a full size ATX tower. The led strips are about 12 inches long. They have sticky tape on the back and they are also magnetic. Magnets work good didn't need to use the tape. I had plenty of wire to put them were I wanted them. I have three on channel one and one on channel two.

You will need a USB 2 port on your Motherboard for the controller. Also you will need to download the software from Corsair.com . Download the LINK software. Your lights will not work without it. When I first turned my PC on after installing the lights they did not come on. After I installed the software and configured it I had no problems what so ever! You get a lot of options. You can control each LED strip. I had to update the firmware
column3: it was very easy! The only con is the price. They are expensive but the quality is outstanding. You get what you pay for."^5^Nov 26

Before installing this
column2: my temps barely ever got as low as 38 C on idle and would reach 65-70 C while gaming. After the install
column3: it idles around 29-30 C and playing the same games it's only hitting 40 C!  I have six 120mm intake fans with a very conservative fan curve
column4: and I set the ml140s about the same.  Now the only noise I really hear is is coming from the GPU.

column1: The reason for 4 stars is due to
A) the power and rbg cables coming off the pump are an eyesore.  They need to be sleeved like the coolant lines.  Plus they are very long and make cable management a pain
column2: especially if you have other RBG fans set up.

column1: B) Best Buy doesn't offer any kind of extended replacement plan for this product so if ANY part fails (fans
column3: coolant fittings leak) you have to contact the manufacturer.

column1: Install was not too difficult
column2: just be sure have a plan on how you will route all the cables before you start tightening everything down."^4^Nov 24

column1: Trendy^/corsair-hydro-series-h115i-rgb-platinum-140mm-processor-liquid-cooling-system-with-rgb-lighting-black-silver/6306565?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"So I purchased this puppy as a replacement for my recently purchased Corsair H110i Platinum AIO Liquid CPU Cooler. Lets just say that this is what I was looking for as my 9700k was idling in the mid 40s. Upgraded to this bad boy and now Im idling in the mid to upper 30s. I just needed something more than what the H110 was able to provide and the H115i Platinum (which uses a 280 vs a 240 radiator) is just what I needed!
I would recommend up to a 9900K but the 9700K is the sweet spot for this one."^5^Nov 21

Methtical89^/corsair-hydro-series-h115i-rgb-platinum-140mm-processor-liquid-cooling-system-with-rgb-lighting-black-silver/6306565?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"Before buying this I was having some heat issues with the cooler my cpu came with. column1: mjolnirV^/msi-mech-oc-amd-radeon-rx-5700-8gb-gddr6-pci-express-4-0-graphics-card-black/6374967?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"Windows 10 driver appears to create conflict

Bajo247^/msi-mech-oc-amd-radeon-rx-5700-8gb-gddr6-pci-express-4-0-graphics-card-black/6374967?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"This cards performance caught me by surprise! I've been a long time Nvidia user and just came to realize how much I am overpaying. AMD for the win this year! Great for 1080p and 2k (1440p) gaming!"^5^Nov 15
BenzoSt^/msi-mech-oc-amd-radeon-rx-5700-8gb-gddr6-pci-express-4-0-graphics-card-black/6374967?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"I offer a detailed review of Radeon 5700 MECH OC BV
I recently purchased a Radeon 5700 Mech OC at Best Buy.  When I opened the package
column2: I noticed that the sticker on the backplate read 'Radeon MECH 5700 OC BV'  <-- note the 'BV'.

column1: Question #1: What does 'BV' in my product stand for?

I ran Display Driver Uninstaller 18.0.2.2 by Wagnardsoft ot uninstall previous video card drivers prior to installation of Radeon drivers on this card's product page at MSI.com.  I have beem advised that doing so will help prevent crashes and problems reported with other users of new video cards.  I have however experienced some problems
column4: all as a result of trying out various Radeon features such as Radeon Virtual Super Resolution
column6: and Radeon Enhanced Sync.  I suppose it takes some experimentation to figure out which special Radeon features are compatible with which games.  I attribute these issues to drivers
column7: not hardware.

column1: The performance of my product seems on par with expected
column2: with a 3dMark Time Spy score of 8054 and Uniengine Superposition score of 4420.  I have a Ryzen 3600 CPU and 16gb of 3200Mhz DDR4 memory
column3: which also contribute to these scores.

column1: However
column2: it seems the memory on this video card runs quite hot. I was able to play DOOM 2016 at 4k virtual super resolution (a feature of Radeon cards) at a pretty solid 75 FPS. But in doing so
column3: I noticed that my memory temperature hit 98 degrees Celsius.

column1: Question #2: What is the maximum safe temperature for the GDDR6 memory modules on this card?  I don't want to degrade or break my memory.
I decided to see if I could do something to get my temperature down.  With MSI Afterburner and the Uniengine Heaven 4.0 Basic benchmark
I have a Corsair Carbide 200r case
column2: which has a single 120mm fan in the front and a single 120mm fan in the rear.  I locked both these case fans to run at 100%.  I then used MSI Afterburner to lock my GPU fans at various speeds and compared the respective temperatures with my case's removable side panel on or off.  Here are my results after running Uniengine Heaven 4.0 in 10-minute increments:

column1: Side panel ON:
40% fan (1860 RPM):	GPU at 72
50% fan (2200 RPM):	GPU at 71
60% fan (2500 RPM):	GPU at 70
70% fan (2767 RPM):	GPU at 67
80% fan (2975 RPM):	GPU at 65
(above 80% is subjectively too loud for my ears
Side panel OFF:
40% fan (1860 RPM):	GPU at 66
50% fan (2200 RPM):	GPU at 61
60% fan (2500 RPM):	GPU at 58
70% fan (2767 RPM):	GPU at 57
80% fan (2975 RPM):	GPU at 55

These results clearly indicate that my case is a heat trap. Simply removing the side panel usually reduced temeratures by about 10 degrees. But since I would prefer to not have to open up my case whenever I run a modern computer game
column2: I tried installing a couple of 120mm fans into the side panel.  Running these accessory fans at 100%

column1: Side panel ON
40% fan (1860 RPM):	GPU at 61
50% fan (2200 RPM):	GPU at 57
60% fan (2500 RPM):	GPU at 55
70% fan (2767 RPM):	GPU at 54
80% fan (2975 RPM):	GPU at 54

So my experiments clearly indicate that this GPU will likely want plenty of airflow to manage it's high memory temperature.  I reiterate that I don't know what constitues an unsafe temperature for GDDR6 memory; if it's safe up to like 110 degrees
column2: then I suppose anyone could just buy this card and not worry about it.  However
column3: I recommend downloading MSI Afterburner and set it to automatically start with Windows
column4: which should automatically set up a fan profile that's more effective than the default Radeon profile.  However
column5: I think the general rule of thumb is that all components should be well under 95 degrees.

column1: I have attached images of the default Radeon fan curve (which probably doesn't run the fans fast enough for this card) versus the default MSI Afterburner fan curve (which probably runs the fans faster than necessary) versus my own custom fan curve.  Once again
column3: setting it to start automatically with Windows
column4: and either use the default Afterburner fan curve or set up your own as I have.

column1: Overall
column2: I would recommend this card with reservations
column3: for reasons that should be apparent from this review.  If you have a case with powerful cooling
column5: you should search for a card with a bigger heatsink and better memory cooling."^4^Feb 11

column1: lareynolds1987^/msi-mpg-z390-gaming-pro-carbon-ac-socket-lga1151-usb-3-1-gen-1-intel-motherboard/6319405?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^4^0^"This is a phenomenal motherboard

Much needs to be tested from thermals to overclocking ability ect. Lets see what intel will have instore for us in the near future."^5^May 27

column1: Scooter^/msi-mpg-z390-gaming-pro-carbon-ac-socket-lga1151-usb-3-1-gen-1-intel-motherboard/6319405?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"If you build your own systems you will have a typical experience using this board.  It has many bells and whistles I will most likely never use but for a bigger enthusiast they are good to have.  The LED lights are nice but I don't have a see through case so I don't mess with them.  I used the first NVMe slot and it has benched out typical of the performance expected.  CPU is an Intel 9700K so it has plenty of overhead for gaming and other tasks.  I will look into over clocking someday and other reviews do say it's a reliable platform but I have not tried yet.  It is still early on but I have had no problems with this build and as I have said it a typical motherboard install.  Only issue
column3: is the built in blue tooth.  Blue tooth is always odd when it comes to computers for me.  My headphones just keep dropping out and it takes a lengthy turning off and on and resetting computer then turning the system device on and off.  They are skull candy crusher wireless.  I also have the same issue with my LG bluetooth ear buds I use on my phone.  Software or hardware or device
column5: but what I do know is they work flawlessly every day all day with my Galaxy S10 and have never dropped once or had problems reconnecting.   If you get this I feel you will not be disappointed based on my experience so far."^5^Jan 4

column1: Deeje^/msi-mpg-z390-gaming-pro-carbon-ac-socket-lga1151-usb-3-1-gen-1-intel-motherboard/6319405?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"This was my first PC build and this was the motherboard I chose due to needing something with Wi-Fi and I wanted some RGB flair. The Mystic Lighting works with the fans in the case I purchased and I wanted two M.2 slots. It was a lot of little things that led me to this board. I also watched a youtube build by Jayz2Cents and that used a similar MSI board. I have to say for my first build
column2: everything was very easy. I didn't have a disc drive for the drivers so I had to use a thumb drive to add the network drivers but once I did that I was able to finish the rest with downloaded drivers and utilities. I did end up having to update the bios (which took 15 minutes tops) so that my MSI Dragon Center would properly register the temp of my CPU. I've been running it for a week with no issues and it appears to be solid and I'm more than happy with it. I called MSI support for a quick question and they were good to deal with and picked right up. So all is good from my stand point and I was torn on ASUS vs this MSI board and I am happy with my choice."^5^Apr 1

I used this mobo for my first build and did hours of research into which one would suit my needs best. Initially I was looking at the MSI Gaming Edge
column2: but decided to settle on the Pro Carbon AC for the design and wifi capability. Currently using it with a 9th Gen i5 and an RTX 2070 and couldn't be happier. Also the rgb looks great
column4: but still visible. Mystic Light also works perfectly to control the Corsair rgb elements in the case (cooler
column6: ram).

column1: Overall great board!"^5^Jun 28

surfahdude^/msi-mpg-z390-gaming-pro-carbon-ac-socket-lga1151-usb-3-1-gen-1-intel-motherboard/6319405?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^0^9^"The MSi Gaming Pro Carbon is a nice looking board with great features with one fatal flaw.  The board utilizes a 4+2 voltage regulator design which is insufficient for the latest high (95+) wattage AMD Ryzen CPUs.  Better boards have as much asa a 14+2 VRM deisgn (such as MSi's top boards).  MSi cut corners here and it shows when the board is pushed under load.
When running under load
column2: the voltage regulators will run a steady 95 degrees
column3: extremely high where some other brands run only 65-75 degrees C.  If you are using a 65 watt or lower Ryzen CPU
column4: this should not pose a problem.

column1: If you are looking to use a AMD 3900X or any CPU that draws 95 watts or more
column3: especially if you want to overclock the CPU.  The motherboard will cause the CPU to thermal throttle
column4: e.g. slow down until the temps go down."^2^Sep 26

JayDubsFL^/msi-super-ventus-oc-nvidia-geforce-rtx-2080-super-8gb-gddr6-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card-black-silver/6362414?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^6^"I ended up with this card because I bought a 2070 Super but decided I wanted a little more
column2: so I returned it and get this one as it was the only 2080 Super they had in the store. Here are my observations:

column1: Pluses:
1) Mild overclock from stock speeds.
2) Quiet fan.
3) Plays everything I can find at ULTRA settings without a hiccup.
4) Temperatures are well within acceptable ranges (this may be due to the fact that I have a huge case with great airflow).
Minuses (These don't even count - they're minor nitpicks):
1) It's $229 more than the cheapest 2070 Super.
2) No RGB lighting of any sort. This is not due to a problem with the card - that's how this card is.
3) My eyes can make out any visible difference in frame rates from the 2070 Super - how high of frame rates do you really need?
Ultimately I may end up with another 2070 or maybe even a 5700 XT - money really isn't the issue - it's the fact that above and beyond 60 FPS I can't tell the difference
column2: but these newest enthusiast cards are so high that it's straight up silly to pay for something you can't tell the difference on!

column1: YES - THIS IS AN AWESOME PRODUCT - but maybe too awesome (if that's possible?)"^5^Nov 19

Jordan^/msi-super-ventus-oc-nvidia-geforce-rtx-2080-super-8gb-gddr6-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card-black-silver/6362414?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^4^"The card performs great and I get great a stable FPS in most games however
column2: the MSI afterburner utility prevents any sort of OCing the scanner netted a max of 12 mhz... sad for a 2080 super. The temps are hotter than expected sitting at maxes around 84 c while gaming in very well ventilated case (MSI's 200-300$ case) with stock clocks. There's no option for increasing power limit at all
column3: potentially fixable with a vBios update however none have been released. For a 2080 super it is kind of disappointing
column4: my MSI 2080 (non super) Gaming X Trio was quieter
column6: and performed on average 5-10 fps higher. I'd only recommend this card if you absolutely want a 2080 super but don't want the FE version but want to get the lowest tiered 2080 super you can. For the nearly 800$ price tag after taxes this card doesn't perform as an 800$ card should (again this could potentially be fixed with a vBios update but at this point in time I'd say go with an FE
column7: or go with a slightly cheaper 2080 (non-super) and overclock as you will get near to the same or better performance while also saving 100$+."^4^Oct 19

column1: We built a system from Best Buy on Pre-Black Friday and Black Friday deals. Corsair Vengeance 2400 DDR memory (64Gig total)
column5: XLR8 overclocked NVIDIA GTX 1660 graphics card
column6: Corsair 3 RGB fan case and a 750 Watt EVGA power supply. Windows 10 Home OS. We run virtual box with Ubuntu Server to develop MMORPG video games in Unity Game Engine.

column1: Even with several internet browsers open
column2: and running both OS and the Virtual Box with the Unity Game engine
column3: we still average 80FPS in the 3D Game we are developing. We upgraded a couple older laptops we purchased at Best Buy years ago with new PNY 120 Gig SSD to use as Beta Server for testing. Lenovo Y-510 and HP Pavilion 17-e037cl laptops. The PNY SSD also come from Best Buy.

column1: Some people reviewing appear to be unhappy with the slight difference in the memory type
column2: but the differences are minimal. I mean on one card it would get between 79 FPS and 104 FPS and the other would be 78 FPS and 104 FPS. Sometimes on multiple tests
column3: going through the same area of a game
column4: the same exact card with the same memory would fluctuate and show that minimal difference.

column1: An engineer that knows card manufacturing and testing of memory types knows I am giving factual relevant data on this topic. Neither of the video cards utilize the full potential of the 3.0 PCI pipeline. Nit pickers complaining over 1 FPS and sometimes the slower memory might be faster by 1 FPS as the particles in the scene at that time might be slightly arraigned more efficiently by chance. It really is down to that factor. DDR 6 is newer than DDR 5 but some DDR5 performs about the same as some DDR6. Their holding mathematical figures and numbers for the GPU to process. It is millisecond differences that give a 1 FPS to 2 FPS difference sometimes. Most of the time they are the same resulting output.

We even used DDR4  2400 memory because the same results with those tests. The 3200 showed a 2 - 4 FPS difference than the 2400 memory. We could buy 64 Gig of 2400 instead of the 32 Gig of 3200 memory. More Memory means more Multitasking at the same time and having larger 22K sized 3D maps in a game with tutorial videos playing on Asset reviews. FPS is more about the graphics Processor and Pipeline structure and the efficiency design of the game. GPU Instancing
column3: Particle Emitter variations and Baked Mesh or Baked Lighting all play a larger roll in better FPS than DDR5 to DDR6 memory. The advert is a Typo
column4: but the cards perform the same."^5^Dec 25

column1: My first motherboard died after a week. I figured
column3: that happens. I exchanged the board for the same model.  Not too long after starting the system (not right away however)
column4: I started getting some sort of signal noise out of my speakers (which I ran with my previous build).  First I started looking for external influences
column5: but no matter what I did
column6: I was finding I could not get rid of the noise with the Asus board (unless I uninstalled the Realtek drivers or disable the onboard sound from the BIOS). I started reading on this issue and have found this problem looks to have existed for a couple generations now and it seems there are a lot of potential fixes. I've tried several with no luck.  Hours into this
column7: I've still not figured out the problem.  I've also been unable to get Sonic Studio and Sonic Radar installed
column8: which was a major factor in my buying decision. I'm going to keep working on the issues and will likely have to contact Asus.  If I get things resolved
column9: I'll try and make it a point of coming back and updating the post.

column1: So far
column2: I am quite unhappy with my purchase and have serious regrets of not going with the MSI Meg.  I have never had issues with my MSI boards. Sadly
column3: this is the second Asus board I've had challenges with (I had a z87 Asus ROG Impact ITX board with a Haswell processor that gave me some issue a few years back. I did love that motherboard after working through the issues).

column1: If you a tossed up between this board and the MSI Meg
column3: listen to the reviewers.  So far
column4: I regret that I did not listen to the reviews and going with the Meg as the preferred board.

column1: NazK^/asus-rog-maximus-xi-hero-wi-fi-socket-lga1151-usb-3-1-gen-1-intel-motherboard-with-led-lighting/6306415?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"The motherboard is nice. The BIOs and overclocking is good. The AI overclocking is interesting too.

The biggest gripe with this board is the top m.2 slot. IF YOU GET THIS BOARD - check these screws foremost!! The screws on the heatsink are incredibly difficult to unscrew. You have to be extremely careful to not strip the screws. They shouldve eased up on how hard they factory screwed them in. They shouldve also used flat heads or anything other than philips for these. I managed to unscrew them after a lot of effort and had to take out my graphics card just to gain more leverage and space to work... All for 2 tiny screws. Do better ASUS. The bottom m.2 slot was just fine tho
column2: as both shouldve been from the start.

column1: I also had some bent header pins out of the box
column2: which was unfortunate - but I managed to tweeze them into place and they worked in the end.

column1: Other than that
column2: its still a nice motherboard. Just make sure to check the top m.2 screws."^5^Oct 11

column1: Druuzil^/msi-mech-oc-amd-radeon-rx-5700-xt-8gb-gddr6-pci-express-4-0-graphics-card-black/6374966?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^8^7^"The problems with the 5700 series are well documented.  Wattman crashes.. black screens.. games crashing..
I tested the card in 2 systems
column2: both which are capable of handling significantly greater power loads.  The 1st uses an EVGA Supernova 1200w Platinum certified.  The 2nd has an 850w Corsair Gold certified supply.  I've been running dual 2080 Ti's in the 1st system and a 2060 Super in the 2nd.  Each 2080 Ti uses around 275-300w
column3: and the 2060 Super uses around 200.  The issue isn't power
column5: or an engineering flaw in the 5700 series in general.

column1: I returned the card after troubleshooting for around a week.  The image quality was superior to Nvidia
column2: and the HDR performance in certain games like AC Odyssey was also superior
column3: but the instability made it increasingly frustrating to use.

column1: I do not recommend this product until AMD gets their act together."^2^Nov 8

column1: I tried the newest update that rolled out in Jan and recommended drivers from both msi and amd however the card still needs more software updates to be even effective at 1080p at 144hz.

TechBuyer^/nvidia-geforce-rtx-2080-ti-founders-edition-11gb-gddr6-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card/6291646?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^127^8^"If you are asking yourself this question
column2: then the answer is probably no. That is my answer to the question 'Is it worth it' but I bought one anyways. Why? Because I could actually use the performance in the games and resolution I play at (4K)
column4: and I can afford to buy the card without too much concern other than grief from the wife.

column1: That said
column2: who should seriously consider buying this card

column1: 1) Anyone gaming at 4K and wants 60 FPS average or 3440x1440p and wants 100+ FPS on a G-Sync panel. This card is NOT going to wow you at lower resolutions like 1080p or 2560x1440p
column2: but at 4K the difference is 40% over 1080Ti which is a pretty big boost and often enough to put you over that elusive 4K/60 barrier where the 1080Ti was close but not quite there.

column1: 2) Anyone who doesn't mind dropping $1K on a video card
3) Anyone who already owned a 1080Ti and understands there's nothing else faster for the foreseeable future.
So why isn't it worth it? Most people will correctly point out RTX 2000 series is the smallest performance jump and one of the biggest price increases from one generation of Nvidia cards to another.
That said
column2: the price increase also contains a lot of forward looking and speculative features like Ray Tracing and Tensor cores for a new method of anti-aliasing that boasts of improved image quality at a fraction of the previous performance. If you buy this card
column3: you are basically funding the R&D and adoption rate for these features as an investment for the future.

column1: Not everyone is going to go for it
column3: but that's why this card is so expensive. Its massive
column4: its forward looking and its expensive to make.

column1: As for the performance
column2: I ran a few benchmarks and they are in-line with published benches
column6: all within 2-3 FPS of online benches. Overclocking is good
column7: about the same as Pascal 2080Ti. The new FE cooler is outstanding in terms of build quality
column8: but temps will touch into high 70s when overclocked so you need to turn the speed up. Overall its much quieter than the old blower fans but make sure you have good case airflow.

column1: I took one star off which had nothing to do with the performance of the card which is definitely impressive. 1/2 star off for the price hike from Nvidia to $1200 for a non-Titan card. Another 1/2 star off for a poorly executed launch where this card was announced on 8/20 and supposed to ship on 9/20 but was delayed 2x. BestBuy was also late
column3: it was an Nvidia supply issue and they still managed to only be 2 days late for me
column5: no RTX case badge from Nvidia this time
column6: they've had this with their GTX founders cards since the 900 series.

column1: Overall VERY pleased with this card despite the price
column4: I'm going to keep it anyways. I would not recommend it to a friend though
column5: because what kind of friend would recommend a $1200 graphics card to their friend???"^5^Oct 15

column1: Bill^/nvidia-geforce-rtx-2080-ti-founders-edition-11gb-gddr6-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card/6291646?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^7^2^"I had this video card for 3 days and then artifacts started appearing. 3D Mark tests failed. vrixiun^/nvidia-geforce-rtx-2080-ti-founders-edition-11gb-gddr6-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card/6291646?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^9^4^"First off
column2: this card is EXPENSIVE. The price to performance ratio is absolutely abysmal. This is probably the worst series revision in NVIDIA's history due to how little of a gain it is on the previous series vs the cost increase.

column1: That being said
column2: this is the first gaming card that can truly say it can run games at 4k/60fps. Sure
column3: you could get that on the 1080Ti or the regular 2080
column4: but you had to compromise quite a bit in the settings depending on the game. With the 2080Ti
column5: you can put the settings all the way up and get 4k at roughly 60fps.

column1: The two games I've tried so far (will update as I try more games):
Forza Horizon 4 never dips below 60fps with all settings maxed.

Assassin's Creed Odyssey averages 50-60 fps fully maxed with some dips into the 30s for a second when a lot of objects are being loaded. My assumption is this will improve to true 60fps with driver updates or even a game update since V-Sync is required in this game to eliminate screen tearing. It might even improve with a slight overclock
column2: which I'll try in a few weeks.

column1: Bottom line
column2: unless you are trying to push 4k/60fps on ultra or are trying to push UWQHD at 120+fps
column3: I would not recommend this card. The only reason I purchased this is because I've had a computer I built for the purpose of gaming on my 4k TV sitting waiting for this generation for the last half a year. I'm pleased with the performance so far

column1: Kurp^/nvidia-geforce-rtx-2080-ti-founders-edition-11gb-gddr6-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card/6291646?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^7^2^"Two things:

1. I am in a unique situation when compared to most buyers. I only had to pay $216 in the end after using a gift card Best Buy gave me (long story). That was the only reason why I decided to buy the card. I would not pay the full $1
column2: 298.99 after tax out of pocket as it is too high of a price for 'unknown' peak performance. I say unknown because we do not yet know how Ray Tracing or DLSS will do in the future.

column1: 2. This card performs very well for current games and is a huge upgrade from my GTX 1070 OC. It is absolutely PERFECT for current 4K 60fps gaming OR 1440p 144hz if you are trying to achieve 120+ fps at that resolution with settings maxed out.
Bottom line:
If you are willing to ride the promise that Nvidia has given us for Ray Tracing and DLSS AND you either make a stupid amount of money or you get into a unique situation like I was in
column2: then this card will be for you. Especially if you are looking to run everything at max 4K 60fps."^4^Oct 18

column1: New 20xx series founder editions looks a lot sleeker than previous generation. They got rid of the blower style and swap to a open air cooler. I have a congested case and this GPU runs in the low 70C which is not bad for the power it harness. When it comes to performance

column1: EtotheL^/nvidia-geforce-rtx-2080-ti-founders-edition-11gb-gddr6-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card/6291646?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"My games look great and run smoothly but there is one bit of a flaw... Mosfet buzz/'coil whine.' As soon as temps hit around 45-50 degrees celcius
column2: there is a strange whining/buzzing sound that occurs. Through much research I found that these are Mosfet coils and it is very common. I even contacted Nvidia support and was able to RMA the card
column3: but my new one has the same issue. A friend also bought the same card and his doesn't have the buzz
column4: but upon researching more and more
column5: I found that it's just the luck of the draw. In one post I read
column6: a guy RMA'd his 3 times and they all had the noise. The fans are also as noisy as a jet engine
column7: same on friend's card
column8: so if you want quiet
column9: go for water cooled. I now wish I would have water cooled but this card already costs so much and I couldn't spend more. It truly games beautifully but the noise is horrible. Research tons and make sure whatever you get doesn't have Mosfet buzz. I just wish I knew that before buying this card. Would have been 5 stars if it wasn't so noisy."^4^May 21

column1: Rich^/nvidia-geforce-rtx-2080-ti-founders-edition-11gb-gddr6-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card/6291646?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"Hands down the best card on the market for gaming in spring 2019."^5^Mar 8

Teambellyflop^/nvidia-geforce-rtx-2080-ti-founders-edition-11gb-gddr6-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card/6291646?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^11^10^"I got lucky and recived a card that is not currently defective. Easy installation and boot up once in the game nividia experience auto set the graphic configurations. Ultra everything no problem at 1080 144hz runs most games at 170 plus to max game settings. But it auto scaled resolution to 200% on everything which without realizing it was dipping fps to 120 plus but big spike dips. Still super good for 2 k 144hz but 4k is still not up to par you'll still be getting roughly 60 to 75fps on ultra. Mine luckly stays cool and quite for a founders card. At 144hz ultra 270 fps highest it hits is 81 C or 177F with 4 stock case fans on there own learning curve (smart case h700i)
Ok now the features ray tracing and dlss. Almost none existent.
Battlefield just launched rtx that's it. And it's not super impressive. Youll roughly get 50 to 70 fps at 1440p at 1080 you'll roughly get 60 to 80fps.
Plus the power house pc you need to run it tho if your spending 1200 on a graphics card it better be up there anyways.
Overall I enjoy it for 2k ultra no rtx. Rtx is at its early stages and without games to see the performance of it and dlss it's not worth the 1200 price tag.

Also with the newer 7nm in the talks I have a feeling this will be around for a year or two before the next card comes out and assuming those rumors hold it will be better plus you have time to see implementation.
They also announced they stopped production of the 1080ti. So if your going to get a new card I'd get a 1080ti soon."^3^Nov 16

Pete^/nvidia-geforce-rtx-2080-ti-founders-edition-11gb-gddr6-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card/6291646?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^10^9^"I made a 200 mile round trip to pick up this card as BB wouldn't ship it at that time.
