Is it worth the price? No.
As mentioned in other reviews
column2: this card is for you ONLY if you MUST have the best performing card on the market AND paying way more for a little bit better makes sense to you. Any other combination of if's and the answer is no.

column1: Pros:
- While the RTX generation yielded several triple+ slot cards
column3: this 2080ti card takes only two slots. This card is also actually shorter than two of the three 1080s I own (one of them was a 'mini').

column1: - It is fairly quiet. It's only marginally louder than my previous 1080s (non-ti)
- Fastest card there is.
Cons:
- Price. An RTX 2080 or even a GTX 1080ti will give you a much better bang for your buck. You can get a 2080 for ~33% less and it'll likely only be about ~15% slower.
- RTX what? A month after release there are literally NO games that support it.
- It does take a bit more power than the previous generation
column2: which translates to noticeably more heat coming from under my desk."^3^Oct 20

column1: EternalEngine^/nvidia-geforce-rtx-2080-ti-founders-edition-11gb-gddr6-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card/6291646?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^70^69^"OK! Let's get this out of the way: There is *nothing* wrong with the build quality of the GPU itself. It's a standard Nvidia Founder's Edition (FE) GPU
column2: which is also available directly from their website. Historically
column3: all FE GPUs are excellent in terms of performance and reliability. You really can't go wrong with any of them
column7: etc.

column1: If you want the BEST of the BEST and have money to burn
column2: this is the GPU for you. Period. It will run 4K gaming setups while it's cooking dinner for the kids AND taking the wife out shopping. Nvidia has taken their Turing GPU architecture and combined it with the updated GDDR6 VRAM to establish an incredibly quick and powerful video card
column3: not to mention the addition of ray tracing units
column4: which are dedicated to real-time ray tracing and performance enhancement. So
column5: again! If you absolutely need the best video card on the market
column6: this is going to be your solution.

column1: Now
column2: why did I give it only 3 stars? Simple:

column1: ***This GPU is not worth the money in any way
column3: or form for the current generation of video games available.***

column1: Previously
column2: Nvidia would release their flagship X80 Ti GPU (780 Ti
column6: with each generation being much more powerful than the previous
column7: giving up to a 40% increase in performance between generations. The average cost of a flagship model upon release has been around $750-800USD
column8: unless you purchased a more expensive model with additional bells and whistles
column9: such as enclosed liquid cooling
column11: etc. The last iteration of this was the powerful 1080 Ti
column12: which was approximately $700-750USD for a founder's edition version.

column1: What performance difference is there between a 1080 Ti and a 2080 Ti in 99% of all real-world testing?
About 28%.
$1200USD versus $699USD - That's about a 60% cost hike to obtain that 28% performance gain. For most gamers it's simply not worth the cost.
The 1080 Ti will still play almost any triple-A title at 60FPS without a sweat
column2: 4K included. Base 1080 GTX video cards are going on sale in many places for under $450USD
column3: which is still a very powerful GPU capable of playing most games at ultra settings at the point in time
column4: and is a much better deal for end user.

column1: CONCLUSION:
If you need the best and have too much money in your wallet
column2: this is your GPU. In all other cases
column3: I recommend purchasing the previous generation
column4: as the price versus performance increase is not reasonable at this point in time."^3^Oct 5

I originally thought that the RTX 2080 non TI would be enough to get the max 60 FPS that is possible for the TV but it just didn't quite cut it.

I guess you could say I got lucky because the 2080 that I purchased continuously overheated no matter how I configured the fans in the case. This made me look into exchanging it for a new one and the closest Best Buy to me had the RTX 2080 TI in stock and not the non TI version at the time. I decided to bite the bullet and upgrade it. Now I get mostly 60 FPS on Assassins Creed Odyssey at ultra settings. I haven't tried any other games yet.

My biggest worry is that if the non TI version struggled without Ray Tracing then when it actually becomes available would it really be worth it if I had to adjust graphics settings or drop to 1440p or 1080p to use it. It could be that the Ray Tracing may drop the FPS on the TI as well but there is a better chance for it to stay closer to 60 FPS.
I don't regret buying the RTX 2080 TI
column2: I only knock off a star due to the price. It is expensive but NVIDIA knows that they have the best card out right now and are taking full advantage of it."^4^Oct 15

column2: 'Oh the new GPU?' Or the screeches of the money-less about how it's 'too much' for their wallets. It's not only the first iteration of a new GPU series with brand new gen of GDDR Mem and entirely new VRM layout; it's redesigned completely.

column1: While it's not worth the price if you're going to play < 2K resolution it's a powerhouse at anything 4K Max related. It can eat HDR like it's nothing and push frame-rates I never thought possible at extreme settings.
Since my boyfriend has a 8700K machine with 2 1080Ti's I'll be putting this together into a different build with a 9900K once those are shipped at a normal price.
Love it or hate it
column2: you can't stop it from being an absolute unit of a graphics card."^5^Oct 11

column1: Juny^/nvidia-geforce-rtx-2080-ti-founders-edition-11gb-gddr6-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card/6291646?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^17^"Didnt had a chance to test :( the one i bought was lost"^1^Jul 26

razerflower^/nvidia-geforce-rtx-2080-ti-founders-edition-11gb-gddr6-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card/6291646?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^17^81^"Nvidia has already introduced a powerful video card RTX 2080 which will be more than enough for 1080p
RTX 2080Ti is even more powerful video booster which is intended for 4k"^5^Oct 1
Zapix^/msi-geforce-rtx-2080-ti-gaming-x-trio-11gb-gddr6-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card/6290652?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^34^0^"For starters
column2: this card is a size monster. At just under 13 inches long
column6: making it look almost like a 24pin motherboard cable. expect this to take up your case. It fits nicely in my Corsair 1000D.

column1: Performance wise
column2: this is a single card ready to handle 4K/60 with high/ultra settings

column1: For reference to what I'm running this on...
Asus Rampage VI Extreme
i9 7900X (no overclocking)
64GB 3200MHz C16 DDR4 RAM
MSI RTX 2080 Ti Gaming X Trio (no additional overclocking)
- Final Fantasy XV ran at 4K/60fps with minimal drops on the highest settings with only AA
column3: and ShadowLibs disabled. Enabling VXAO and ShadowLibs took it down into the 45 to 55fps range with drops to 30fps in battles
column4: which is still playable if you're not bothered by less than 60fps performance. Running the benchmark
column6: just over 5% higher than the standard RTX 2080 Ti listed.

column1: - Shadow of the Tomb Raider on ultra settings with HDR and AA disabled ran an average of 61fps at 4K/HDR
column2: with a low of 52fps and a high of 95fps.

column1: - Because why not
column2: I ran Sleeping Dogs (Definitive Edition) on ultra (extreme) settings. With AA on extreme
column3: the game ran an average of 50fps
column5: and highs in the low 60s. Turning AA down to normal
column6: the average went up to 87fps with a low of 59.

column1: - And lastly
column2: I threw a fan favorite at it... Batman: Arkham Knight. Can you taste the sarcasm? At 4K on ultra settings with only AA disabled
column3: Arkham Knight ran a lovely average of 80fps with a high of 108. The lowest minimum I saw was 58fps despite the screenshot showing 33. This benchmark chokes at the very start coming out of the loading screen.

column1: If you're using anything less than 4K/60
column2: this card will handle whatever you throw at it. Tested several games on my Asus 34' ultrawide @ 3440x1440 with AA turned up

column1: The card idled or of the box around 45C
column2: so maybe you've heard complaints about heat. Fans don't spin up until these cards start to get hot
column3: so I installed MSI Afterburner to setup a custom fan profile. Idles now around 30C. In my testing
column4: I never saw temps go much higher than 65C.

column1: According to MSI Afterburner
column2: I was reaching a boost clock of 1995.

column1: Note that the RTX GEFORCE on the side of the card doesn't have LED lighting and makes it look a bit broken with the rest of the RGB around it.
Waiting on a second one to enable NVLink
column3: I'm thinking maybe I should cancel it or stick it in my X99 system that has 2 Asus 1080 cards.

column1: The price is high
column2: but the results speak for themselves.

column1: I'm coming from 1080 SLI which handled my 3440x1440 gaming
column3: sometimes without. The RTX 2080 Ti feels like a perfect single card solution for this resolution. 4k/60 will require some settings being turned off

column1: If you're looking for 3440x1440 or 4k gaming
column2: this card is for you. If you're gaming on anything less
column3: this will obliterate everything you throw at it with the highest frame rates."^5^Oct 25

column1: Ariel^/msi-geforce-rtx-2080-ti-gaming-x-trio-11gb-gddr6-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card/6290652?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^10^1^"Excellent results so far when compared to my old 1080 FE Card. In Shadow of War
column2: Far Cry 5 and Total War Warhammer 2 I'm seen double the FPS at 4k resolution in Ultra Settings. AC Origins and GTA 5 get well over 60 FPS now in 4K with Very High settings on. Also this is a very large video card
column3: I had to remove a HD bay to get it to fit in my Corsair PC case."^5^Oct 5

column1: bradwhite87^/msi-geforce-rtx-2080-ti-gaming-x-trio-11gb-gddr6-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card/6290652?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^7^0^"This card right out of the box offered no problems. I was impressed by its design and looks as I Installed it into my new gaming pc. This time I around I told my self I deserved the best! When the card was working fine it was more than a match for my Acer X34
column2: driving the monitor to heights my old 980 Ti only dreamed of. But then everything came crashing down not more than 2 days after install. After one reboot of the PC after a Battlefield 5 crash
column3: nothing to do with the card
column4: I see nothing but purple 'space Invader' like artifacts all over my screen. I am a pretty technical guy with decent googling skills but all attempts to fix the issue have ended in failure. I am not one to easily RMA a product but after a week of attempts I have finally given up. Just sucks having to go through the whole process. I would hold off on these cards till they become a bit more reliable. Now I am afraid I have backed a bad horse and even when I get my replacement all I can think about is when will it happen again. Not a fun feeling when you put a 1400 dollar car in a PC that will be my main gaming workhorse for beyond the 3 years of the factory warranty. I would give this card 5 stars for performance but my rating will have to be 1 start because I was always taught growing up
column5: you are only as strong as your weakest link and in this case its reliability."^1^Jan 26

column1: Beradon^/msi-geforce-rtx-2080-ti-gaming-x-trio-11gb-gddr6-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card/6290652?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^6^0^"Recently I upgraded to the MSI Geforce RTX 2080 TI Gaming X Trio from my Geforce 1080 FE from a few years ago and I have to say this was well worth the upgrade.
I've been driving my 4k screen from my GTX 1080 for a few years and while it 'could' do it
column2: it wasn't 'great' at it.  Most games at 4k would run well even at high settings
column3: but I was missing the 'ultra' settings that I really wanted.  This card can do 4k at ultra (at least in all of the games I've tried so far).

column1: Anyways
column2: to start.  The packaging is relatively average
column5: but there's nothing special about the packaging.  For such a high end card marketing to a premium audience it could have had a bit 'more' to the packaging to make it feel like a premium experience.  One thing they did that I really did not like is the fact there are 2 separate clear film plastic stickers stuck to and around the fans
column6: that if you got overexcited in installing your new card you could miss
column7: in which case you've effectively taped one of the fans stationary.  This is poor packaging.  Hearkens to the screen-protector-that-wasn't-a-screen-protector for the Galaxy Fold
column8: but in this case you DO want to remove these to ensure your fans rotate freely.

column1: The first thing you'll notice is the card is HUGE.  The specs mark it as 327mm which puts it just shy of 13 inches long.  This is long.  Very Long.  My GTX 1080 looked like a baby next to it.  This is important to note because I was installing this into my Antec Twelve Hundred full tower proved to be a challenge and I am actually having to upgrade my case to fit it fully
column2: with the card in place and functioning
column3: one of the drive bay racks in the tower will not slide fully into place.  So be aware
column4: you need a case that can handle this card.

column1: Second
column3: you'll find that the card has 2x8 pin power connections and 1x6 pin power connection.  I've never installed a card that requires so much power
column4: and on top of that I believe most of the 2080 TI cards only have 2x8 pin power connections
column5: so this card has the capability to draw a SIGNIFICANT amount more power than most 2080 TIs.  This also means you need to be sure your power supply will support all of those connections.  It DOES come with one adapter to go from 6 pin to 8 pin if needed
column6: but suffice to say you'll still need a total of 3 connections.  It also comes with a metal support bar.

column1: In terms of performance
column3: this card screams.  In running Assassin's Creed Odyssey there are zero hiccups and it runs at a full 60 fps at all times in 4k on ultra settings.  Clearly in games like Overwatch it barely even breathes hard.

column1: On the note of breathing
column2: you will notice one important thing about this card.  The fans have a function where they TURN OFF when they are not needed.  So if you're just in Windows and not doing anything graphic intensive
column3: do not be surprised to see the fans not turning.  This is a feature.

column1: The card has multiple long bright RGB strips along the side and front which default to a cycling rainbow effect.  You can manage this from MSI's RGB Software (Mystic Light).
Overall the card is pretty incredible and near the top end of the market (aside from the obscenely expensive RTX Titan
column2: not that this card isn't expensive enough).

column1: If you're in the market for a top end card and have the budget (and space) to install it
Pros:
Fast
RGB lighting (if you're in to that sort of thing)
Lots of cooling
Cons:
Huge
column3: it will not even fit in some full tower cases

column1: Needs TONS of power
column2: 2x8 pin and 1x6pin is more than any other card in the class"^5^Jul 8

column1: Naruto367^/msi-geforce-rtx-2080-ti-gaming-x-trio-11gb-gddr6-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card/6290652?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^7^2^"Unit is huge but has a big bang
column2: super fast and raised all my 4K games FPS with max settings. Runs much cooler with your own fan profile. Idles at 30c with 5% fan speed and hits 63 C running at max. All benchmarks point to this as being one of the fastest 2080 Ti out and is equivalent if not quieter to the ASUS ROG STRIX GEFORCE RTX 2080TI OC. Both cards are the best but the MSI wins out IMO. I have a second one on order for a SLI set up."^5^Oct 16

column1: David^/msi-geforce-rtx-2080-ti-gaming-x-trio-11gb-gddr6-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card/6290652?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^4^0^"This graphics card handles anything that I throw at it. I can run any game at ultra settings without skipping a beat. Modern warfare
column3: Witcher 3 etc. graphics card does run a little hot while gaming. On modern warfare Im running at 85c and was a little concerned about the heat but Ive played on my desktop for 9+ hours and consistently without issues. Has the ability to overclock but I wouldnt with out a water block/ gpu cooler. you can download the msi after burner app which allow you to manually adjust the fan curve but even with all 3 fans spinning  at 100%Im only able to get down to 83C. The card itself comes with a support bracket and a disc with some utility app and drivers. Very satisfied with my gpu . I cant wait to see the future games with ray tracing"^5^Dec 18

column1: JiYong^/msi-geforce-rtx-2080-ti-gaming-x-trio-11gb-gddr6-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card/6290652?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^0^"Checks everything off the box and then some. Great card and RGB!"^5^Dec 14
NvidiaDude^/msi-geforce-rtx-2080-ti-gaming-x-trio-11gb-gddr6-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card/6290652?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^0^"This is definitely enthusiast level power
column2: nothing I can throw at this card even makes it break a sweat.  Raw performance and overclocking potential is the real draw here
column3: and this beast delivers on all fronts

column1: This is the largest card I've ever seen.  Once I pulled this thing out of the box
column2: I was aghast at how truly massive it is
column3: it DWARFS my FE 1080ti.  I've got a Corsair Crystal 680X case (the thing is as big as a refrigerator) but I only have less than an inch of space between the back of the card and the front case fans.  Definitely take realistic in-case measurements before going out and picking up one of these porkers.

column1: This thing is also HEAVY.  My Z370-P motherboard did sag with the sheer mass of this card
column2: the included bracket is necessary unless your motherboard is seriously reinforced at the slot.  The bracket is a bit unsightly unfortunately
column3: might not blend well depending on your RGB/case color scheme
column4: which is a shame as the card itself is very aesthetically pleasing.

column1: One thing that does seem unusual is the lighting on the card.  The RGB is great
column2: but while the MSI logo is lit up on the side of the card
column3: the actual RTX Series logo is just a decal.

column1: Overall
column2: if you've got the money and the desire for top tier performance

column1: Oh
column2: and it does eat up 3 slots
column3: so if you plan on SLI

column1: vang2k^/corsair-ml-series-120mm-case-cooling-fan-white/5845209?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^0^"Was planning to purchase the Thermaltake riing 120mm fan white led version vs this fan. column1: Kurt^/corsair-carbide-series-atx-mid-tower-case-black/6323389?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"My only complaint about this case is that literally
column2: the minute I finally put the removable sides back onto the case
column3: the RGB light in the top fan stopped working.  I have check the cabling and cannot find any disconnect between the fans and the motherboard.  The bottom two RGBs work great.

column1: It's kindof ironic
column2: I did not really want RGB lights
column3: but bought the case at the last minute to assemble a PC before Christmas.  After 11 years between builds
column4: there was a learning curve.  Asus VIBE controls the LEDS and the keyboard lights.  The case is solid and quality built.  I just can't give it five stars with an LED going out within a couple of weeks of purchasing the case.

column1: If anyone from Corsair would like to comment

column3: because I'm not taking the whole machine apart to get the case repaired."^4^Feb 24

column1: Mayur^/corsair-carbide-series-atx-mid-tower-case-black/6323389?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^0^1^"This case advertisement was misleading in my opinion. Bought this case thinking that it comes with RGB fans. But when I installed my motherboard and other components
column2: I found out that these RGB fans require special type of motherboard with ARGB header on them only from Asus
column3: MSI and Gigabyte brands. My motherboard does not have such headers. Tried looking everywhere for some type of adapters to make things work but was totally unsuccessful. Corsair also sell RGB LED Fan hub
column5: and RGB Commander Pro. None of them worked either. They all require different type of 4-pin connectors. These fans have different types of connectors to hook them directly onto the motherboard. I can't return this case anymore
column6: otherwise I would have bought another one which is iCue compatible. Totally unhappy with this purchase."^1^Mar 14

column1: Jordan^/corsair-carbide-series-atx-mid-tower-case-black/6323389?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^5^"I have had this case for some time
column2: it is not at all AIO friendly
column3: it will not accommodate any size aio bigger than 120mm/140mm. I have a 2080 gaming x trio and there's less than a finger width between the front fans and the gpu. If you have a high end Mobo and a decent sized gpu good luck fitting any AIO. I have mine mounted at the top and you cannot access anything at the top of the motherboard without removing the entire water cooler and radiator. This case would be good for anyone with a small gpu and an air cooled cpu. If you want to build a decent water cooled system with a gpu that has enough fans to keep cool
column4: I highly suggest a different chassis/case. Build quality is good however when the specs state it will fit an aio cooler it is recommended to actually fit them with the average components installed instead of saying it will fit them in only the perfect specific conditions."^2^Sep 29

column1: Ellis971^/pny-nvidia-geforce-gt-710-verto-2gb-ddr3-pci-express-2-0-graphics-card-black/5092306?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^7^1^"Constantly crashes the system. Installed drivers still had issues"^2^Jul 23

mkcar1^/pny-nvidia-geforce-gt-710-verto-2gb-ddr3-pci-express-2-0-graphics-card-black/5092306?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^6^1^"I had built a new desktop and moved my main GPU to it so I needed something for my 'old' desktop since the motherboard connections are not operable. This fit the bill exactly as I wanted something low profile and relatively cheap. I pretty much stick with NVIDIA as I master DVDs and its CUDA cores seems to provide much better processing.
The card specs;
PCI-Express 2.0 x8
up to 3840  2160 (Digital) resolution but I have only used 1080P.
Support for three concurrent displays:
HDMI
Dual-link DVI-D
VGA
I only tried 2 (HDMI and DVI-D) which it processed fine.
I dont do any gaming so cant speak to how it processes those.
But if you you are looking for a nice quiet entry level GPU that will make your movies or work look great - this it it!"^5^Jul 22

rksj0000^/pny-nvidia-geforce-gt-710-verto-2gb-ddr3-pci-express-2-0-graphics-card-black/5092306?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^6^1^"The GT 710 is a basic GPU. You aren't going to be pumping out 60 FPS playing the newest games
column2: but that is okay. That is not the purpose of this graphics card.

column1: The purpose of this graphics card is to serve as a basic upgrade to an aging system or as a graphics solution for a modern system that will not benefit from a GPU. The GT 710 is actually weaker than the onboard graphics of most mainstream chips now.

I purchased it for an 8 year old desktop computer that has been handed down to my 5 year old daughter. Some of the low powered games she likes to play required a newer version of DirectX than what the old Dell's original hardware supported. In steps the GT 710. Everything works now!"^5^Mar 9

column1: DPTNash^/pny-nvidia-geforce-gt-710-verto-2gb-ddr3-pci-express-2-0-graphics-card-black/5092306?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^1^"Bought two on Black Friday for use on two 9 Y.O. HP Pavilion a6838f desktop units with 8GB ram running Windows 10 Pro (8GB is maximum allowable on that motherboard); was expecting to free up Shared Memory
column2: hoping to transfer video memory demand to 2GB on card

column1: Cards and software installed on both PCs by our tech. On one PC
column3: running 2 monitors (Word + Outlook) for increased worker productivity

column1: However
column3: it sucked up additional 3.9GB of 8GB shared system memory with same settings as first PC (total 5.9GB memory for video)
column4: slowing system response considerably while running QuickBooks
column6: sometimes freezing completely.

column1: Found that system BIOS on both HP motherboards did NOT allow reconfiguration of Shared Memory (i.e. restricting new video card on second PC to just 0.5GB or less of Shared Memory). No work-around other than pulling video card and reinstalling OEM drivers for Intel onboard vid chips. Ah
So be sure FIRST that your BIOS on motherboard is indeed reconfigurable; read that motherboards from 2014 & newer should work without issue.
Recently solved memory issue on second PC via ReadyBoost by getting a USB 3.0 card and adding 32GB USB 3.0 thumbdrive; fast system response now
column3: but takes as a few extra moments on PC shutdown for extra memory to finish writing to hard drive. Milking our 2009-vintage business Pavilions for all their worth - ha!"^3^Jan 17

column1: jerryelp^/pny-nvidia-geforce-gt-710-verto-2gb-ddr3-pci-express-2-0-graphics-card-black/5092306?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"I installed it on s SFF pc that I am using as a HTPC for my home theater needs because it can handle true 4K resolutions and so far its doing a great job. It does not hinder a 4K monitor on any settings but I expect gamers may find it too slow. My sole purpose was a usable 4K setup for viewing 4k video and it has been running non-stop for about a month without a hitch."^4^Jul 20

column2: on good graphics settings. It will struggle if you enjoy gaming while streaming video

column7: which prevented photo editing apps from working properly)
column8: so I needed a cheap upgrade to insert into a PCI slot. While I have had to sacrifice the USB 3 card I got
column9: that is fine. This is because I was banking on removing the stock NVIDIA card. Well
column10: it seems I cannot do this because it causes Windows to crash. I have not had the time to figure this out
column11: I am just glad I can use my photo editing applications like Adobe and Luminar. I don't do games
column12: so I have no clue how that works. But
column13: for a cheap update to an older computer for basic use this works perfectly fine for me."^4^Oct 5

column1: Graystone55^/lg-super-multi-24x-internal-dvdrw-cd-rw-drive-black/2691169?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^23^2^"I have mixed feelings about this purchase.
1st
column2: the drive received is not a GH24LS70 but rather a GH24NS90. I sure wish BB would stop switching products out without changing their ad descriptions!

column1: The picture in the ad is not of either of these drives. It shows the Lightscribe logo and the LG and the SuperMulti logos. The actual drive has only the LG and SuperMulti logos as well as a M-Disc logo.

I bought this drive because the picture indicated it was Lightscribe certified. Neither the drive advertised nor the one provided support Lightscribe. Without the Lightscribe capability it is not worth $40 as many drives without this feature sell for $10-15 cheaper.

The software packaged with it is Cyberlinks Suite. Cyberlink stuff is pretty bad at interfering with other things in the PC and advertising you to death if you are not careful how you answer setup questions. I wish they would have provided the bundled versions of Roxio or Nero instead of Cyberlink. That might have made the extra cost for this drive a little more worth it.
With this drive is a single M-Disc and it is M-Disk certified. There's no included information on what this is. After several internet searches
column2: it looks like it's just a more reliable type of DVD. But to use these you have to buy M-Discs which are about $3 each! Also you can't label these disks like you would a standard DVD. Ouch! Another nearly useless included feature that few people are likely to use.

column1: The speed of the drive is good at both burning and reading DVDs. It has lots of formats of discs it supports writing/reading to. I hate the Cyberlink Software Suite and am back to using an older version of Roxio.
While I'm a bit disappointed I did not get a Lightscribe drive like all my other drives have been
column2: it is useful as a simple no-frills rewriter. I ended up putting this newer drive into an older PC because my older drive did do Lightscribe.

column1: In summation
column2: if you are just looking to read or burn DVDs and CDs this drive will do it fine.

column1: I don't know about the quality as I haven't had it but for a few days. But the last LG rewriter I had lasted me for 3 years and is still going strong. I burned about 2 discs a week with the last one. So hopefully this one will be as reliable too.

I chose to say yes to the recommend to friend box although I have my reservations due to the issues stated here. I was told by a BB in-store person after the install that if I installed the drive I had bought it. They won't take it back since it was installed and used once."^3^May 24

column1: SOLUTION FOR WINDOWS 10 PROBLEM:
Windows 10 gave me a bit of trouble (and apparently a lot of others when googling for the solution)
column2: but just hit 'Windows + R' type in 'devmgmt.msc' and hit the enter key. Expand 'IDE ATA/ATAPI controllers' and right click every entry and select uninstall. After that
column3: reboot Windows 10. *DO NOT REBOOT UNTIL EVERY ENTRY HAS BEEN DELETED!!!*

column1: This should fix the problem."^4^Jan 30

column1: RedMage^/canakit-raspberry-pi-4-2gb-starter-kit-clear-case/6365734?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^4^0^"Getting a Raspberry pi 4 was tough for a while
column2: but being able to get one at a local retailer is a huge boon. Simply because the price is no different from the prices on CanaKit's own website

column1: The kit itself is nice
column2: the case is a huge step up from their Case for the Pi3 model b/b+. It still has the notch to hold a camera board
column3: both upright behind the usb/ethernet ports
column4: and on the lid behind the raspberry logo
column5: but gone is the plastic layer that covered most of the board making it possible to use a much larger variety of accessories within the case from different cooling solutions and HATs (hardware on top). Additionally there is now a clip in place on the lid to mount a cooling fan.

column1: The kit comes with everything you need to get started
column2: though only just. The pi itself
column6: micro to full size HDMI cable
column7: and a micro sd card with noobs software preinstalled so you can get Raspian OS up and running minutes after opening it up and assembling it all. You of course will still need your own screen
column8: keyboard
column9: and mouse.

column1: A major recommendation though would be to get your hands on a fan for the case early on
column2: the little heat sink does help with the temps a little but with a fan you can run it more reliably at the cost of a little power and noise. My tests on 2 separate boards get idle temps in the high 60's low 70's and quickly jump up to the 80's when actually doing anything without a fan
column3: and idles at 38/40 degrees with fan and only ever climbs to around 55/60 in regular use. [synthetic benchmarks can push the little machine much harder and still reach temps in the 80s with a small fan and heat sinks
column4: but that's not a true test of what to expect.

column1: CanaKit does offer kits that come with a fan as well through their website though it would have been nice if they were the ones best buy were carrying. It's not a deal breaker though.
Some things to take note of:
1. The Raspberry Pi 4B can output on up to 2 4k screens from its dual micro hdmi ports
column2: it can run one by itself at 60fps

column1: 2. Despite being able to run 2 4k displays in use
column2: it is not able to actually stream 4k content reliably. At least not as of my writing of this review. As software catches up to the new hardware it may be more capable down the line.

column1: 3. Micro HDMI ports are fragile
column2: take care when plugging and unplugging your cable or your going to have a bad day.

column1: 4. The internet is your friend
column3: and google to the fullest extend of your abilities and you will almost always be able to find someone who is having or has had the same problems your having with it.

column1: With all that in mind however
column2: if your just starting out or even if you've used raspberry pis in the past
column3: its a good kit to pick up since it has all the important components you need to get started on a new project
column4: and you save a little money compared to picking up power supplies and cases and cables separately."^4^Oct 4

kspgamer^/amd-ryzen-9-3900x-12-core-3-8-ghz-socket-am4-desktop-processor/6356274?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^8^0^"This CPU is a total overkill for almost any workload. I can have basically every piece of productivity software that I have running at once
column2: with a browser open and 100+ tabs with a video playing and still play a AAA game with very little performance loss. So if you are just a gamer then this CPU is a bit excessive. A Ryzen 7 X3800 would probably be a better choice
column3: but if you game and run heavy multithreaded workloads like 3d modeling / CAD
column5: or rendering then this CPU is awesome. It can run games incredibly well while still crushing heavy multithreaded workloads.

column1: With this CPU I can work on models with way more active points in Zbrush. My old CPU (Intel i5-4690K OCd to 4.4 Ghz) would start stuttering around 2-4 million active points
column2: while this CPU can handle around 20 million. It is very nice to be able to work on a model at that detail level without having to use Zbrushs Geometry HD feature.

column1: Another big advantage of having this many cores is that even while a heavy multithreaded workload is running there is usually still enough CPU left for normal computer functionality. When I was stress testing this CPU I ran Prime95 then I forgot to stop it. I went on browsing online and watching a video without noticing that anything was wrong until I started to run another benchmark. I really noticed this when I rebuilt the lightmapping in Unity the other day and I could still use my computer normally
column2: with my old CPU my PC would be barely function during this process. Admittedly most applications that are really multithreaded allow you to set how many threads you want them to use
column3: but with this may cores you will probably never even have to think about it.

column1: As many other people are reporting mine does not seem to turbo up to 4.6 GHz
column2: the most that I have seen on my monitoring software Is around 4.54 GHz
column3: but this CPU is so powerful that I do not really care. Plus I get a solid 4.15-4.2 Ghz clock on all core loads
column4: which is really good considering the rated base clock is 3.8 Ghz. I get cinebench R20 scores that average around 7350
column5: my old CPU just got 1580. Idle temps are around 40C and full load temps are about 70C in a good air cooled case. I am using an ASUS TUF 570 motherboard (which I highly recommend) and 32 GB of 3600 MHz ram."^5^Oct 6

surfahdude^/amd-ryzen-9-3900x-12-core-3-8-ghz-socket-am4-desktop-processor/6356274?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^9^3^"There has been a lot of news about the 3900X.  I can attest to the fact that the CPU is blazingly fast.  When using applications
column2: the CPU kills Intel's i9 9900K.  But all is not perfect.

column1: While rated for as much as 4.6 GHz
column2: 90% of users have polled that the CPU never reaches that speed.  My sample maxes out at 4.45 GHz.  Also note that AMD rates the CPU speed only at one core
column3: i.e. all the other cores may not reach advertised speeds.  So while my CPU peaked at 4.45 GHz
column4: most of the cores only averaged 4.35 GHz.

column1: Another issue is that the CPU runs hot
column3: even a 280mm water cooler.  Previous CPUs would run as high as 80-85 degrees so the AMD is a lot hotter.  This is due to the smaller 7nm die and high clock speed.  It is constantly running at 1.485 volts
column4: even at idle.  This high voltage is not conducive for long life.

column1: On the other hand
column2: this CPU kills the Intels when running applications that are multi-core friendly since this CPU has 12 cores and Intel's i9 9900K only has eight.  I use the AMD for rendering videos
column4: the same video will take about 60-75 minutes on the fastest Intel CPU
column5: the i9 9900K.  The speed difference is a lot higher when compared to Intel's i7 9700K which has eight cores but no hyper-threading (the AMD has 24).

column1: Playing games
column2: the AMD is a tad slower than the Intel
column3: because games run better at higher CPU speeds and are not core dependent
column4: but the differences are usually about 3-7%
column5: negligible when you are looking at 120-150 fps with a good GPU.

column1: Be also aware that the X570 motherboards designs are all over the place.  You have to get a board that has a well designed voltage regulator layout.  Some boards have only a 4+2 design which means the VRMs hit 125 degrees.  The CPU will throttle back its speed until the VRMs cool down and repeats this cycle.  Better boards have as much as a 14+2 VRM design which keeps the VRM temps to about 60-70 degrees."^4^Sep 26

Initially had an issue with the network driver (blue screen booting windows) which required me to reinstall my old processor and disable it in device manager. column1: Matt^/amd-ryzen-9-3900x-12-core-3-8-ghz-socket-am4-desktop-processor/6356274?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^5^0^"Wow. Just. Wow.

TooMuchFreeTime^/amd-ryzen-9-3900x-12-core-3-8-ghz-socket-am4-desktop-processor/6356274?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^5^0^"In short this is an excellent work horse and if you're looking for work and gaming it's a champ.
Okay this going to get more technical as I go deeper but I'll try to put that lower down.
For gaming it's fine but if you're just streaming consider 3700x. It's an excellent alternative.

Boost clock issue: This CPU currently (9/6/19) does not hit its advertised boost (cooler master ml370r) some very expensive mother boards do get close or beyond sometimes. A high end Aorus or ROG is needed for that. (Update is said to be coming to fix this issue)
Overclocking Notes: After following every OC guide I could find I can say it is possible to beat Precision Boost Overdrive (By a good amount too!)
Motherboard:
One of the main problems is that VRM Temps are too high with the boosting on this system. Aorus Pro
column3: or TUF seem to have the best VRM temps. Some people do undervolt to fix this.

column1: If you have an x470 motherboard make sure to patch it first or contact AMD and they will actually send you a CPU to boot and update.
RAM:

The infinity fabric that connects the two dies is tied to the ram speed. So get quality RAM with good timings and clocks. (Just google a calculator so you don't get screwed with bad timings) after 3800 it does decouple from the infinity fabric.
Linux notes:
This one has been a struggle. I haven't tried it with every Linux distro but here are my experiences.
Debian:
Works like a charm so far but I haven't had it running very but it will at least run.
Arch:
No. Some of the bugs are patched but after two manual builds
column3: and anarchy none of them would fully boot. It would freeze during start up (9/1/19 release)

column1: I hear Ubuntu too does work for the 3900x but I don't personally use it"^5^Sep 6

SyGreenblum^/amd-ryzen-9-3900x-12-core-3-8-ghz-socket-am4-desktop-processor/6356274?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^5^0^"I recently built a new PC coming from a Intel 3770K.  The 3770k is still a good processor and I still use the machine but as far as speed the Ryzen 9 is roughly twice as fast on average but this depends on the programs you're running.  The speed of the system in general feels much faster
column2: much of this can be attributed to moving from and SSD to an M.2 drive but having 12 fast cores certainly plays its part.

column1: One thing I should state is do not fall for the M.2 PCIe 4.0 marketing pitch.  They are currently twice the price per GB and under normal circumstances are 'slower' then Samsung Pro devices and most cases slower then even the Adata 8200.  Maximum transfer speed means almost nothing in typical use.  I may need to revise this statement next year when better dives hit the market but for right now save your money or use it on better memory or gpu."^5^Sep 6

column2: I love that their processors have always performed at higher frequencies out of the box than other brands.  This is no exception.  It is rated at 12 cores 3.8GHz and even under full load tests with rendering from 3D programs or processor heavy After Effects composites as well as my games
column3: this processor has been awesome and rarely drops under 4.0GHz without any overclocking.  Install the AMD chipset for it in addition to your motherboard chipset and make sure to update your BIOS on your motherboard right away to ensure all the built in clocking mechanics are running correctly.  It runs at a higher voltage than I am used to in idle states (1.3-1.4) but AMD & Asus have assured me that this is how the chip is designed and it is performing as intended.  If you want a great processor that will allow you to game as well as do productive tasks
column4: this is a great choice.  I've only been using it for 3 days now
column5: but out of box with stock cooler and a good case with fans to keep air moving
column6: it runs perfect."^5^Dec 20

column1: delbro^/amd-ryzen-9-3900x-12-core-3-8-ghz-socket-am4-desktop-processor/6356274?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^0^"So first things first I ordered both 3700x and 3900x to test out both since I was undecided. 3700x would've sufficed but my batch of 3700x wasn't binned properly. The infinity fabric that connects the chiplets was not clocking properly to match memory clock speed to have a 1:1 ratio
column2: causing bad latency at high Memory speeds.

column1: 3900x blows my 9900k out the water when it comes to work and gaming. 9900k has a slight edge in my gaming benchmarks but the work load performance in 3900x is unmatched at this price point. Got lucky with the binning of my 3900x as well as it clocks its Infinity fabric up to 1900mhz.
Using x470 Asus ROG Crosshair VII for this one."^5^Aug 3

column1: scTech^/corsair-vengeance-lpx-series-16gb-2pk-8gb-3-2ghz-ddr4-desktop-memory-white/5822465?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"Bought for Gigabyte B450M ds3h WiFi motherboard. After installing and turning on XMP I got a blue screen of death. Disabling XMP running memory at 2133Mhz system was stable.  After some research I found an article to adjust memory timings manually.
On the M.I.T. tab in Bios select Advanced Memory Settings. Then select Memory Timing Mode and select Manual.
First enable XMP
-Set DRAM voltage manually to 1.35v
-Set RAM multiplier to 32x
-Set the first five subtimings manually to 16-18-18-18-36 (important)
-Set the sixth timing (tRC) to 56 instead of 54 (important)
When setting timings manually in Bios highlight the timing you wish to change and type in the number and press enter. Do this for all timings you change. Save and exit.
After applying these timing changes my memory is rock solid."^4^Dec 7
Hail4Gaming^/corsair-vengeance-lpx-series-16gb-2pk-8gb-3-2ghz-ddr4-desktop-memory-white/5822465?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"The RAM

column2: it did not. Windows 10 recognized the drive but only loaded standard drivers. The error message from device manager follows:

column1: Windows cannot verify the digital signature for the drivers required for this device. A recent hardware or software change might have installed a file that is signed incorrectly or damaged
column2: or that might be malicious software from an unknown source. (Code 52)

column1: I consulted several forums where other people experienced the same problem and no one seemed to have a solution. ASUS told me to contact Microsoft. HA! Like that's gonna happen!

Vamadman^/corsair-carbide-series-275r-atx-mid-tower-case-black/6237542?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"I bought this case for my very first build and I chose the right one. I added 2 more fans to it to help keep it cool.  I like the simplicity and no frills look of it along with the satisfaction in knowing I got the most bang for my buck.  I put an AMD 3700X CPU on an MSI X570 Edge WIFI mobo with 32gb 3200mhz RAM and a Cooler Master Hyper 212 CPU cooling fan and still have plenty of room to add more stuff.  The white LED's under the front cover add a touch of class to the case and was an added bonus.  Cabling was a breeze with all of the cutouts and oblong grommets to run wires and hide them neatly out of sight.  The front cover is solid brushed look ABS so if you are looking for a case to mount RGB fans into
column2: this may not be the one for you as they will not be visible from the front of the case.  The tempered glass side panel with knurled thumbscrews and rubber grommets is easily taken off and installed if the case is laid on its side.  The glass cover adds a nice look too as you can see the inner workings of your build.  This case is not fancy like a lot of others but with its minimalist appearance
column3: it has a classy look.  Remember

column1: frosty357^/corsair-valueselect-16gb-2pk-x-8gb-1-3-ghz-ddr3-sdram-laptop-memory-multi/4690376?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^4^0^"I installed these memory modules into a December 2011 MacBook Pro along with a new SSD hard drive (Samsung EVO 850 1TB) and it's now ZOOMING right along. It was a big upgrade - from 2x2GB to 2x8GB - yet the improvement in speed still exceeded my expectations.

I replaced the hard drive first (upgrade to High Sierra killed the HDD hard drive) and saw some improvement in reboot speed and performance but overall performance bumped up noticeably when these modules were installed.
On average it now takes about 20 seconds from the time I hit restart until its ready for me to enter my password.

My MBP is a unibody so it took only a few minutes to remove the 2x2GB and replace with these 2x8GB modules. The MBP booted up immediately and it's been running smoothly ever since (installed ~12/8/17).

An investment of less than $140.00 has increased the speed and performance so much that I'm kicking myself for not upgrading this new-to-me MBP six months ago when I bought it from a co-worker."^5^Jan 15

column1: AudiLuce^/xfx-amd-radeon-rx-580-gts-xxx-edition-8gb-gddr5-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card/6136515?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"I use this card for video editing and it cut my time in half. I am in love with this card and now tempted to hook it up to my husband's Skull Canyon to see how it performs on Beat Saber."^5^Feb 26

JoeT^/xfx-amd-radeon-rx-580-gts-xxx-edition-8gb-gddr5-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card/6136515?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"I bought this card to replace the anemic on-board Dell R9 370 in a XPS 8900 chassis. The card works great with Windows 10 19H1 and 20H1
column2: but there are two caveats - first
column3: you can set the built-in 'video card brace' aside
column4: it's too narrow to fit this card - second
column5: the card has a 8-pin PCI power plug
column6: and comes with a 8-pin to dual 6-pin adapter cable
column7: which is a good thing because the XPS 8900 has two 6-pin PCI power plugs on its video power cable and they BOTH must be plugged into the XFX's adapter cable to power this card - it took me two tries to figure that out
column8: because no documentation I could find told me about that little gotcha. All that said
column9: the card has more than enough capability to drive a 27 or 34 inch Dell Ultrasharp monitor at full resolution with perfect clarity."^5^May 17

column2: and decided to pick this one up. Fits perfectly in my midsized tower. Measure to make sure it fits. Bad reviews based on not measuring don't give this justice. Dropped about 20 degrees while idle
column3: while gaming it dropped 20-30 degrees depending on the game. Average temp idle is 37 in case
column5: average gaming is 47 and it's overclocked to 4ghz. (Might be different for your situation
column6: it's also on the paste it came with). It's not loud IMO. I have 7 fans
column7: and it's rarely loud. Rgb I could care less about but icue software works fine for adjusting color and performance. I'm sure there are cheaper products
column8: but I was in a pinch and was local. I'd say worth a buy. Install was annoying but was easy and straightforward. Hope this helps."^5^Oct 21

column1: needmoarhardware^/corsair-hydro-series-280mm-liquid-cooling-system-with-rgb-lighting-black-gray/6181282?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"I have this installed on a Ryzen 7 2700x. I had a smaller 120mm AIO cooling it before.

HeavyGamer^/corsair-hydro-series-280mm-liquid-cooling-system-with-rgb-lighting-black-gray/6181282?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"Got motivated to build me a new system intel based. my orders from newegg came in fine. Only thing my i-7 didnt come with was a Fan an heatsink. Instead of waiting for another week for one part. I decided to go to bestbuy to pick this up. Since my new case was designed with liquid cooling in mind. I said what the heck. Went in smooth no issues it mounted up in a designated spot on my case. Ran some extensive Benchmarks to see how well it would handle. Kept my CPU between 35 to 42C with no issues. As of now I dont see an issue and I checked the cords an connections to make sure it didnt leak before I installed it. Pretty well built. Only time will tell how well it will hold. After installed played about 7hrs of Doom on ultra settings no problem it stayed at a cool temp the whole time."^5^Sep 24

Flood404^/xfx-amd-radeon-rx-560-4gb-gddr5-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card-black/6183042?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^30^0^"In order to use this card your motherboard's BIOS has to be UEFI and not using a legacy BIOS. So do not expect this card to work in something made in 2011 or older. Or Socket 775 systems or older or AM2+ or older those will most likely not have the UEFI BIOS. If you tried to install this in a computer running a legacy BIOS. The driver will refuse to load with a code 43. Does not matter if the computer is running windows 10 or 8.1 or even 7 it will not work because of the UEFI BIOS requirement."^5^May 26
yincision^/xfx-amd-radeon-rx-560-4gb-gddr5-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card-black/6183042?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^16^3^"This is a great budget gaming card. I built it up with an i5-7400
column2: 8 GB DDR2400 RAM and a 500 GB SSD. All is hooked up to a 30-inch 2560x1600 IPS display.

column1: Games I play include Lord of the Rings Online

Looking to make some cash I sold my GTX 1070 and put this Radeon RX560 into the rig. I see absolutely no difference in real-world gaming experience between the two cards at 2560x1600. I know on paper and by tech specs there is no comparison between these classes of cards (and that the GTX 1070 blows it away). But all of the above games assign highest/best quality settings to both cards when I auto-detect the graphics properties. Sure
column2: FRAPS tells me a different story when I actually watch framerates. But as far as gaming experience goes I see absolutely no difference. Actually
column3: I prefer the colors and saturation of the AMD Radeon RX560 over the GTX 1070.

column1: Bottom line - in more demanding top tier games this card would most likely be trounced by other offerings. But if you are playing games similar to those listed above
column3: the RX 560 will do perfectly well and provide you quite a satisying experience without stuttering or lag.

column1: I hope this helps someone making a decision on their purchase."^5^Aug 14

column3: over that and it doesn't do as well
column4: but that's to be expected with a non-full sized graphics card.

column1: It ran fine in everything from an old Inspiron 530 to a new modern Ryzen system.
It's suprisingly cool and quiet
The graphics quality of video's is crisp and clear.
It works well for Mid to High end content creation
column2: the speed and memory of 4GB is currently enough though I wish it was 8GB and had more stream processors
column3: for how it's being used it works fine no complaints.

column2: just know that this is the 560D version that only has 896 stream processors. The bestbuy website said this one came with 1024 stream processors. This is incorrect. This is basically a rebagged rx 460. So just be careful
column3: if you are looking for the full rx 560

column1: CarGuy1969^/xfx-amd-radeon-rx-560-4gb-gddr5-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card-black/6183042?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^6^3^"FYI - RX 560's come in two forms now - 1024 shaders and 896 shaders. AMD doesn't do a good job being clear on which card is which. This one's the 896 shader version. Read the fine print before you buy but the actual performance difference is only about 3%-10% real world.

Pro's - Very good FPS performance on 720p. Ok FPS performance on 1080p. (This is not for 4k games but does support 4k video). The card runs cool and quiet. DX12 and Vulcan support. It's a vast improvement on the Intel 530 integrated graphics it's meant to replace.

It's a few FPS slower than the 1024 shader version and the GTX 1050 2gb cards (varies from game to game) - but it's less expensive too. If you want 60 FPS+ 1080p gaming you should get an RX 570 or a GTX 1060 anyway. This one's attached to an older 720p TV and does very well in e-sports titles. Most AAA titles can be played at lower to mid settings. The most demanding titles will display but won't play well.
It need's a dedicated power connector because of t's power requirements so check your power supply to make sure it's big enough.

I needed a budget priced card to give a handed down gaming PC some punch for my son on his TV (I kept my GTX 1070 for me). This works great. If his TV (monitor) was 1080p I would have gotten a higher end card."^5^May 29
Dafrenchman^/xfx-amd-radeon-rx-560-4gb-gddr5-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card-black/6183042?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"The card works for some things

Some time after it was released they started selling a less powerful variant under the same model number that only handles 896 streams. This card is the 896 stream variant. column2: I put it all on an Asus Rog Strix z390 E motherboard. I installed everything and booted up the computer
column4: opened MSI afterburner and started playing. Mainly I play Apex Legengs right now so that is what I am going to base this review on
column5: I've had the card for two days and have not had a chance to try any other games. Anyways
column6: booting up Apex and leaving everything on mad settings
column7: 1440p 144hz the card runs at 70-95%. Auto boost clock running at 2050 out of the box with no tweaking. I have pretty good airflow
column8: but running this card with these settings the temp peaks at 55c and does not dip below 144hz. So far with performance I am absolutely pleased.

column1: Noise: For me
column2: aesthetics and noise come secondary compared to performance. I play with noise cancelling headphones
column3: and when gaming I have 8 fans spinning up anyways
column4: so I have not really heard the card over the rest of the fans in the case. All I know is that my temps are perfect
column5: and I am happy with it.

column1: Looks: This card looks amazing in my opinion
column2: it has a pretty simple design and I love it. The card is solid and sturdy. I do wish that the Geforce RTX logo was changeable but I can live with that.

column1: A couple of side notes: The reason I gave this 4
column3: is because when installing the GPU into the mother board for the first time the bracket and the PCI slot were not lining up. After further inspection I found that the mounting bracket was bent at the top where it slides into the case
column4: maybe 2 off. I bent the bracket straight by hand
column5: and it went right in. Although I would prefer to not recieve a card bent out of the box
column6: it works perfect and I'm not waiting for a replacement. Maybe Nvidia can chime in to how a $700 GPU comes with a bent bracket out of the box?

column1: Also
column2: and this has no effect on my review
column3: the first day I had the card in everything ran perfect. My temps were slightly higher
column4: but that was because I didnt plan far enough ahead to realize that the mother board only offers 2 Chassis Fan Headers and a couple others
column5: so I only had 3 fans running in the case. Since all my fans are corsair and I did not want to buy splitters
column6: I purchased a commander pro to control fan speed and RGB. To get the iCue software to control the PWM fan speeds
column7: I had to update iCue to the latest version. I put everything in
column8: booted up
column9: upgraded
column11: and started playing. My gameplay went from 144fps butter smooth
column12: to 100-120fps and stuttering. I couldn't shoot anything. I thought maybe I plugged something back in wrong. After troubleshooting I figured out that the iCue software is the root of the problem. Uninstalling iCue and rebooting the game

column1: Would I buy it again? Yes I would."^4^Sep 9

column2: i'm using MSI Afterburner; over 2Ghz boost. The Control game is amazing to experience RTX. I would recommend it if you play story based games (Cyberpunk 2077 can't wait!). I wouldn't use it in FPS games like Battlefield.

column1: As the Nvidia drivers become more stable and optimized to use RTX the card will continue to be better. Full load temperatures 60-75C. Obviously it's gonna run a little bit warmer but they designed the fans very well - quiet @ 60% fan curve.

I got this card for high frame rate 1080p 144-240hz however it can definitely handle 1440p very well. If you want 4k with high fps and settings then you're gonna have to buy the 2080ti. If you're looking for a new GPU and don't care for RTX
column2: get an board partner 5700xt @ $399-450 for 2070 super equivalent performance (*not capable of RTX reminder*). recommend having Gen 7 i7 or newer intel processor or good gen 1/2 Ryzen OC

Aliengamer^/nvidia-geforce-rtx-2080-super-8gb-gddr6-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card-black-silver/6361326?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^4^0^"Just picked up and installed in my Alienware Amp.
Perfect fit
column2: the only downside are the blowers. They blow up and out rather than through and out. So I reversed the fans to exhaust on the case and when I'm really gaming and OC I keep the Amp case cracked.

column1: Steady OC at 125 on memory and 500 on core. Able to run Final Fantasy Online maxed at 4k 60fps. Control runs 1440p 60fps with RTX on medium. Control with RTX on high requires 1080p. Most if not all games I own are now maxed at either 4k or 1440p.
This should be helpful for all Alienware and Amp owners:
1. Uninstall all display drivers
2. Download GeForce Experience and let it install your built-in GPU driver
3. Shutdown
4. Plug in Amp and boot
5. Notice your card has generic Microsoft adapter
6. Right click that card in device manager
7. Update driver by pointing to the GeForce Experience download file
8. Let the driver install
9. DONE
Update BIOS to latest and Windows 10 to 1903 minimum for RTX features.
Highly recommend this card for the Alienware and Amp combo."^5^Feb 16

jtyler^/nvidia-geforce-rtx-2080-super-8gb-gddr6-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card-black-silver/6361326?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^5^9^"I've been using an XFX 5700XT for the past few weeks and decided to give the 2080 Super a try on my 1440p 144hz gaming monitor. The first thing I noticed when getting into a game (Ghost Recon: Breakpoint) was the SUPER LOUD high pitch whine the card was making. It wasn't a fan noise but more of an inductor noise. You can be in-game and go into the pause menu
column2: and the noise will go away. At first
column3: I thought it was my power supply
column4: so I got down and put my ear up to it and the 2080 to try to pinpoint where the insanely annoying sound was coming from. It sure sounded like it was coming from the 2080 instead of my EVGA 1000W PSU so just to be sure
column5: I removed the 2080 and reinstalled the 5700XT. The sound went away. Come to find out and some Google research
column6: this is a pretty common problem on the 2080 Supers and 2080 ti's.

column1: As for performance
column2: I gained about 10 FPS in Breakpoint
column4: at the same very high (not highest) setting for both cards. I'm using a Ryzen 3600 with 32GB of 3200Mhz DDR4 Ram
column5: the CPU utilization never goes above 50% and the GPU utilization stays pegged out so I'm pretty sure I'm not running into a CPU bottleneck. But thinking about it
column6: it costs roughly $300 for 10-20(max) more frames. I think that's a very crappy deal when looking at performance per dollar. And yeah
column7: that was the only game I personally tested
column8: but after hearing the horrible sound the card makes
column9: I already know I do not want it.

column1: I do plan to return this specific card soon but will exchange it for another brand 2080 Super. If youre thinking about this card
column2: just beware of the noise issue and the competition which is a lot cheaper for just a small performance loss. The 2080 Super is probably an overall nice card

organshifter^/amd-ryzen-9-3950x-16-core-3-5-ghz-socket-am4-desktop-processor/6391901?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^40^18^"Whew! I finally got a chance to order this beast! It took some serious dedication! It kept selling out everywhere! Being that Best Buy's product page had newly launched (~11-27-2019)
column2: I decided to focus solely on it. Periodically (sometimes obsessively) refreshing the page for days was well worth the time. On the morning of 11/30/2019 at approximately ~8:21am
column3: I was shocked when the 'Sold Out' button briefly turned into 'Add to Cart.' When it happened
column4: I was nearly floored! I immediately thought
column5: 'How many more people are seeing this with me?!' My anxiety levels went into overdrive! I have never clicked through the checkout process so quickly in my life! Had I been using the Best Buy app on my phone
column6: I probably would have dropped it. Lol.

column1: Anyhow
column2: like everyone else interested in this processor
column3: I had been reading/watching all of the reviews for it. The results are astounding! It's unlike anything we've seen in the mainstream consumer space before. I have no reservations in saying that the AMD Ryzen 9 3950X is nothing short of spectacular! No matter the task (gaming
column6: etc)
column7: the 3950X rises to the occasion
column8: and will continue to do so for many years to come.

column1: I was actually leaning towards a Threadripper 3960X as I wasn't sure if the amount of PCI-E 4.0 lanes on the AM4 platform were going to be enough. Once the 24/16 lane count from a combination of the CPU/X570 chipset were confirmed
column2: I knew that a total 40 lanes would suit me just fine.

column1: This new rig is replacing my build from March 2017. Over the last two and a half years
column2: the only parts I've upgraded on it are the power supply and graphics card
column3: both of which I'll be carrying over to the new build. I purchased everything else I needed for the new build week ending 11-23-2019. The processor was all that remained. I got lucky!

column1: Best Buy estimated it to be delivered on Wed 12-4-2019
column2: but UPS had it at my local facility on Tue 11-3-2019
column3: scheduled for delivery the same day! Best Buy sent me a very festive email
column4: excitedly proclaiming that my package was arriving a day earlier! Things couldn't get any better! I waited and waited until
column6: the UPS truck arrived at 12:20pm! I was at the door waiting patiently. He walked up and delivered my new tower
column7: second NVMe drive
column8: and nothing else. I asked if there were any more packages. He said those are the only items set for delivery to my address. As he walked away
column9: my heart sank. I immediately brought up the app. The 3950X was still scheduled for delivery. All was not lost!

column1: After waiting for around thirty minutes or so
column2: I opened the app again. An exception occurred at 12:23pm. As I read the status of my package
column3: it felt like time stood still. 'Due to operating conditions
column4: your package may be delayed.' Dang it. That was the last thing I was expecting to see. Oh
column5: well. I called UPS to find out what was going on. The first guy I talked to told me that the scans I see on the website and app are just labels
column6: and that UPS doesn't have physical possession of my package. Wait. What? You cannot be serious. How so? He said the package is considered lost
column7: and didn't seem interested in discussing it any further. He actually insisted that we file a report.

column1: I was sick to my stomach at the thought of my CPU being lost
column2: and the claims process ahead of me. I couldn't accept that answer
column3: so I asked to speak to a supervisor. I was finally connected to someone with access to more information. She reassured me that UPS was indeed in possession of my package. She went on to say that it was left at the facility by the driver and would be delivered the next available business day. I told her that I would be more than happy to go pick it up myself. She went ahead requested a same day hold for me. I drove over to the local facility (~9 minutes) and talked to someone. Turns out
column5: but on a truck that was waiting to be unloaded/sorted. There was no way I could get the package that day. Sigh. I returned home. I reasoned that it wasn't the end of the world. Besides
column6: it was a day early anyway.

column1: So
column3: I received my package today (12-4-2019). I'm excited and can't wait to get started. Sorry for such a long story. Thanks for reading.

column1: Good luck to everyone else trying to get their hands on this elusive part.

Case: Rosewill Nighthawk Z-RGB"^5^Dec 4
Beradon^/amd-ryzen-9-3950x-16-core-3-5-ghz-socket-am4-desktop-processor/6391901?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^10^0^"When I read that AMD was going to be releasing this processor
column2: I knew this was the one for me.  As with many
column3: I saw it immediately go out of stock on most major retailers instantly on the day of release but lucked out being cable to catch one at Best Buy a few days later.  Best Buy is also one of the very few that hasn't started to jack the price up at this point because of demand as well
column4: so that just further increases my respect for this company.  That aside
column5: this is a review about the processor.

column1: This processor is fast.  More than that
column2: it has a lot going for it that is beyond most of the current offerings from either AMD or Intel.  In the forefront is the fact that this processor is not only the highest core and thread count of any non-HEDT processor currently
column3: but it is also the highest clock speed of any current AMD processor.  At this speed it easily trades blows with Intel's top of the line 9900K in many cases
column4: and I could see it start skewing more in the favor of the Zen2 series as optimization improves with games
column5: drivers and Windows itself (with AGESA 1.0.0.4B and improved power plans from Microsoft for Windows 10 we're already seeing this happen).

column1: In addition
column3: which no current Intel offering even supports.  This was a major deciding factor when I was in the market for a new chip as with the relative infrequency that I find myself in the position to upgrade
column4: I didn't want to come to a point in a year or two from now where I wanted some PCIE 4.0 capable storage or graphics but not able to use it due to lack of support.

column1: I plan on using this processor not only as a gaming processor
column2: but also to support streaming and VMware capabilities
column3: all of which it is capable of doing without breaking a sweat due to the insane number of cores and threads.

column1: I am running it with a Corsair H100i AIO cooler with fans in a push-pull configuration and have not seen it go above 64'C under full benchmark load.
Paired with my 2080TI
column2: I am not seeing anything that can come close to stressing my system.

column1: There is a downside to moving from Intel to AMD as I did with this build.  I have been using Intel since the first gen core-i series (i7-860k) and only moved to AMD at this point because the performance ball was finally in the AMD court.  But the downside to moving here was the loss of Intel RST raid.  I understand that motherboard raid is a controversial feature
column5: I've been using it for years
column6: and because I was moving from board-to-board that was all Intel
column7: I didn't have to rebuild my storage array.  Moving from Intel to AMD required me to rebuild my array (which also made me re-think using onboard raid
column8: and indeed I've now moved to Microsoft Storage Spaces).  Why am I even mentioning this?  Intel's RST is dramatically *DRAMATICALLY* easier to configure and use than AMD's RaidXpert2.  I ran into many issues with AMD RaidXpert2 including an inability to remove a drive from RAID to use a standalone without using a third party tool to blow away the partition information that RaidXpert2 places on it when you initialize the drive.  I dont feel I should need to use a third party tool just to disable RAID on a drive.  In addition
column9: there were issues in the creation of the raid that resulted in some dataloss for me
column10: which was unfortunate.  I would suggest that unless you absolutely require it
column11: avoid using AMD's RaidXpert2 onboard RAID.

column1: All in all
column2: I would easily recommend this to anyone
column3: provided they understand the strengths of this processor.  This is not going to be the fastest processor for everyone.  While it does excel in both games and productivity
column4: if you are purely gaming this may not be the best choice.  It is also not an excessively great overclocking chip as AMD has already pushed this package so close to the edge."^5^Dec 21

column1: WMicke^/amd-ryzen-9-3950x-16-core-3-5-ghz-socket-am4-desktop-processor/6391901?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^9^3^"To start off
column2: I have to admit that this is my 3rd AMD-based computer that I have built from 2010 until today.  Despite this
column3: I don't think that I would consider myself an 'AMD fanboy' I've simply always liked AMD CPU's from a price vs performance perspective.  Originally I looked to AMD because it was more affordable
column5: even when I could have afforded an Intel i9 9900 KS
column6: I chose the AMD Ryzen 9 3950X.  Why?  Because right now it's simply the best CPU on the market.  Sure
column7: Intel might beat out the 3950X on a few lightly threaded gaming benchmarks (although the 3950X is always extremely close)
column8: but when it comes to gaming
column9: I don't know anyone who games that way anymore.  I won't just have a game open
column11: and I'll have Discord
column12: and I'll have Browser Windows (probably with at least half a dozen or more tabs open)
column14: or perhaps a stream deck...  and running multiple simultaneous apps is where the Ryzen 9 3950X shines.  Oh
column15: and when it comes time to stop gaming and actual try to get some productivity tasks done?  Not even a contest.  AMD wins every time.

column1: The only thing I will add
column2: is that when it comes to getting the most from your Ryzen 9 3950X
column3: please make sure that you download the latest BIOS and motherboard updates from you motherboard manufacturer
column4: and any available chipset updates from AMD... but most importantly download AMD's Ryzen Master software
column5: it makes tweaking your CPU and RAM clock speeds as simple as adjusting a slider
column6: and it does an excellent job of checking stability (when you click the 'apply and test' button) after you make any changes.  Those simple updates easily gave me an extra 5-10% performance
column7: and can help you avoid any headaches."^5^Dec 31

column1: dave^/amd-ryzen-9-3950x-16-core-3-5-ghz-socket-am4-desktop-processor/6391901?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^5^0^"I replaced a  1800x  with the  3950x. I'm still  using my crosshair vi  motherboard ..  everything   runs  great.. Cinebench  20 stock setting   hit averages  between 9085  and 9140  with all stock settings"^5^Jan 14

This processor is definitely overkill solely for gaming
column2: the myriad of 6 to 8 core processors available nowadays would be better options
column3: but for anyone using it for professional or multithread workloads
column4: the 3950X is without a doubt the best consumer processor available."^5^Dec 27

column1: joeymcnew^/amd-ryzen-9-3950x-16-core-3-5-ghz-socket-am4-desktop-processor/6391901?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"With 16 cored and 32 threads
column2: there's nothing that this can't do in a really short time. I do video creation and editing and this processor
column3: I can render in 4k in real time or less. Actually I can render up to 3 videos at once in Sony Vegas Pro 17. I'm not sure if I could render more than 3 at once because I haven't tried to as of yet. If you get the opportunity
column4: get one of these and try it. You will want to get a water cooler for this as they can or could run a little warmer than the previous chips. This does run cooler than the Ryzen 3 3900x. The Ryzen 9 3950x and the NZXT x72 keep my temps in the 30-35 celcius range."^5^Mar 23

column1: mike^/amd-ryzen-9-3950x-16-core-3-5-ghz-socket-am4-desktop-processor/6391901?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"I am coming from a 3 year old i7-7700k and can't believe the increase in performance.  I can edit 4k videos in real time

MrHumdy^/amd-ryzen-9-3950x-16-core-3-5-ghz-socket-am4-desktop-processor/6391901?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"So I bought this mainly for gaming and streaming and I know everyone says it is for productivity and not really for gaming but hey I love this CPU and I assume in the future games and other applications will take advantage of multicores and this CPU will last me for a very very long time! column1: RiverWayne^/amd-ryzen-9-3950x-16-core-3-5-ghz-socket-am4-desktop-processor/6391901?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"I paired this processor with an Asus Crosshair VIII Formula Z570 board
column2: 32 GB DDR4 3200 Ram and a Nvidia 2070 Super video card. I use a Corsair H115i Pro AIO cooler for cooling. The performance across the board is excellent - for gaming
column4: and everyday tasks. It is a 'jack of all trades'.  Performance with Windows 10 has been fine with no crashes. It outperforms my Intel 16 core and from the on-line reviews it is on par with the upcoming Intel 10980XE 18 core CPU. Of note
column5: the memory channel support is dual and not quad as you would get from the 10980XE or AMD Ryzen Threadripper CPUs."^5^Feb 11

column1: aarondr^/amd-ryzen-9-3950x-16-core-3-5-ghz-socket-am4-desktop-processor/6391901?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^1^"The 3950x is as everyone says: an excellent chip. It's fast
column4: and plenty of frequency to go around.  It's kind of amazing to think not even 3 years ago we were stuck with 4 cores 8 threads on desktop.  AMD has multiplied that by 4 to get us 16 cores
column5: 32 threads.  And this is no slouch either
column6: straight up beating a 10980xe in head to head despite having 2 fewer cores.

column1: Like most Ryzen
column2: you won't get tons of overclocking headroom like Intel.  Coming from a HEDT Intel chip before this
column3: I was used to finding the right voltage
column5: and frequency to get the most out of my chip.  Ryzen 3rd gen especially is a temperamental animal
column6: and essentially cranked to 11 by default.  This is less of a reflection on Ryzen
column7: and more of just how they have their CPUs tweaked.  The Ryzen architecture has never scaled especially high like Skylake
column8: but it really doesn't need to to get equivalent performance.

column1: Ryzen is by far a different flavor
column2: even compared to the old XP
column3: and FX series from AMD and prior.  I have been buying AMD and Intel for years
column4: and Ryzen is the first real deathknell to CPU tweakers - but not because of imposed restrictions
column5: but because the chip manages its boost so well.  Sure you can overclock RAM
column6: and tweak timings - or even do an all core OC or per CCX OC - but non of this nets much really.  This isn't knocking the chip at all
column7: but rather the reality that overclocking (the CPU at least) may be mostly dead for anything but sub-ambient cooling.

column1: The biggest cons of this chip are:
* No included cooler (while the 3900x gets the pretty Wraith prism
column2: the extra $250 here gets you no cooler and just 1 more chip-let -albeit a better binned one).

column1: * HEDT performance without HEDT features (you get the same mainstream X570 limitations on PCIe lanes - albeit they are 4.0 speeds at least and support for a paltry - hehe - 128GB of RAM).
Both of the above cons are really just more FYIs.  Beast-mode builders of gaming/streaming rigs won't really care about either of the above
column2: but professional are even more segregated to using threadripper.

column1: This is a super fast chip.  If you were considering HEDT platforms before
column2: this wipes the floor with everything
column3: even previous threadrippers must bow to the superior per thread performance of the 3950x.  This CPU costs a pretty penny
column4: but its sure to be relevant for quite a while.  Someday it may end up powering my NAS
column5: but for now it's the fastest CPU around barring 3rd gen threadripper."^5^Feb 15

column1: Flyrod^/amd-ryzen-9-3950x-16-core-3-5-ghz-socket-am4-desktop-processor/6391901?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^4^"Been Running AMD processors since the mid 90s or so.
K5
column6: Opteron 165
column8: Phenom 2 965 Black edition
column9: and an FX8350 . and now this Beast.

column1: This is Flat-out the Best Mainstream CPU available today. period.. there are some Threadripper parts that are better but not really a mainstream part. since as noted above I do not build new pcs that often I expect this one to give me years of service.  .I put this on a Gigabyte Auros Master Motherboard. with 64GB of 3200Mhz Corsair LPX Ram
column2: an AMD 5700XT Video Card. a Pair of Sabrant Rocket 4.0 1TB NVME 4.0 Drives and a big backup spinner drive. cooled by the Corsair H115Pro RGB and stuffed into an Corsair Obsidian 750D Air Case..no temp issues at all .running win 10 Pro OEM. boot time is sometimes faster than the monitor comes alive.  overall WOW WOW WOW>  you will not be disappointed no matter your use of this one."^5^Jan 17

column4: it will hold a playable frame rate at 4k (3840 x 2160) between 50-60 FPS with some dips below that during very heavy action

column1: Now
column2: granted my experience is not going to hold true for every game or every PC setup
column3: but it's worked for me. As with everything PC related

column1: Anyway
column2: if you want a highly capable mid-range GPU then this is a great one to look at
