column1: Jmdonnel60^/xfx-amd-radeon-rx-590-fatboy-oc-8gb-gddr5-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card/6315898?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^9^3^"Very smooth and fast works well with games and post video production"^5^Dec 2

VastLite^/xfx-amd-radeon-rx-590-fatboy-oc-8gb-gddr5-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card/6315898?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^7^2^"XFX has a strange way of releasing products. They are pretty solid on the whole
column2: but this one definitely needs some tweaking out of the box. The great thing about this is XFX somewhat encourages it
column3: as long as you aren't being obtuse.

column1: I love this card. It might not seem like much of a step up from an RX 480 on paper
column2: but there is a noticeable improvement to frametimes in some of my favorite games. Finally I can enjoy things at my monitor's higher refresh rates!

column1: There were some teething issues during the first couple hours. I looked up a review on the card after experiencing temperatures above 80C. Turns out this is a dual-bios card with a dip-switch for changing between the two. Unfortunately
column2: XFX ships this card set to the 'quiet' fan setting
column3: it would seem. Before install I would recommend flipping that switch!

column1: Even at that though
column2: with higher fan speeds and lower temperatures
column3: I still wasn't quite happy with what I was seeing. There were numerous dips in Vcore and core clock during gaming and benchmarks. After reading reviews on another site
column4: I stumbled across a really decent fix for it!

column1: You see
column2: AMD are pretty awesome about things. Their driver suite just comes with overclocking capabilities that are quite easy to set up. So I took that reviews advice and increased the power target by 15% and set a more aggressive fan curve. (I've attached a screenshot of which settings I used in the driver control panel to get more stable performance.)

column1: Results? Buttery-smooth performance and some decent temperatures to boot! The drawback with the RX 590 in general is the power consumption. It has stellar performance for its price (Especially during the 50th sales) but it comes with a power cost.

I routinely see a power draw over 200 watts just for the GPU die (according to GPU-Z.) Not even taking into account the rest of the board. This isn't an issue if you have a good power supply and decent airflow
column2: but I would be hesitant to try this card on older or budget builds. If you do have an older setup and are worried about power
column3: just get a decent (as in 550w+) 80+ Gold or better with plenty on the 12v rail and you're good. You can also get some pretty well-performing cases for a song online. All a matter of how tenacious you are

column1: All-in-all I'm blown away by the performance-per-dollar of this card. The drawbacks are negligible
column2: especially remembering cards like the R9 300-series where power was very much off the charts. The 12nm refresh does well by this architecture
column3: with the only tradeoff I can see being increased power consumption. There are more eco-friendly options out there for sure
column4: but you wont find this level of performance for the price!"^5^May 4

column1: I replaced the fans

column1: Some complaints though

column1: So lnp channel one is used for my 6 ll120s connected to a fan hub. The second lnp channel is used for the logo. If you want strips you need another lighting node pro. And you need to be really good at cable management.
Instead
Expect to spend more money.

column4: it is seen by the icue software
column5: and I can turn the light on
column6: but it flickers

column1: I have my fan hub connected to my commander pro
column2: and my strips and psu shroud connected to the lnp. I am going to try moving the strips to the commander pro so that the only thing on the lnp is the psu shroud to see if that helps. Hours of research shows that this issue is common though. So be prepaired for that.

column1: Otherwise I love it

column1: oprib^/corsair-crystal-series-570x-rgb-atx-mid-tower-case-mirror-black/6237540?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^7^2^"Let me say that this has the best looks I've seen in a new case in a long time being sleek and sexy. However
column2: with it being mostly glass you have the downside of fingerprints and smudges however they come out easy with a microfiber cloth that most should own and if you don't you're going to need it with this case. From the cable management to the included RGB I can't complain. The front IO has ample features and enough room for a double rad up top or triple rad on the front (I have and have tried both and both fit comfortably). I have ran dual 1080ti's and a 7900k (not a flex) and have had no issues with cooling or dust as the built in filters work perfectly and enough cooling to run a 7980xe Easily if you truly wanted. Corsair has hit the mark on this one and I love it. BONUS- the fans included are full RGB for all those who want to RGB everything and they are pretty decent quality as corsair is the king of fans (IMO).

column1: Cons- Water-cooling (if you wanted) would be somewhat tight however you could still absolutely do it. Nothing else to mention as it's a pretty darn good system and why I keep coming back to corsair.
Design- 10/10 from cable management to the airflow
column2: no detail was overlooked and this is truly

column1: Durability- 10/10 and you're probably like 'but its all glass' and you're exactly right. You knew what you were getting into and you will have to be a little more careful since this is mostly tempered glass however it's not going to break for no reason and everything else is made to a high quality. For this I give it a 10 because you can tell in looks
column2: feel and heft that it's going to last.

column1: Quality- 10/10 I cant complain about anything and haven't had any issues. Corsair is known for its quality and customer service.
Cost- 8.5/10 you pay a little more because its all glass and as always the RGB tax. I wish it wasn't as pricey but I don't regret paying for it either.
Practicality- not going to give a score for this as this is more of an enthusiast level case and you're paying for things you don't need like RGB (that can be argued for some of you)
column2: all of the glass and so forth. You buy this because its sexy and the best
column3: you can get a $50 case that cools and will do fine but you pay the big money because this is the finest looking baddie you can get.

column1: Conclusion- If you have some extra money left over in your budget and you want the best looking case that catches eyes this is THE case. Even my enthusiast friends drool over this and I wish they made one big enough for an E-ATX and I would have 7 of these sitting around. Would absolutely buy again no regrets. Thumbs up if this helped!"^5^Dec 16

column1: I couldn't place a 360 mm radiator on top because it doesn't allow enough space to fit a motherboard.  Maybe a 240 mm can

column1: I agree with one of the reviews mentioned that you are going to have difficulties managing more fan lights
column2: and expect to spend more money.  I purchased 2 kits of LL120
column3: because the SP120 that comes with the case doesn't have the many cool features like LL120 have or the HD120 for that matter.

column1: You can only control the fans lights (SP120) and the two Corsair logos from the three buttons on top of the case.  With the provided RGB hub you are limited to just add two more connections because one of them is being used by the two Corsair logos.  You may be able to control all of the lights using the ICUE software
column2: but then you will forgo the functionality of the three buttons on top of the case

column1: A better purchase
column3: will be the Corsair 500D SE RGB
column4: and even though it may cost about $80 more
column5: you will save more money because it comes with 3 LL120 fan lights (These lights are the best I have seen so far in the RGB market) and the commander PRO which roughly valued altogether is anywhere between $180 to $200."^3^Oct 25

CupOfSyaro^/corsair-carbide-series-100r-atx-mid-tower-case-black/6198945?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"Pros:
Decent cable management on the back
Easy to open and close
Window Side-panel
Comes with a beefy case fan
Plenty of places to put extra case fans
Has two 5.25 inch expansion bays on the front
Cons:
The top of the case doesn't really have much room to route the 8pin EPS so if your power supply has smaller cables you might struggle a bit to connect it to the port on the motherboard.

The You may have trouble removing/inserting your graphics card into your motherboard while in this case because when you lift the card you will run into the metal housing on the case so you will have to do a little bit of wiggling t get it out of the case.

Overall: Good case for those who want to display some of their internals while also having room for something like an internal blu-ray writer and any other 5.25 inch expansions one can think of."^4^Feb 11

Larry^/corsair-carbide-series-100r-atx-mid-tower-case-black/6198945?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"I was looking to build a computer that I could have a good sized board and spaces to add other cards and drives. Of course if all you're using them for is gaming then they serve the purpose.  I needed something different and this unit has good space inside.  Plenty of room to add optical drives
column3: and a board big enough to add additional cards.  It is easy to get into on both sldes by just removing two thumb screws and one side has clear material that allows you to look inside and see what is going on or show off to your friends.  The easy install drive trays are nice but I didn't find any hardware made specifically for SD drives or the smaller drives but you can make it work. So far it is very good!"^4^Sep 6

column1: surfahdude^/corsair-carbide-series-100r-atx-mid-tower-case-black/6198945?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^0^1^"I needed a case that supported 5.25' drives and this one fit the bill. i also required a case that supported multiple four 3.5' and/or 2.5' drives.  It's not that large
column2: has a nice acrylic side panel.

column1: The issue is that the case cannot accommodate dual fan liquid coolers.  The interior is pretty tight and there is no clearance for a 240mm radiator in the front or top (the height of the radiator and fans will block the motherboard mounting).  This means you will have to get either a large air cooler or a single fan liquid cooler.
This will restrict the case to lower powered CPUs as CPUs such as the AMD 3900X or Intel i7 9700K or i9 9900K will not be cooled properly.
The case has mounts for five 120mm fans (two front
I was able to install an Intel i7 6700K with a Gemini S524 air cooler with no issues on a MSi Z170 Gaming Pro board.  I generally like the look and design
column2: I just wish that the case was a tad larger to accommodate AIO 240mm radiators.

column1: I also like the fact that the case does not come with a power supply unit.  This way you can buy a PSU that fits your needs."^4^Sep 26

column1: MECHNIC^/xfx-amd-radeon-rx-550-core-edition-4gb-gddr5-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card-black/5982203?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^6^0^"I have had this card installed for a couple weeks now & i had upgraded from a R7 due to some software issues and this is a huge upgrade to what i had before and the software works great.

The install was very easy and the windows 10 automatically installed drivers for proper function out of the box but i do recommend you go to XFX website and download the latest software package for full functionality .

The card looked and felt very high quality with its constructions one thing i was surprised in is how the fan only runs when it needs to so less noise and power consumption for your system so dont panic if you dont see the fan running .
There is no power connectors for this card so its and easy install.

Now on to the software the install was a breeze and the whole platform is well laid out and easy to understand but there is one thing i noticed in my system is it would not let me update the software so i had to go back to the XFX website and download the update from there so not a big issue but just FYI..
This comes with a 3 yr warranty so do register it and your covered .
YES I WOULD RECOMMEND ."^5^Jan 19

column8: vs the NVidia card I had previously been using. After building the Ryzen system

Desertfox^/corsair-hd-series-120mm-case-cooling-fan-kit-with-rgb-lighting/5845212?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^0^2^"These fans are overpriced for what they do. One
column2: the screws provided in the box were extremely hard to screw the fans and install into my computer case. I could not use the provided screws as they were extremely difficult to tighten without using brute strength. It felt like I might break them so I had to use the screws from the two fans that came with my case along with extras that was luckily provided for the third Corsair fan. These screws were slightly better but not easy to screw into the holes. Two
column3: I wanted to control these Corsair fans with the JCorsair1 header on my motherboard through software. However
column4: there is no cable provided to do this. The box which my motherboard came in did not include this cable either. The only way I can control them is using the provided Corsair controller.

column1: So I emailed Corsair about a week ago and never got a response back. I had to search Google to look where to find this cable as Corsair does not sell it. There is only one place that sells it and it is about $10.00 and not including shipping costs. This adds already to the overpriced fans.
Overall
column2: these fans are nice and good quality. The RGB lights are bright and the lighting effects are excellent. But I wish that I would not run into issues that I had with them. If I could return them I would. The fans that came with my computer case were quieter than these and I even adjusted the speeds in BIOS. I am sorry I cannot recommend these please go with a different manufacturer. If you love RGB and have to have them then go with these as I believe these are probably the best RGB fans on the market."^1^Jun 21

column1: Luke^/corsair-vengeance-rgb-series-16gb-2pk-8gb-3-0ghz-ddr4-desktop-memory-with-rgb-lighting-black/5823006?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^4^0^"this ram is running with a ryzen 7 1700 and asus crosshair vi hero and there is no problems. only issue is rgb cant be controlled from asus aura for some reason
Fnnoobee^/corsair-vengeance-rgb-series-16gb-2pk-8gb-3-0ghz-ddr4-desktop-memory-with-rgb-lighting-black/5823006?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"Pros:
+ Fast rated clock speeds.
+ Easy to set XMP speeds @ 2933Mhz OC on Ryzen platform (if you're motherboard supports it)
+ Reliable performance
+ Pretty lights
Cons:
- Requires another third-party program (Corsair Link) to be installed to set the RGB options for anything other than default Rainbow
- Can be tricky to get working properly on some Ryzen platform motherboards at rated speeds other than default speed of 2133MHz (this is more a limitation of individual motherboards
column2: BIOS firmware and the still maturing Ryzen platform than a fault of the RAM itself)

column1: Other thoughts:
Tried to run this set of RAM at XMP speeds @ 2933MHz on my first motherboard
column2: the Gigabyte AORUS X370 Gaming K5
column3: and it wouldn't post at any speed besides 2133MHz. After failing to run two sets of RAM at supported XMP profiles (I tried a set of PNY Anarchy-X RAM @ 3200MHz)
column4: I decide to RMA that board and purchase an ASUS Prime X370-A motherboard. I'm glad to report this RAM runs solid and fast on that motherboard with a Ryzen 1600 CPU with no issues. The RGB is a cool feature
column5: that whilst unnecessary does look neat in my clear panel case. Using the Corsair Link program I can choose from many RGB options. Only downside is that you have to use that program to set the option
column6: when most motherboards support some sort of native RGB functions already. Also
column7: couldn't seem to find anything other than solid red color
column8: but couldn't make it pulse or breath one solid color
column9: just in different colors FYI. The RAM's RGBs still stay lit when computer is in sleep mode so if your rig is in a room where people sleep
column10: you may want to fully shut your computer down when you go to sleep instead of letting the computer go into Sleep mode. All minor quibbles and not enough to knock a star. Again
column11: very pleased with this product and loving it in my new build!"^5^Mar 10

column3: the first kit I purchased had a dead stick in it. The return process was quick and simple
column4: which is a nice change of pace from having to RMA through Newegg. As for the product itself
column5: the kit runs at XMP profile speeds and the RGB LED lighting is an excellent touch to really make the motherboard pop.

column1: My only functionality complaint is that the RGB LED's continue to stay on if the machine has been put to 'sleep.'
The Corsair Link software that controls the lighting and monitors temps is easy to use and works with most Corsair products.
I will be purchasing another 8x2 kit ASAP.
System:
Gigabyte Z170 Gaming 7 Mobo
Intel i5 6600k CPU
EVGA GTX 1070 SC GPU
Corsair h80i v2 AIO CPU cooler

But before adding I would suggest you review these 3 questions when considering upgrading;
1) Make sure your motherboard supports the amount of memory you want to add and whether it uses dual channel or not.
2) If using Windows - make sure you have 64 bit system
column2: as 32 but will only use 4GB of memory even if you have more.

column1: 3) Make sure what memory your system is using as they are not backward compatible due to the different pins. (DDR2 (old)

TheTGB^/msi-b450-tomahawk-socket-am4-usb-3-1-gen-1-amd-motherboard-with-led-lighting/6305796?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^6^0^"I built my first gaming PC and I couldn't have done it without the ease of using the MSI B450 Tomahawk as my motherboard. When I found the right processor for my build
column3: I needed to find the perfect motherboard to complement that component. Building on a budget
column4: I was looking at MSI's motherboards and really wanted something that came ready for Ryzen's 2nd generation processors so I wouldn't have to worry about flashing the BIOS. The MSI B450 delivered on that promise and it was pretty much plug and play from there installing all my components on this board.

column1: I also wanted a motherboard that could handle DDR4 memory at 3000MHz. Again
column2: not a problem with this motherboard. Since it also supports up to 64GB
column3: it will still be able to grow with me as I upgrade this rig. These are even built with overclocking in mind
column4: though that is something I haven't done yet. It's really built for people who want to build mid to high-end gaming rigs and they thought of everything a gamer would want.

column1: Cosmetic wise
column2: this piece is beautiful. The gun metal colors around the motherboard's branding is a beautiful touch
column3: there are some RGB lights built in to light up your case
column4: and it just looks amazing when paired with everything else.

column1: To me
column2: this is a budget board that does far beyond what other more expensive boards will do for you and for that I'm grateful that I was able to find this board and make my first gaming rig a reality."^5^Nov 25

column1: Stockk^/msi-b450-tomahawk-socket-am4-usb-3-1-gen-1-amd-motherboard-with-led-lighting/6305796?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^5^1^"The motherboard shipped with no problems. column1: Raytheon^/corsair-vengeance-16-gb-2pk-x-8gb-1-6-ghz-ddr3-dimm-desktop-memory-kit-multi/5771735?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^1^"This pack of Corsair Vengeance contains two (2) 8Gb RAM chips for a total of 16GB. I would suggest this to anyone who:
- Overclocks
- Uses hi-end media software such as Adobe Creative Suite or PROtools.
- Hosts dedicated servers for various games.
- Uses resource intensive applications

If you are looking to build a 'future-proof' machine I would also suggest this simply because if you are not doing any of the above there is not a single application or process that will be using all of this RAM up - unless there is a memory leak or the application itself is not optimized correctly.

The best thing about this RAM however - the main reason I bought it personally - was because of it only being 2 chips and not 4. Your best bet would be to buy two of these for a total of 32GB of RAM if you only have 4 memory expansion slots on your mobo (motherboard)."^5^Mar 9

The Shipping said it would take 6. Was a little worried when i got it because it was labeled 'Compatible with Intel i7 and Intel Core Processors.' Being an AMD User this was a worry
column2: but when I got it in my rig and clocked it to 1600Mhz there were no worries at all. Everything runs as expected and I recommend this to all gamers."^5^Feb 17

GameElder^/pny-xlr8-nvidia-geforce-gtx-1650-overclocked-edition-4gb-gddr5-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card-black/6343714?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^13^0^"Before buying a GTX 1650
column2: I had heard that getting the drivers was a problem. That is an understatement. Nvidia uses an application called Geforce Experience to identify the card and install the drivers. I strongly recommend you have that website bookmarked before you install this card.

column1: I was replacing a GTX 1050 2GB card with HDMI and Display ports. Nvidia's GeForce Experience app had already been installed. My machine booted up at 800x600 resolution and the card itself was not identified by Windows. Geforce Experience was nowhere to be found. I had to reinstall it to get the 1650 drivers. If you have never installed a discreate graphics card before from Nvidia
column2: I can tell you from experience this is a common occurance. Be ready to install it again.

column1: The PNY has 1 HDMI port and one duel-linked DVI-D connection. Be warned that the DVI-D connection does not work until the drivers are installed. If using a dual monitor setup
column2: make sure to plug into the HDMI port for setup (using a HDMI to DVI-D connector will not work until the drivers are installed).

column1: Now for the good news. The graphics delivered from this card are gorgeous. At 1080
column2: running two monitors barely caused the card to pay attention. Running multiple instances of my favorite online game at high quality was consisderably smoother than on the 1050. I cannot vouch for VR or 1440 gaming
column3: but I was extremely satisfied with the performance I received at 1080.

column1: Also keep in mind that this card runs off the motherboard's power. No extra connectors
column2: no need for a larger power supply. If you have 300 watts
column3: you are good. If you are looking for an entry level gaming graphics card
column4: it may be hard to beat the 1650 unless you are willing to upgrade other computer parts. If you are willing to upgarde power supplies
column5: the 1660ti may be a better value.

column1: -1 star for the terrible driver install process."^4^May 8

Chris^/pny-xlr8-nvidia-geforce-gtx-1650-overclocked-edition-4gb-gddr5-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card-black/6343714?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^0^"This is overall a decent card if you are in the niche market of a compact card with low power draw.
Pros: Compact

column1: Some other reviews have mentioned difficulty with the driver installation. However

column1: Duffman^/msi-geforce-rtx-2060-gaming-z-6gb-gddr6-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card-silver-black/6322052?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^17^3^"My computer set up: This MSI Gaming Z RTX 2060 6GB graphics card
column2: Intel Core i5-7600K CPU at 4.8Ghz and 1.265V
column4: on Windows 10 Home version 1809 (mandatory for RTX) using Nvidia Driver 419.35.

column1: Out of the box the card boosted to 1980 Mhz on the core clock according to GPU-Z during Metro Exodus gameplay
column2: due to Nvidia's GPU Boost. It hovered around 1965 when it wasn't at 1980. The temperature reached a maximum of 67'C in my mini-ITX ThermalTake Core V1 case (accompanied by 6 other fans
column3: mind you). Fans stay off until card reaches 60'C
column4: and were mildly audible when they did spin. After implementing a custom fan profile in MSI Afterburner
column5: core clock boosted to a max of 2010 Mhz and temp rose to max of 68'C. This was in a room with ambient temperature of 72'F. Overclocking the card by adding +100 Mhz to core and +800 Mhz to memory in Afterburner resulted in a stable 5.6% performance increase at 1465 Mhz core clock (shown as 1980 boost clock in AF) and 2055 Mhz memory clock (shown as 7801 Mhz in AF) with power slider at 105%. Normal power consumption during Metro Exodus was around 194W at stock settings
column6: and around 204W when overclocked
column7: peaking at 70'C.

column1: It has been able to handle nearly all games at ultra settings at a minimum average of 60 fps (most between 100-144) at 1080p with the exception of Assassin's Creed Odyssey
column2: which averaged 58 fps on ultra (with volumetric clouds on medium). Faster ram or CPU (7700k or 8th/9th gen 6/8-core CPU) may result in averages above 60 in this single game
column3: or by overclocking (which did make the average 61 fps). Other games like RE7
column6: STEEP
column7: Shadow Warrior 2
column8: Gears of War 4
column9: Apex Legends
column11: played above 60 fps at 1440p ultra settings some reaching closer to 100. Even Metro Exodus (which was redeemed with the purchase of this card) played at 1440p 60FPS using this card at ultra (DX11
column12: RTX off
column15: and DLSS off) with some lows into the 50s.

column1: The card also supports the new NVENC encoder in OBS and I tried the Max Quality preset for streaming which seemed to be equivalent to x264's Faster Quality preset
column2: so x264 on Fast or better will still produce a higher quality stream. The advantage is reduced CPU usage with NVENC. Fortunately
column3: streams had about 0.1% dropped frames/no latency at 720p 60fps or 1080p 60fps at 6000Mpbs
column4: and the card's usage remained at about 80% utilization with 4.5/6GB of VRAM used during NVENC streaming.

column1: I opted to not use RTX or DLSS during Metro Exodus to avoid experiencing stutters or frame rate drops (it increases VRAM usage by 800Mb) but when activated in-game
column3: darker areas look harsher and fps dropped from 85 fps average on Ultra to 61 fps average with RTX. Game looks great normally
column4: and even better with ReShade which I believe is what most people should use instead of RTX in this game.

column1: Overall
column2: great design and cooling provides really good performance for triple A games at 1080p and 1440p. It would be comparable to GTX 1080 but with less VRAM. It is the best RTX 2060 model out of the bunch
column3: and I personally believe it's a better value at $389.99-$399 than RTX 2070s at $529+
column4: whether or not you overclock it."^5^Mar 21

column5: this product is a perfect upgrade. I have rarely had a problem with PNY Ram. To find out which and how much Ram is OK
column6: look at your system board (motherboard) for it's model number. For instance
column7: ASUS model number B85M-F . Google that motherboard type adding the word 'specs' after the model number and hit enter

column2: I decided to treat my wife and myself to a really good Christmas present. I bought the LG 65 inch flat screen OLED TV. My wife had never been in the store with me

column5: Then called her into the room. She was complexly amazed. I was very happy as the picture was every bit as good as the one in the store. I could go on about specifics
column6: but you can read some of the other more in depth reviews that are available. Suffice it to say
column7: this is the best TV I have ever seen or owned. It cost a lot more than the non OLED TVs
column8: but if you want an unequaled viewing experience
column9: it's worth it."^5^Jan 16

column1: MidNiteDriveThru^/corsair-rmx-series-1000w-atx12v-2-4-eps12v-2-92-80-plus-gold-modular-power-supply-black/6073500?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"As with most Corsair products I've purchased
column2: this power supply feels well-made. I'm unlikely to have much use for the cheap draw-string bag it came in
column3: but the velcro flap pouch for the modular cables seems like a good way to keep them together if you're not immediately using all of them: because YOU MUST NOT INTERCHANGE MODULAR CABLES. Apparently
column4: there is not a 'standard' pinout for these: so do not assume that cables from a different modular supply will work
column5: or you might end up replacing hard drives or even your mainboard. (I'd seen the custom kits for people who want to add color by swapping out their cables for fancy ones
column6: and mistakenly thought that meant that I could avoid wrecking my neat cable management job. 16TB of cooked drives
column7: a dead burner
column8: and one frotzed GIGABYTE board later
column9: it is NOT a mistake I'll make again.)"^5^Nov 23

column1: Quazimoto^/corsair-rmx-series-1000w-atx12v-2-4-eps12v-2-92-80-plus-gold-modular-power-supply-black/6073500?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^0^"I purchased the Corsair RM 1000x to replace a 10 year old failing PSU. This beast is driving three GPUs (2 RX 580 and 1 GTX 1080) on an i7 Skylake Z170 board with plenty of other peripherals connected. Even still there are several unused rails. It doesn't break a sweat and runs near silently. Rock solid voltages. This unit is hefty without being over-sized. It has only been a month but so far I am very pleased with it."^5^Sep 28

column2: one of my cables was damaged but I didn't need that cable but it's something you should be aware about this brand."^3^Sep 11

column2: this card is exactly what I was looking for.

column1: If you own a 1440p monitor
column2: this card was tailored for anyone using that resolution as it drives all current games in ultra settings often above 60 FPS. It can even touch base a bit on 4K displays just don't expect ultra settings and 60FPS.

column1: My first PC build used AMD components throughout and was an incredible machine. The new one with a 3700x CPU and this graphics card nails it out of the park as well and that's coming from an older 3570k and a Nvidia 980 GPU.

If I had any con for this card it's the fact that it is just the reference card and other manufacturers like Sapphire will likely be coming out with variants that are likely to be cooler in temperature but other than that
column2: it's incredible for what I use it for.

column1: Overall
column2: if you are looking for a cheaper equivalent of a 2070
column3: take a look at this. Look at benchmarks and see for yourself before making your purchase but if you want to save the money

column1: Jordan^/xfx-amd-radeon-rx-5700-xt-8gb-gddr6-pci-express-4-0-graphics-card-black/6358893?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^5^4^"Sorry for long review.
Short of it
column2: is its buggy/poorly optimized and constantly forces unprompted reboot or no display to be shown over display port and static on occasion over hdmi.

column1: I genuinely wanted to like the card as I have a freesync monitor and have always wanted amd products but it just isn't meant to be for now with all of the problems I have had.
I had this card for about a week
column2: I had ordered it and had it shipped to me (as the stores don't carry it). Install was great and fitment is good in an ATX case. This card performs well
column3: when it works that is. I generally place this card above a standard 2070 most of the time and rarely above the 2070 super
column4: for the price if it worked perfect; it would be excellent as fps in game when its working correctly is amazing for the price

column1: Now to the software and drivers and reliability side of the card. There is next to no stability with this early amd card. I had everything installed and routed perfectly inside my case
column2: but due to poorly optimized drivers and blower cooler this card will consistently blue screen
column3: drivers fail to black screen or forced reboot
column4: or just not work at boot until restart a couple times. I couldn't complete most tasks without a graphics driver or hardware failure. Attempted defrag of a storage drive crashed 10 minutes in due to graphics driver. I would say until things get sorted out with the new architecture you will have issues for several months or more.

column1: Sitting on the desktop for more than a couple minutes with absolutely nothing running was enough to cause a full driver/graphics card failure and I would often run downstairs to grab a drink and come back to find my computer had restarted and sitting on the look screen.
Great card if you don't mind tons and tons of bugs and issues
column2: including complete failure at the worst times (especially with a raid0 setup).

column1: Returned and purchased a more refined NVIDIA 2080 card and haven't had a single issue since
column2: even runs cooler with 20-40 fps better performance in games at a higher resolution.

column1: Would consider AMD again if they can get the bugs sorted out 'before' launching a product not 'after'.
This card is also very loud when you start pushing the card to the upper limits even with stock clocks and fan curve.
If you're looking to oc the card. Good luck
column2: barely pushed it to a 10 MHz overclock and it failed to even launch any game. Idk if it was a very unlucky lottery but I couldn't even maintain standard game clocks in a very decently ventilated case.

column1: Buy at your own risk
column2: idk recommend waiting a few months for aibs and more refined drivers/software."^2^Aug 16

I know AMD is still new to the GPU game so I'm not going to talk badly about them so all I can say is that for right now I'm going with the NVIDIA 2070 Super and I already miss the 5700 xt because I was getting way more fps with it but it does the job for me."^3^Dec 29

column2: and I wanted to give AMD a chance here. I thought any issues could be easily avoidable. I spent about 2 days dedicated to simply getting this card to run a game for 3 seconds. Any time a game starts trying to use the card
column3: it restarts my computer. Skips the blue screen and just kills the power. This card is very physically good
column4: but it is actually unusable. No matter what you try
column5: this card will find a way to let you down. Not a fault of XFX
column6: the card is built well. AMD has just really dropped the ball on drivers. Buy something else. Coming from someone who absolutely loved AMD just days ago."^1^Dec 8

Korn^/xfx-amd-radeon-rx-5700-xt-8gb-gddr6-pci-express-4-0-graphics-card-black/6358893?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^16^"I waited a little over a week for my 5700xt. Was excited when I got a text from bestbuy my item is ready for pick up. I got it today and installed it today and found that the display is not working. My motherboard showing red VGA light on. Switched  graphic card to another slot and it's doing same thing. Installed a friend 2070 and my display now works. Guess ima return my card and buy the 2070 or 2080 super."^1^Jul 27

Ravenrider808^/xfx-amd-radeon-rx-5700-xt-8gb-gddr6-pci-express-4-0-graphics-card-black/6358893?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^5^19^"I got this card as an alternative to getting an Nvidia 2070 or 2070 Super.  I ran it in my Ryzen 5 3600
column3: replacing an rx590.  I also ran it on two 2k monitors.

column1: I was disappointed when I ran a game (Battlefleet Armada II) and an open Chrome window on my other monitor.  I played for about 30 minutes and the computer completely shut down.  I touched the back of the video card and it was almost too hot to touch.
I checked the temp a few minutes later once I had everything booted up and the 5700xt was at 73c.  I tried running the same game again and the computer would not allow it
column2: closing it immediately right after I opened it.

column1: I re-installed my rx590
column2: which got up to 72 c as well
column3: did not shut down and ran two 2k screens.  My game only suffered by having to go from 'epic' settings to 'high' settings.

column1: Perhaps AIB cards will improve cooling along with bios updates.  I would steer clear of this early version for now.  I was very disappointed that I would have to go back to Nvidia
column2: who's price gouging at the moment.  Good luck out there!"^1^Jul 25

column1: Moneylaw^/xfx-amd-radeon-rx-5700-xt-8gb-gddr6-pci-express-4-0-graphics-card-black/6358893?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^23^38^"I did allot of research on this card before I bought it. Most of the reviewers and individuals that have this card have been running into major driver issues that could result in the computer black screening/rebooting.
Looks to be a issue with programs like MSI Afterburner and AMD Overlay/Wattman that are causing these issues.
If you even mess with the fan curve so this card does not run at 85-90c that will cause a black screen.
Something is majorly wrong with drivers 19.7.2 and 19.7.1.
Until these issues are confirmed resolved I would advise to stay away from this card.
I am very experienced with this type of hardware and troubleshooting there is nothing that can be done until the drivers are fixed.
The card runs very hot and if fans are turned up it is very very loud I would recommend to wait for aftermarket cooler versions that should be coming out within a month.
More or less AMD should have known better then to have released the 5700 series cards so quickly
column2: Need to iron out drivers first.

column1: Please note this review has factual information to it

column1: Rantman^/hdhomerun-connect-duo-tuner-free-live-ota-tv-black/6079607?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^50^15^"I bought this version of HDHomerun to connect to an over the air antenna based upon YouTube raves by Lon.TV and my interest in subscribing to their internet pad dvr feature (they never explain it is software
column3: I have not been able to get it to work yet. I am disturbed at the BAD documentation. There is NO NO NO video showing the basic install process so you don't know what to expect. You only get a piece of paper telling you to go to a website where it tells you to download an app. For Windows 10
column4: I had to go to the Microsoft store and download their free app. But all I got was a Green HD icon and when launched
column5: it showed a full black screen with the green HD logo an some text in the lower right. Nothing else. So I called support at 925-233-2240 and got a recording. They are in California and only work business hours there. But I called at about 3:30 California time and no answer
column6: and no response to my message. I called the next morning and left another message. It is now 7:30 am their time
column7: so maybe they will call. But right now the unit is useless. They do have a website with a troubleshooting database
column8: but no introductory video of how installation should work. They want me to do all the work of reading all their knowledge pages to find a solution. Not impressed. Now many people like this product
column9: so I will come back and fix this when I get a response and it is working
column11: and comment about BAD setup documentation. I am old school - I expect competent written and vidoe details on setup and use of a product and I could not even find a YouTube video by reviewers that showed the setup process. I am using Chrome and Windows 10 on a new Intel 8th generation i7 system and have a working wifi and internet. I even downloaded the app to my Android Samsung 10' tablet and got the same exact black screen. See the pictures. I am just trying to get the hard wired system to work."^3^Feb 21

column1: Scott^/hdhomerun-connect-duo-tuner-free-live-ota-tv-black/6079607?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^41^14^"Best Buy had this on sale for $79.99
column2: so I finally decided to purchase it after much research. As a cordcutter
column3: I'm always looking for a better way to view TV and save money. This device is worth the price and is very easy to install and setup. I was able to scan 39 crystal clear channels using only a flat digital antenna in a window. I suppose if I had a good roof mounted antenna
column4: I would likely get more channels. This is so much simpler than using a TV tuner. You just open the app on your streaming device and scroll through the channel guide for programs to watch. My family likes this very much which makes my life good. The only thing I do not like is the HDHomeRun app
column5: which has a very poor channel guide. I used the following workaround for my specific streaming devices:

column1: 1. For my 4K TV
column2: I installed the Live Channels app for Android TV on my Nvidia Shield. This app is nice because it also picks up streaming channels from several other installed apps
column3: so I'm getting about 170 channels. The channel guide in this app is also very good.

column1: 2. For my HDTV
column2: I purchased the Channels app from iTunes and installed it on my Apple TV 4. This app is also very nice with an excellent channel guide.

column1: I haven't setup the DVR functionality yet on either device
column2: but I don't expect any problems. I will connect a 1TB HD to my Nvidia Shield and I will probably use my iCloud drive for the Apple TV 4. So far I am very satisfied with my purchase."^5^Jul 6

column1: Lovethetech^/hdhomerun-connect-duo-tuner-free-live-ota-tv-black/6079607?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^18^4^"This silicondust connect worked like a charm. Very easy to set up. Just plug in the coax from your antenna
column2: then the Ethernet chord from the connect to your router and voila
column3: tv signal streamed to any connected tv. The signal is crystal clear as long as your devices are wired or you have a newer AC router. I did return it though as I wanted to run the signal through my plex system on my NAS. I got the hdhomerun extend because it has the built in transcoder so I wouldn't have to have my NAS do all the work while watching live tv or shows that I dvr'd while away from home. If you just want to stream to other tvs or iOS/android devices and you have a newer router
column5: and there's nothing wrong with that...it just works."^5^Sep 1

column1: StanM^/hdhomerun-connect-duo-tuner-free-live-ota-tv-black/6079607?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^17^3^"Plugged it in

column1: zpenguin^/hdhomerun-connect-duo-tuner-free-live-ota-tv-black/6079607?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^14^1^"HDHomeRun allows you to literally walk around the house with a TV in one hand. This would have been considered just a dream a few years ago and nobody 20 years ago would have dreamed of this. The TV I am describing is actually a tablet (iPad or Android - you supply yourself or sold separately). Although
column2: you should have a fairly good tablet and router to use this product. Since this product does not 'transcode' - i.e. compress the video on the fly
column3: there is a lot of data that has to be carried by your router (recommend AC router or better) and the tablet must be able to process this to avoid pixelation. The video will break up if you are any distance from your router unless you have a good AC1200
column6: AC3200 dual or triband router. An N router will work
column7: just don't stray too far from your router. Forget about using anything less than an N router - the pixelation and breakup of images make the product unusable. Also
column8: your client (tablet
column9: PC) on the receiving end should be a fairly good/modern product. Don't try to use an end-of-life product and expect good results. Other than that
column10: this product works very well using prescribed good tablet/router combination. Some bugs/minor-glitches on the client software
column11: but they are not too bad. Mainly just start the software on the tablet in landscape (not start the software in portrait orientation) and you should be just fine. In other words
column12: all the bugs are tolerable and if you work around them
column13: the product adds so much convenience and value that you forget about the short-commings. Don't expect perfect from this product
column14: especially considering its pricing as compared to other products. Also
column15: consider that you DO NOT have to pay a subscription like TiVo. The subscription on TiVo is highway robbery compared to free over the air TV and this product (compare
column16: and you will see what I mean). You can pay for a subscription on this product to get a better TV guide (channel listing)
column17: but that is optional and only if you want PVR and extended channel listing capability. This is a very good product for the price."^4^Nov 5

column1: Hutchewon^/hdhomerun-connect-duo-tuner-free-live-ota-tv-black/6079607?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^18^5^"If you are tired of paying for cable or satellite TV
column2: this device can be the backbone of your over the air system. It will let you watch and record TV via most devices on your home WiFi network. If you have a media center PC or a NAS you can also use it as a DVR so you can watch recorded programming on your tablet (IOS
column5: game console). One great aspect of this
column6: is that you don't have to pull antenna cable to watch TV in all the rooms in your house. Since it is on your WiFi network
column7: you can even watch TV in your yard as long as your WiFi sighal is strong enough.

column1: You can also purchase additional HDHomeruns if you need more tuners."^5^Jun 30
pdub^/hdhomerun-connect-duo-tuner-free-live-ota-tv-black/6079607?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^10^0^"I purchased this to enable live TV on my Plex server. This works perfectly for that."^5^Aug 18
TheGoodHusband^/hdhomerun-connect-duo-tuner-free-live-ota-tv-black/6079607?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^10^1^"Well
column2: I cut the cord over a year ago and have been looking for a better way to share my Antenna between multiple TV that could include my laptop
column3: etc. I had originally split the antenna across the TVs directly
column4: but the signal loss didn't provide the quality that I was hoping for.

column1: I have a Synology NAS and a house full of ROKU devices
column2: so I was looking for a solution that could potentially leverage all of this and give some DVR capabilities. I have thought about getting an HDHomeRun for years... and so I jumped in. The device
column3: in and of itself is very stable and the setup is easy. You can download the HDHomeRun DVR app for multiple devices ... EXCEPT THE ROKU!

column1: I had the ability to directly connect it to my NAS and being able to setup to DVR. I did have the ability to access the tuners from the ROKU leveraging the Media Center App and then select the channels individuals from there
column2: but no channel guide or mechanism to schedule a DVR event.

column1: Ultimately
column2: the integration level with ROKU was where it failed for me. I have zero desire to run plex on my NAS so since there isn't a native Roku app for the HDHomeRun it just wasn't going to work for me.

column1: That being said
column3: the video quality is solid and there are multiple devices you can connect it to: Laptops
column5: cellphones... just not the one device that I purchased this for (Roku).

column1: Needless to say
column2: I returned the device and spent the extra $$$ to get a Tablo. Had it up and running in just a few minutes and is great... but that will be a different review. Do not let my review talk you out of this device (unless you are trying to connect it to your Roku).

column1: My Criteria for Stars is as follows:
1 - Product did not work for primary designated functionality
column2: was poor quality. I would never recommend this product.

column1: 2 - Product may have worked for primary functionality
column2: but may also have been poor quality. I would likely not recommend the product.

column1: 3 - Product may be useful in some scenarios
column2: but didn't meet my primary needs. Product was likely inferior in quality. I would likely not recommend the product.

column1: 4 - Product likely didn't meet all of my needs but was otherwise high quality. I would likely recommend the product with caveats.
5 - Product met or exceeded all of my needs and I would definitely recommend the product."^4^Feb 1

column1: However
column2: that's where it fails a bit. Without the Connect
column3: I was able to pick up most channels in my area (Nashville
column5: including the NBC and PBS affiliates that run on Hi-VHF. However
column6: when I plugged in the Connect

Olebon^/hdhomerun-connect-duo-tuner-free-live-ota-tv-black/6079607?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^1^"The device works as described. The electronics is really nice. I live in an area with a low signal and I use an antenna amplifier
column2: bur for this receiver the amplifier had an opposite effect
column3: i.e. it picks more channels when no amplifier connected. The bad part is that to use it as a free DVR you need to be a real guru
column4: however paid services work great. I gave up with free DVR idea and subscribed to Plex ($5 a month). The receiver supports all possible protocols and is discovered by most software and hardware tools in a second

column1: I purchased this to watch OTA TV on a TV that has no cable drop nearby. Antenna is plumbed into a cable network that functions without issues on other TVs. Heres the outcome on different devices that SiliconDust advertises as compatible with HDHomeRun:
Amazon Fire Stick Gen2
- Video freezes every 5 seconds for at least one second.
- Audio lags video about 1.5 seconds.
This was tested on a Fire Stick that streams 1080p HD video with no issues. There are several online reviews noting this issue.
Bottom line: Unusable.
Windows 7
- Receives video
column2: but no audio. This is a known issue for which SiliconDust offers three workarounds.

column1: 1. Use an HDMI device. Sorry
column2: does not work thru an HDMI device.

column1: 2. Reconfigure the preview application in HDHomeRun Setup applications tab. Theres no applications tab in Setup.
3. Install another audio decoder  no specific steps offered.
Bottom line: HDHomeRun is not plug-n-play on Windows 7; unusable.
iPhone
- App actually functions as designed on the iPhone.
But
column2: why one would choose to watch TV on a phone when youre surrounded with full-sized TVs and monitors is beyond me. (Remember
column3: this is Wi-Fi technology which basically limits its use to inside your home.)

column1: Technical Support
- Still no response 24-hours after submitting a ticket with very detailed explanation of issues.
Im running SiliconDusts latest firmware edition - 20170815. Streaming Rate is 13.276 Mbps.
Summary:
Big promises
column2: but technology not yet developed for consumer use."^2^Aug 24

column1: skier^/hdhomerun-connect-duo-tuner-free-live-ota-tv-black/6079607?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^5^"On the box it says 'dual OTA DVR'. After connecting the ethernet and antenna
column2: there was no way to connect to my TV. Now that I look through reviews I see I need a Smart TV which I don't. When connected to ethernet
column3: the App ran on my W7 computer and said it was not compatible. I need a W10 computer. The 'DVR' must be in the cloud because it said I had to subscribe to a service to get DVR. I am taking it back. As far as I can tell
column4: this is only good for people who watch TV on tablets and have good internet service."^2^Mar 18

column1: David^/hdhomerun-connect-duo-tuner-free-live-ota-tv-black/6079607?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^5^8^"I was currently a subscriber of TiVo and had the Romeo OTA DVR. This box connects directly to your television with an HDMI cord. I do not however like the $15 a month subscription to TiVo for the channel guide. So I decided to give this a try.
I connected to my gigabit Ethernet network and accessed it with my Nvidia Shield using live channels app to access it. Even with a gigabit router and all gigabit wired connections
column2: I still found the bitrate to my Nvidia Shield through the network was not what I would have liked. It did appear to me that the TiVo picture was better especially in fast action motion like football. There does tend to be some pixelation of the datastream in fast action with the hdhomerun.

column1: I did try the hdhomerun app and found it to be user-unfriendly. As far as channel surfing and setting up recordings live channels from Google is superior for now. The only thing I didn't like about live channels from Google was that you could not watch the show you were currently recording you had to wait until the recording was over to watch it.

I think in time these devices will be better but for now I went back to my TiVo roamio OTA. The DVR function there is much better and the picture is clear throughout the show. I am disappointed I really hoped I could get rid of the TiVo but I hate to say that is still a superior product"^3^Aug 21

FeelingBurnt^/hdhomerun-connect-duo-tuner-free-live-ota-tv-black/6079607?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^2^5^"The product name is HDHomeRun Connect. We are working on updates to better handle HD channel playback.'
After purchasing this 'HD' product
column2: how long are their customers supposed to wait before it delivers on its namesake? I will be returning mine tomorrow."^1^Jul 28

column1: Dale^/hdhomerun-connect-duo-tuner-free-live-ota-tv-black/6079607?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^3^6^"I bought this for a live TV streaming tool for TV's in my home that had Streaming sticks or Roku's so that I could get broadcast TV to places like my Best rooms or Office
column2: or Master bedroom where the cabling just doesn't match up with the arrangement of the room. The device it's self-works great. on the Computer or the Phone. As it was designed. However
column3: I use Plex and the interface only works for the phone. or the computer. The DVR function is great. but the Plex part has a hard time with the live stream even on the Computer. I can stream the same content on the computer great with the native application. Streaming it with Plex. Plex complains about not having good signal. Not being able to display the resolution and other reasons. I am sure the issue is with Plex not the device. but if that is your reason for getting it. this is still early development on the interface.

column1: The Android TV I reviewed earlier works great with the interface playing the DVR content. can't stream the live tv any better than the phone or computer. The Plex Roku interface will not allow the live TV streaming. Nor will the Fire TV. those are not short comping of the HomrunHD they re short comping of Plex. but if those are your reasons for buying. Wait. The Tech is not there yet.

If your wiling to do everything native on the HomrunHD Only VLC for MAC or the interface for Windows(primary native development) then it works grate. If your planning on getting this for PLEX your going to be disappointed. for a little while longer."^3^Jul 28
HiTekRedNek^/hdhomerun-connect-duo-tuner-free-live-ota-tv-black/6079607?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^0^5^"They lead you to believe this gives you free tv
column2: or at least more channels than just an antenna would. It doesn't. All you need is an antenna. Igblot^/hdhomerun-connect-duo-tuner-free-live-ota-tv-black/6079607?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^0^1^"Plugged it in. Connected via Ethernet to get the most stable Internet connection. Connected a previously bought outdoor antenna
column2: which is compact enough to fit almost inconspicuously on an end table in my computer room. Used Antenna Point for an accurate line of sight direction to aim my antenna toward the local TV transmitters in my area. Downloaded the HDHomerun app from the Play Store to all my devices. Opened the app on my iPhone. Clicked on my model. Clicked on Channel Lineup. Clicked on Detect Devices and let it scan for stations in my area. It came up with a whooping 55. Very satisfied. Couple of things you should know. Weak internet connections and poor antenna range and placement will result in glitching
column4: frozen pictures. Two annoying drawbacks have me giving it four instead of five stars. For some reason it will intermittently lose lip sync and the guide interface is very rudimentary and amateurish. Good point - unless you plan on recording TV programs
column5: you can watch live TV programs received by your antenna for free. If you are at all technology challenged
column6: you might want to bite the bullet and spend the extra bucks to get local channels via your cable or satellite plan."^4^Jun 22

column1: btb2k^/pny-nvidia-geforce-gtx-1050-2gb-gddr5-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card-black/5711723?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^16^0^"I was skeptical in purchasing this card and honestly didn't think it'd meet what I was looking for but it did! It's been a while since I played Diablo 3 on my i7 Desktop (which formerly had a GTX 560 card in it) with Windows 10 but recently decided to start playing some of those games again. Suffice to say Blizzard has been busy updating and since all the updates to both D3 and Starcraft II it didn't run very well (let's just say not at all LOL) so
column2: I had to find a replacement without upgrading my whole computer.

column1: Installation:
It was super easy to install in a matter of minutes
column2: I simply removed the old card and put this one in. Didn't need to mess with the power supply at all as it is more than large enough (600 W) and in fact
column3: this card didn't need the 6 pin power connections that my old card did!

column1: The verdict:
For the Blizzard games
column2: the performance overall is a HUGE improvement over the old card - literally night/day difference!! I was hoping for that without spending a ton! For Diablo 3
column3: I was able to crank everything to High and it ran smooth again. The same for Starcraft 2
column4: where I was able to put it to Ultra without any issues - pretty awesome for this card as honestly I didn't think it'd be able to run as smooth as it does. So
column5: I'd imagine most newer games will run just fine for anyone who is looking for a good entry level card.

column1: For a quick budget-friendly upgrade
column2: this worked great for me and is everything I needed to hold off to upgrade to a completely new PC once I decide to get into VR after it standardizes more. Which brings me to my last note .. It is important to note this card does NOT appear to support VR according to the GeForce Experience Software (which was not a need for me)
column3: but it's worth knowing if that's what you are looking for. Outside of that I'd highly recommend this card to get you by if you're looking to upgrade an older card like I had."^5^Jul 23

Chandler^/pny-nvidia-geforce-gtx-1050-2gb-gddr5-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card-black/5711723?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"Bought this GPU for my system as an upgrade from a r7 250 1gb ddr5. The 2 gb ddr5 this GPU has makes a phenomenal difference.
My PC runs on an i3 6100
column4: 1080p 60 hz monitor. and now this brand new GTX 1050. I was a little worried that the 2gb version of this card wouldn't be worth the money but it is.

column1: I have played Planetside 2 a lot with this card. Used to play on Low Settings and got ~30 fps. Now I can easily play on Ultra and get 60 fps when doing non-graphic heavy stuff but in the middle of a firefight with lots of other players (as it happens to be in Planetside) it drops to ~25 or so. But you can lower your settings to gain a more consistent frame rate.
I also played COD IW Zombies at the recommended settings (which look great imo) at 60 fps.
Assassins creed black flag can be handled well also. At Ultra settings
column2: the card does struggle. But this card isn't for ultra. At medium to high settings
column4: I easily got a consistent 60 fps.

column1: To recap
column2: this is for casual pc gamers who like their games to look nice at 1080p
column3: don't need 4k resolution at 100fps (read overkill graphics)
column4: and don't wan't to spend lots of cash."^5^Dec 22

partman1969^/hdhomerun-extend-tuner-for-free-live-ota-hdtv-with-transcoder-black/5939700?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^19^4^"I recently cut the cable and installed an antenna. The tuner in this box allows you to record and/or watch as many as 2 channels at the same time while also transcoding recorded files to smaller sizes more suitable to wireless tablets
column3: or streaming boxes on less robust networks. If more tuners are necessary just add a splitter to the coax and network in additional HDHomerun tuners as necessary. Two of these boxes would allow 4 tuners
column4: 3 of these boxes would allow 6 tuners

mybbreviews^/hdhomerun-connect-quatro-tuner-free-live-ota-tv-black/6079602?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^32^12^"HDHomeRun tuners have a software/hardware flaw (who knows which as SiliconDust doesn't care enough to even attempt to resolve the issue)
Began having an issue with a VHF OTA channel distorting picture/audio cutting out every few seconds. the signal was near 100%
column2: and the TV tuners built into my TV's didn't have this issue at all.

column1: I opened a support ticket w/ silicondust. they believed the signal for channel 7 (vhf 177mhz) was just too strong for hdhomerun to handle
column2: thus that was the cause of the distortion.

column1: silicondust asked me to remove the amp and report back on the ticket
column3: )but of course they're now ignoring the ticket) so:

column1: i removed the amp
column2: which decreased the signal strength by 50%... same issue. i added 9db worth of attenuators
column3: same issue. this is literally the only channel on hdhomerun that has a problem. nnone of my tv's native tuners have issues with this channel.

column1: hdhomerun hasn't responded to the ticket in a week. i've read other complaints on the forum of identical vhf issues
column2: and in the end silicondust basically just ignores the user instead of stepping up to the plate and escalating/resolving

column1: *** for anyone else looking for a solution - buy a Hauppauge WinTV tuner! it has ZERO issues with my vhf channel 7/177mhz. none
column2: zip. and is 100% plex compatible. this is obviously an hdhomerun hardware or software issue. for an 'engineering company' they seem to take very little interest in troubleshooting an obvious flaw.

column1: i've owned 4 of HDHomeRun devices in the past
column2: and they've absolutely lost a customer due to how they've handled (or lack there of) my support ticket as well as many other complaints identical to mine.

column1: I hope this helps someone looking to purchase this device for OTA tuning - beware
column2: they have issues with towers that have strong signals??? and will NOT fix the issue."^1^Aug 11

column1: Kodiak^/hdhomerun-connect-quatro-tuner-free-live-ota-tv-black/6079602?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^10^4^"Looking to cut the cord and get rid of cable

column6: and the quality is as good (if not better) as with cable. I was also surprised to see how many unique channels are available over the air that aren't on cable.

column1: I remember how excited I was when we finally got cable on our street when I was a little kid--I could finally watch Nickelodeon at home. Now I'm just as excited that I'll be returning my cable boxes to the cable company in the next few days. I don't watch Nickelodeon anymore

column1: Dave^/hdhomerun-connect-quatro-tuner-free-live-ota-tv-black/6079602?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^6^2^"Pros: Reliable when mated to the right set-up
column2: Performs as I expected. The native HD Homerun software for viewing live TV is fast and has great picture/sound quality on the computer
column3: the Fire TV Streaming Box App

column1: Cons:
Software Limitations:
The software has no traditional grid-based program guide
column2: although the guide it has is still functional
column4: and very very quick. You need to pay extra for DVR functionality (or roll your own DVR software solution) and to get extended program guide information multiple days out.

column1: Hardware Limitations:

The tuners are not going to do as great a job at fixing weak antenna signals as you are probably used to with most built-in television tuners like you'd get with a Sony flat-screen TV. Part of that is the nature of sharing 1 signal with 4 tuners (as opposed to just 1 tuner in a TV). However
column3: I've observed that it's not entirely the number of tuners
column4: but also the nature of the tuners themselves. They are fairly sensitive to less than ideal signals so for this to work reliably for you
column5: you will need to put in the effort (and possibly some money
column6: if needed) to make sure that your OTA signal coming from the antenna is strong and of good quality. I would suggest looking into a good quality outdoor antenna and a good pre-amp.

column1: The shielding of the device itself could leave a little to be desired. I've noticed that if you move the device around on a desk
column2: your signal quality and strength can change a bit based on the box's proximity to other pieces of computer equipment you have nearby. That hints that the shielding is not as great as it could be."^4^Oct 9

compguru910^/evga-geforce-rtx-2080-xc-ultra-gaming-8gb-gddr6-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card/6290660?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^14^7^"Ugh
column2: how to lead into this. Well
column3: its fast. There is that. The GPU out of the box performs very well
column4: and as an upgrade to a GTX 1080
column5: its great. I play at 3440x1440 and in VR
column6: and honestly this card feel just right for this resolution. Problem is
column7: I have had a 1080ti before. This feels just like a 1080ti. The other problem with that
column8: is the 1080ti is cheaper at the moment. If you're a value minded consumer
column9: this isn't the GPU for you yet.

column1: I say yet because there is untapped potential in these cards. First
column2: there is the DLSS and RTX capabilities that we are simply waiting to be released. I don't expect anyone to buy on hopes
column3: so I wouldn't recommend this card simply based on that. Nvidia has given us no reason to believe these will be competent cards in that regard
column4: so don't believe they are. Secondly
column5: drivers. If this was pascal (10 series) I wouldn't recommend waiting on drivers to improve performance
column6: but they aren't. This isn't simply a rehash of Nvidias gaming arch of old
column7: this is a pretty fresh arch. I could dive into the techincals of it
column8: but I'll save that for elsewhere. But know that there are new cores in here running alongside the old cores that do things the other archs couldn't. It takes time to optimize these
column9: and thats what happening. How much
column11: I don't recommend buying on hope.

column1: Now
column2: if 1080ti performance is enough for you for a few dollars extra with the hope of better performance later and all the eye candy that comes with ray tracing
column3: or the increased performance with DLSS (at a minor visual hit)
column4: then this is the card for you (unless you have 2080ti money). If not
column5: don't buy it. Find yourself a 1080ti thats priced decently
column6: and go with that. It has more raw performance
column7: more memory
column8: and steady drivers."^4^Oct 12

Tomahawk^/evga-geforce-rtx-2080-xc-ultra-gaming-8gb-gddr6-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card/6290660?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^1^0^"So I have been trying to hold off on writing a review for some time so I could play with the card and see what it could handle/ do and how everything looks on some graphic intense games. So far I am not disappointed. So here is a breakdown to why I recommend it.

1) Performance: Because I also like to stream I try my best to keep up with the new games coming out and having a steady stream is important to me. So far running games such as PUBG and APEX (popular FPS currently) I haven't notice a drop below 60 fps during game play. A match from start to finish has been a smooth ride. on the other side of the spectrum I heavily mod Skyrim and the Witcher 3. Very high graphic games (post Modding with Skyrim) and I have yet to run into any clipping or other issues with rendering objects issues you would see in this game with my much older card. I currently have 4 monitors connected to the card. while one plays the game
column3: one has the stream open for me to notice any performance issues
column4: and the fourth lets me manage any other media platform i'm also using. to date I have not notice an issue with all this running at once
column5: and the fans on the card are very quite IMO.

column1: 2) Upgrade: I have been rocking a GTX 980 for about 4-5 years and I am able to tell the deference easily with the new upgrade. As I just noted
column2: everything is running smoother than before even with some heavily modded games. HOWEVER because I was back in the GTX 900 series I fell that anyone else at this level or lower should make the Jump to the RTX 2080. Simply because I don't try to keep up with the newest and coolest thing that just came out. when I make the purchase for a component such as this i try to keep it for as long as i possibly can. if you are currently in the GTX 1000 series spending the money honestly right now doesn't seem to be justified just yet. I say this because this time around we are not seeing crazy outstanding performance increase from the 1080's to the 2080's. Unless you have the cash burning a hole in your pocket
column3: you may want to wait till something new is released or Ray Tracing becomes more of a thing (i'm betting on it but i could be wrong).

column1: 3) Investing: This plays a little bit off the last part
column2: Ray Tracing. I honestly believe this is going to be brought into play sooner than others may expect (although I could be wrong). until recently Nvidia only had what they developed and to showcased last year what the possibility of what Ray tracing could do. however just recently using Unreal engine a stunning short video with ray tracing inside of it came out. diving deeper into it i found they added the support for Dx12 ray tracing
column3: and will be releasing this for development soon. With them moving forward with it i felt it was the right investment for me to get a 2080 rather than a cheaper 1080.

column1: In conclusion
column2: This is a great card. the price may be high but I plan to keep my card for the next 4-5 years at the least. if you are currently rocking a GTX 1000 series
column3: honestly hold off till the end of the year or maybe the first quarter of 2020
column4: because your card should be fine until something better with ray tracing actually comes out. (just because its released soon doesn't mean it we'll have a new game overnight) and hopefully further in the year the price will drop for the 2080's."^5^Apr 1

Tornado^/msi-geforce-rtx-2080-gaming-x-trio-8gb-gddr6-pci-express-3-0-graphics-card/6290654?variant=A&sort=MOST_HELPFUL^34^0^"INITIAL PRESENTATION:

This card is massive. Perhaps one of the largest 2080's you can buy. It is a non reference PCB (thats a good thing imo) and requires 2x 8 pin connections rather than the standard 1x 6pin and 1x 8pin connections. The back plate is nice and solid
column2: and has thermal pads under it to help with cooling. The card comes with a support bracket which I would recommend installing given the size and weight of this monster. Heatsink is massive. 3 Fans help keep it all cool. The 2 large fans spin up together at the same RPM
column3: the smaller fan spins up if the card gets a little hotter at a separate RPM. Hardware applications will report just 2 fan speeds
column4: and from what I have been able to tell
column5: the 2 big fans are reported together. In addition to the card you get the support bracket
column6: and a 6pin to 8pin adapter. Initial presentation is very good. It feels tightly put together
column7: solid
column8: heavy
column9: quality

column1: OVERCLOCKABILITY:
Short answer: 2070mhz core
column2: +1000mhz memory. You will max out the memory slider in MSI Afterburner. I think the memory would actually go higher if the slider went higher
column3: but at +1000 youre maxed out in the software - truly impressive memory overclock. Many people are running around +700 or +800 on memory overclocks from what Ive seen on the 2080's. Also just for reference my particular card came with Samsung memory modules
column4: as per GPU Z. The core clock honestly ends up being limited by the power limit. 109% is the highest power limit you can run on this card as of right now. This gives you enough headroom to run most games at around the 2070mhz mark
column5: which is still a great overclock. The card ran at 1995mhz under full load right out of the box before I even touched it. I ranOC Scanner then adjusted the curve manually so that at the higher voltage draws (load) I would top at 2100mhz. Due to the afformentioned power limit however
column6: you rarely see 2100mhz as it gets throttled. Still
column7: at 2070mhz core and 8
column8: 000mhz memory speed
column9: I am seeing a nice bump in performance over a stock 2080
column10: and closing the gap a little on a stock 2080ti. I consider the card a great overclocker that is actually limited right now by its own bios and software. At these speeds and under full load I never saw anything above 68 degrees C
column11: and in many games I sit around 62C...Really impressive. This card has the best you will find in air cooling. The RGB lighting and Mystic Light V3 software are a nice addition. There are lots of different lighting presets you can play with in the software - probably a good 15 options or so of various effects and animations then you can customize your own colors if you'd like.

column1: PERFORMANCE:
Performance is about what you would expect if youve seen other reviews or benchmarks of the 20 series. Im around 10
column2: 500 in 3d mark timespy benchmark (defaults) with an i7 7700k at 4.8ghz and ddr4 3000 memory. The card drives most all the games I play currently to my personal magic number
column3: which is 120fps. Im running an ultrawide 3440x1440 monitor that has a refresh rate of 120hz. The whole purpose of getting this card
column5: was to push 120fps to the monitor to take full advantage of the panel refresh rate. Where my 1080 powered many games (like BF5) at around 90 or 95 fps
column6: with this card I am hitting that 120fps mark. Call of Duty Black ops 4 easily tops 120fps at ultra graphics
column7: 3440x1440 resolution
column8: only occasionally dropping below my 120 cap just a few frames. This is all I wanted it to do - push high/ultra settings at 120fps
column9: and it does it in most games. The nice overclock I get form the card as mentioned in the previous section also helps a lot. I hope in a future bios release they up the 109% power limit on the card
column10: because I think you could push this core right on up to
column11: and above
column12: 2100mhz. The thermal headroom is there thanks to the great cooling solution on the card
column14: non reference PCB and backplate. There is more surface area to spread the heat
column15: and the heatsink and fans are both bigger than many of the competitor cards.

column1: STABILITY / RELIABILITY
With all the news of 20 series failures
column2: this was the one thing that really occupied my mind when I bought this card. There has been a lot of talk online about potential problems with the 20 series and failure rates - particularly the 2080ti
column3: and even more particularly the founders edition cards. Nonetheless
column4: my first priority was to hammer this card as hard as possible after purchase with heavy
column5: prolonged loads. Ive looped intense benchmarks like furmark
column6: 3d mark
column7: heaven
column8: and others for hours on end
column9: some even ran all night long while I slept
column10: and I have not had the card crash or fail a single time thus far. Im over 2 weeks into ownership now but have logged dozens of hours of actual full load processing on the card. My theory is that if it is a dud
column11: or if it is going to fail
column12: I want it to fail right now so that I can take it back. I have a 45 day return window with bestbuy so If it is a dud I want to know it asap
column13: and that is why I have hammered the card so hard in testing. Thus far however I have been unable to make it crash. The only issue I have noted since upgrading from my 1080 is occasionally I get some weird flickering on one of my 2 screens (I run a double monitor set up). This flickering will occur just sitting at desktop sometimes
column15: or watching a video or stream. I have determined however that this issue appears to be driver related
column16: and is related to GSYNC. If I disable
column17: and re-enable GSYNC in the video drivers then the flickering goes away completely. I've not been able to determine what the onset is however. It seems to just randomly start happening sometimes
column18: and its somewhat rare. In 2 weeks for example Ive had it happen maybe 6 times
column19: and every time I've just been at desktop or browsing online
column20: very light load on the video card. Toggling gsync off and back on has always fixed it
column21: so feel strongly that this is a driver issue that will get fixed. I did flash to the latest BIOS for the card and it had no impact on the issue
column22: it has occurred a few times since the flash. If I felt for a second that this was a hardware level defect then I would return the card immediately
column23: but I'm convinced it is driver related
column24: otherwise toggling gsync wouldn't fix it. Ive never had the issue show up while in a game or benchmark loop however
column25: which is where you would logically expect a hardware problem to really show up. Temperatures even under multi hour benchmark loops never went above 68c. Often sat in mid 60's under full load.

column1: FINAL WORD:
If youre in the market for a 2080
column4: then I can recommend the MSI Gaming X Trio enough. I feel perosnally that this is THE best 2080 you can buy. I say that because it has what I think is the largest heatsink on the market
column5: and some of the largest fans
column6: coupled with a solid metal backplate. Not only does it have potentially the biggest cooling solution
column7: but it is also on perhaps the largest PCB. This isnt a reference PCB
column8: it is a custom built PCB from MSI and is larger
column9: meaning it has a larger footprint for heat spread
column10: including on the backplate which coves the entire back. I also like that the card runs on 2x 8pin connections. Most every other 2080 you look at will run on 1x 8pin and 1x 6pin
column11: so this board has access to more power. So you got the best air cooler
column12: more power headroom
column14: with stellar overclocking results. I dont know of a better 2080. Maybe you could point to the 109% power limit cap...that's the only negative that I could potentially see. However
column15: my testing has shown that even with 109% power cap I am still sitting clos to where most people are topping out their 2080 core clocks. You eventually just run out of voltage room on these cards given the vcore is locked by nvidia
column16: and thats true for all cards.

column1: PROS:
+Large
column2: Custom PCB. Not a reference design

column1: +2x 8pin rather than 1x 6pin and 1x 8pin.
+Largest heatsink and cooling solution to my knowledge on the market for a 2080. Temps sit mid 60's under full load and full overclock.
+Nice RGB lighting and backplate design. The card looks sharp.
+Comes with support bracket
column2: cause this thing is a beast.

column1: CONS:
- Only 109% power limit as of this writing in afterburner. Future bios could open this number up as weve seen with some other manufacturers in the past."^5^Nov 26
